text: Sussan Ley is a class operator and correct when she says this is a once in a generation opportunity for reform. I would expect the government to adopt most if not all of the final recommendations later this year.
author: TimOfAltona

text: A good friend friend of mine who lives in QLD tells me Newman has tried to do too much too quickly - changing the world overnight and he has managed to leave some people behind with some decisions. I suspect he will slow down the pace of change to better reflect community expectations.

text: Time for the Labor/Greens cheer squad to take stock of their crass insensitivity to people dying and being killed just so they can try and land confected blows against the government.

text: Good to see Abbott taking a world leadership position on pressuring Russia to allow access to the crash site. Abbott and Bishop are leading the charge on behalf of the relatives of the murdered Australians as well as all the other nationalities - exactly what we expect of our PM.

text: Can't see that happening myself, still over 2 years to go before the next election and plenty of time for the polls to turn around which they undoubtedly will as Abbott's policies gain traction and Labor's mismanagement of our economy is reversed by the new government.

text: What a load of crap. Your greatest fear is that Abbott gets the recognition he deserves for doing all he can to bring the dead Australians' home - you put your cheap political point scoring ahead of the deaths of Australian men, women and children and the grieving of their relatives.

text: The Greens already have enough power - they keep the Labor party afloat - in fact without the Greens, Labor would be lucky to cobble together a dozen seats in the Lower House.

text: Gee Bob, maybe it has something to do with Labor blowing all our cash reserves and we have to borrow money from overseas to fund foreign aid programs and then pay a billion dollars a month in interest payments.

text: Yes, the absolute cruelty of preventing perhaps a thousand more deaths at sea since last September is unfathomable - just can't comprehend how cruel that policy is...all those lives saved.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I don't think Mr Bean gets it - Australia does not have the ability to keep borrowing money  overseas only to send it  overseas as foreign aid and be left standing with an interest bill of a billion dollars a month to cover it.

text: Labor may have looked good for a while with their smoke and mirrors budgets, but sooner or later we have to actually pay that money back that Labor kept on borrowing and reduce the debt.

text: The current group on board the customs vessel did not have a man with a gun at their head when they departed for Australia. They came from the relatively prosperous Tamil state in Southern India. They were not escaping fearing for their lives or escaping persecution - 70 million people live happily in Tamil Naidu... they were coming to Australia hoping to tap into our welfare system and perhaps get a job and perhaps give their families a better head start in life - there are tens of millions queued up behind them wanting to do the same thing.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The other news is that the Tamil Governor of that state is attempting to legislate for Sri Lankan Tamil refugees to be granted Indian citizenship to help them integrate and give them equal rights for employment, health care & education.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Yes - people smugglers do exist in the  world and yes, people hoping to bypass the UNHCR program and get to Australia by illegal boat do pay people smugglers for the service.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The people 'crewing' the boats are not the people smugglers - they are being paid by the people smugglers to do the job - the people smugglers have made millions of dollars and a % of this goes to the corrupt police, military and assorted Indonesian government officials who are also on the payroll to facilitate the safe departure of the boats from Indonesia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Also, many of the people paying people smugglers are not genuine asylum seekers - they are economic migrants looking to tap into Australia's welfare system and with any luck get a job here.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You pretty much have to go back to the Labor government under Kevin Rudd that opened up our borders and got the people smuggling industry back on it's feet. Tens of thousands of people climbed into people smuggler boats and headed for Australia, many hundreds drowning along the way.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The new government came in to fix up Labor's mess and is making good progress - the ultimate aim is to close down all processing centres, on and off shore. This will be achieved by stopping the boats - so far so good on that front - much to the annoyance of the Labor cheer squad who wanted the boats to keep arriving just so they could come into the Guardian threads and proclaim yet another Abbott promise broken. Good to see that little piece of enjoyment has been denied.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Thank you Longers - at last a Labor supporter who acknowledges that the government is doing the right thing in it's efforts to bring our dead home to their families.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Pretty much all the other's are attacking Abbott and Bishop with confected abuse over the handling and response to the tragedy. I guess their key issue is that they want it to be a  PM doing all this, not a Liberal and they can't bring themselves to acknowledge that Abbott and co have done a bloody good job so far in doing everything we can to help the families and bring their deceased loved ones home.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny thing is though, you have to stop the boats to achieve that - otherwise, as we saw under Labor, the detention centres keep on filling up, even having to open up new ones to cope with the thousands arriving by boat each month.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Now come clean with the Australian people Crowey - you know as well as all of us here that had Abbott left the country to attend a meeting in Palau, you and the rest of the cheer squad would be up in arms attacking him for running away and leaving the the families of the victims of MH17.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Best to give up on your attacks over Abbott and MH17 - he is doing what we expect the Australian PM, Labor or Liberal, to be doing and that is firstly - doing everything humanly possible to help the families & to bring their loved ones home and secondly doing all the Australian government can to to assist in bringing the perpetrators to justice.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Some events transcend domestic politics and this is one of them - follow the lead of your Labor party who have thrown their weight behind Abbott to help him get this job done.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I think the Labor supporters give Murdoch way too much credit - whilst he was a useful distraction for them away from their internal disunity and dysfunction - I suspect he holds little if any sway over Australian domestic politics. Ask former PM's Rudd and Gillard, they 'consulted' with Murdoch over dinners and lunches whenever they were in NY - I doubt they would support the conspiracy theorists active in these threads today (aka Labor cheer squad) that Murdoch influenced them one way or the other.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Who cares if Abbott discussed the PPL with Murdoch over dinner, he probably discussed a lot of things going on at the time - the PPL scheme was on Abbott's radar years before any dinner with Murdoch - it was out in the public domain back in 2010.
author: TimOfAltona

text: They all beat a path to Murdoch's door when they to NY- Hawke, Howard, Rudd, Gillard, Abbott all have lunches and dinners with the News Corp chairman. Shorten will be working his way to meeting him as soon as he can swing it - if he holds onto the leadership that is.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The truth can be hurtful at times...we have all been there. Don't give up though - there  a place for Labor - it's just that this is not the time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Most are living in denial that Murdoch was calling a bad government for what it was, a bad government. At any examination the Rudd-Gillard-Rudd years were not the best for Labor - dysfunction, back stabbing and leaks were a daily occurrence.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Even the ALP's internal report on last year's election failure stated it was down to internal dysfunction fueled by intense and very public rivalry between the Gillard and Rudd camps.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The ALP's current leader, Shorten, was a key player/contributor to all the unfolding dramas and has, thanks to the unions, been rewarded with a temporary seat at the head of the table. He will not survive in that role if Labor is to have any chance of forming a government in the years ahead.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I gotta say...no matter how many hundreds or thousands of times the Labor/Greens cheer squad type "Election now' or 'DD now' it will NOT bring late 2016 any closer or faster than the normal passage of time - just a tip.

text: Save your key boards and keystrokes for working out how the ALP are to reform themselves and sort out their dysfunctional leadership debacles and future direction. This may assist the ALP one day, perhaps a couple of terms away, being a viable alternative government.

text: The PM is doing what we expect of our PM - doing all he can to get the dead Australians home to their families - clearly this does not sit well with you. How many family members did you lose on the flight?

text: Shorten is trying his best to reignite the "Light on the Hill' rhetoric - but this will fall largely on deaf ears - Australia has moved on from all that working class romanticism crap largely because so many more of us are much better off than we were 20 or 30 years ago.

text: Shame the cheer squad can't throw their support behind Abbott and Bishop's efforts to bring our dead Australians home to their families - in fact they are outright criticising them for doing what we expect them to be doing and achieving. From what I see and hear, the PM is being praised around the globe for his leadership achievements after the tragedy.

text: Abbott has been surviving off minimal sleep since the MH17 disaster - he has been working during different time zones to discuss/coordinate the situation with various world leaders and our team on the ground - typically Europe between 2 and 4 in the morning and then going on to do a full days work. You choose to comment on his eyes as 'evil'. Try tired comrade.

text: is why Labor are out of office for the next 2-3 terms - the disconnect from reality blinds their judgement to the point that they live in a parallel universe from mainstream Australia.

text: Exactly - I have been saying this for some time but keep on being shot down in flames by the Labor cheer squad....seriously, if Labor are to have any hope of forming government over the next 6-9 years they need to refocus on reform - Labor and their supporters banging on about the evil Tony Abbott & hoping that will be enough to get them over the line is pure delusion and will ensure they stay in opposition for years to come.

text: A quick check of the betting markets shows me you are wrong and will blow your thousand bucks - the bookies have Abbott and the Coalition as outright favs to win... understandably so, Labor have no hope until they sort themselves out... years away yet.

text: This interview confirms everyones suspicions that she is way out of her depth when it comes to that shadow portfolio. Foreign Affairs aint Tania's strength, in fact she is a liability.

text: If this is the best Labor can muster and with the hapless Shorten as interim Labor leader, the Coalition are looking at perhaps an extra term in government, on top of the next two coming up.

text: God forbid that the ABC has the  to allow LNP guests onto the Drum, we  want left wing guests on the Drum. It is very important that we only hear the views of the left on the Drum, the last thing we want is to hear the views of our government...that just won't do will it comrade?

text: Smart move by Morrison...the message is still loud and clear to people smugglers ....this government will deny you a product to sell...you will have to wait until a Labor/Greens government is back in power before you can start up your insideous trade again.

text: The left are on the wrong side of public opinion on this one and lost the argument a long time ago...this government is to be congratulated for delivering on what they promised and what we voted for last September. Labor were just not up to the task...how many PM's did they go through and how many Immigration ministers did Labor churn through - was it 5 or 6? None of them up to the task - all failures.

text: The Labor/Greens cheer squad, all 150 of them, would taking to the streets with their pitch forks, flaming torches and burning effigies of the PM - oh wait a minute - they are already doing that. LOL

text: The government has not been forced to send these people to the mainland, they are doing it out of humanitarian compassion whilst it is determined where they will ultimately be sent - India, Nauru or Manus.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The turn back the boats policy has been highly successful - no boats have made it through from Indonesia, where 99% of departures were occurring. This was not being done way up in Southern India for obvious reasons and if it was, this boat would not have made it this far.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The policy of labor and the Coalition has been highly successfully and has effectively saved perhaps thousands of people from drowning, something unimaginable back when K Rudd was running things.
author: TimOfAltona

text: These people needed to be removed from the boat while the high court proceedings are ongoing. It is the right thing to do to bring them ashore temporarily until the High Court judgement is handed down and then they can either be returned to Tamil southern India or over to Manus or Nauru for processing. It is fairly likely these are economic migrants simply looking to improve their lives in Australia so either they return to India or their original homeland. Those determined to be  refugees can be resettled in a third country such as PNG, Nauru or Cambodia.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You seem to be confused .the police are there for security dutiescrash investigators and forensic teams will be doing the work on the wreckage and human remains. The police are there because it would be too problematic for ADF or any troops from any country to be on the ground in that situation.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Julie Bishop and her Dutch counterpart are making good progress in Kiev to bring this about with Ukrainian authorities whilst Abbott is dealing with Putin on the Russian side to allow unrestricted access for the multi-national police contingent to provide security whilst the forensic and recovery teams do their vital work.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Correct, the same occurred in 9/11. The key to this is forensic examination of the various crash sites to occur as quickly as possible before too much evidence or remains are lost...hence the government pushing for a security team to assist with this process.
author: TimOfAltona

text: If he were to say or do nothing you would be on here attacking him for just that - so when he is proactive, as a PM should be, you attack him for just that.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The crash zone is 50 sq km, the multi national police team will comprise Dutch and Australian and perhaps other countries. Australia's contribution is 50, the Dutch may have hundreds there....you talk as if Australia is the only country sending police....providing the MOU with the Ukraine works out and the Russians agree to support it, the police will be on the ground in the Ukraine within 24-48 hrs and the search and removal of human remains can continue.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Shame the Labor/Greens cheers squad are more concerned about a lift in the polls for the PM than they are for the families of the victims of MH17 -it's clear the government is doing a fine job and all decent Australians applaud their efforts to get our dead home to their families.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to know this is the best talent the ALP can muster - the Coalition are staring down the barrel of 4 terms with turkeys like this batting for the other team.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bishop and Houston, along with the Dutch Foreign Minister, are in Kiev this afternoon arranging for a MOU with the Ukrainian PM which will allow a multi-national police force to attend the site so that the remaining bodies can be located and removed and the investigators do their work unhindered. It looks likely the Russians will assist with this process in dealing with the Donekst rebels - but how that eventuates remains to be seen.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Dutch have the lead on this, having lost the majority of citizens and are likely to make up the majority of the police securing the 50km wide zone.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good on Abbott for being proactive on this - not supported of course by those who fear the prospect of the government getting a boost in the polls out of this tragedy, but supported all the same by all decent Australians who want to see every effort made to bring our dead home.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Angus Houston is in Kiev with Bishop getting the memorandum of understanding sorted with the Ukrainian government to allow a multi-national police force into the area to protect the crash site so the remaining bodies can be located and crash investigators do their work - clearly that prospect of success in this area frightens you, but the majority of Aussies applaud what is going on and only a few sad and sorry people like you object.
author: TimOfAltona

text: It is a real shame that the Labor/Greens cheer squad are more concerned about the PM getting a lift in the polls than they are about bringing home our dead.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Clearly none of them have lost a loved one in the tragedy - if they had they would be praising the government's efforts as I'm sure those affected are at this terrible time.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Abbott, Bishop and all the others working on this are to be congratulated not condemned by the faux and confected outrage emanating from a sad and sorry bunch of people concerned the PM may actually come out of this looking good.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Forget the Greens, they will oppose anything and everything - let's hear from Labor on this - the Labor cheer squad have jumped in early on this before hearing what their party line is - Labor may well support the decision too.

text: What a load of crap - Gillard was the most detested PM in a generation - had she gone on to lead Labor to the election they would have been lucky to come away with 30 seats in the lower house - such was the feeling of animosity towards her - not only from mainstream Australia but within her own party. The only reason her and Combet were bosom buddies was because they were both marionettes for the powerful unions who dictated ALP policy through the PM placed into office..
author: TimOfAltona

text: The 'Gillard' experiment crashed and burned for Labor and they will never ever repeat that mistakenot if they ever want to return to government in this country. Gillard was a disaster - nearly destroyed her own party.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I turned on the radio in my car earlier today and , it was that unmistakable drone of Gillard's voice - I thought we as a country had cleansed ourselves of that auditory pornography assaulting our shell-likes without any prior warning.
author: TimOfAltona

text: But no - it was indeed Gillard assaulting the airwaves pushing some book by, like her, another failed Labor politician who is best remembered for under achievements than any over achievements or for that matter  achievements full stop.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I sat there wondering if she was reading from a McTernan script as she did for most her Prime Ministership or perhaps she was channelling K Rudd, her replacement, given he enjoyed significantly more support and respect from both the country and her  party than she could have ever dreamed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I'm writing to the ABC today to ensure they next time they are thinking of putting Gillard's voice to the airwaves, that it is preceded by a health warning to give us all plenty of time to switch stations.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Gillard (McTernan) started this whole confected sexism row as a tactic to try and prop up Gillard's failing leadership and now everyone has to be careful what they say as a result.

text: Re QT - it has developed into a bit of a circus with the Labor MP's acting like recalcitrant school children deliberately baiting the headmistress (Speaker) to see who gets to be thrown out the most. In fact Labor have turned it into a sport.

text: This is as much a reflection on Shorten's leadership as it is on the inadequacy of the Labor opposition - Australians have noticed this and will mark Labor's scorecard accordingly.

text: I suspect your comments have just lost any credibility that may have been left - I doubt even your own side can see that this is a bullshit concoction of yours with no basis whatsoever except a deep hatred of anything to do with the PM.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Funny old thing politics - in the months leading up to last years election the Labor/Greens cheer squad went into hiding when it came to discussing or reflecting on the polls and if they did it was all about how they are all fake and rigged to help Abbott win.

text: the polls have transformed from being highly dubious and a totally unreliable tool of a giant media conspiracy against Labor into a highly credible and accurate source of how voters feel about the government.

text: Don't worry about that comment - it's the Labor/greens cheer squad worried that the PM may look good for what he's done following the tragedy - they can't stand the thought that he may actually have made a major contribution to bringing our dead home and will receive praise for it - none the least from the relatives of those tragically killed.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Goodness, you are  shit scared that the PM may look good out of this that you want all pollies banned from saying or doing anything in relation to MH17 - suck it up Longers - too late - Abbott's already been hailed around the world for his leadership over this tragedy.

text: 32 Australians dead, Foreign Minister attends a memorial service for the dead dressed appropriatly in black and all you can do is attack her for wearing a hat and make some banal comment about the Melbourne Cup.

text: Time the Labor/Greens cheer squad pull their heads in and accept that they lost the last election and no amount of baseless confected attacks on Julie Bishop will deliver you back into government - in fact the opposite.

text: The Labor/Greens cheers squad can't stand to see Tony Abbott get any credit for his leadership and achievements in bringing home our dead Australians. It worries them that he may just be successful.

text: Suggest you go back, read it again, perhaps two or three times and then come back with something that resembles fact and then maybe your credibility stakes will improve. IMHO.

text: You are on a loser trying to condemn the PM for doing what we expect our PM, Labor or Liberal, to be doing - your greatest fear is that he will receive recognition for it - which he has.

text: According to some elements of the Labor/Greens cheer squad,  disaster, war, famine, plague, earthquake or flood anywhere in the world is Tony Abbott's fault - none of them would occur if a  government was in power.

text: You guys need to get out more instead of living in your own squalid world of left-wing delusion - take a look at the latest ABC fact checker on pre-election promises delivered by the government so far - impressive list.

text: If you think Christmas Island has the infrastructure to handle the sheer numbers of people who would attempt the journey by sea then you are mistaken....I reckon conservatively half a million people would attempt the journey over the next 2 or 3 years if they believed Australia was taking in all people who could safely make it to our territorial waters. All the current detention centers on the mainland would need to be opened and new ones built.
author: TimOfAltona

text: I understand your sentiment - however, how will we deal with hundreds of thousands who would seek to make this journey if they believed Australia will take in all comers who wish to claim refugee/asylum status?
author: TimOfAltona

text: How many processing/detention centers would need to be built on top of the existing ones. 5, 10, 50, 100? Where do all the people go when they are released into the community - there is a shortage of public housing now - remember most of these people have no way to support themselves so will rely on taxpayer funded programs government welfare and charities to survive. You only have to look at some European cities to see the effects of open borders - migrant ghettos springing up because the state has no way of providing for the sheer numbers of people flooding into the cities.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Where are the jobs? There is already an undersupply of jobs for Australians let alone migrants - will these people be consigned to a life on government welfare with no housing to accommodate them?
author: TimOfAltona

text: How many thousands of families will perish at sea trying to reach Australia - we have already seen what can happen when the Rudd government gave the green light for boat arrivals in 2007.
author: TimOfAltona

text: ....but there are millions of people in this region who would want to be taken in if they can reach Australia by boat - how many can you accommodate before you say this is too much?
author: TimOfAltona

text: Bottom line is Australia's best hope for providing for a safe and humane asylum seeker program is for a  migration program that can cope with the numbers and ensure the safeguards are in place to allow people to successfully assimilate into the community and start a new life for them and their families.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Placing our refugee program into the hands of the people smugglers is not good policy, has been tried before by the Rudd Labor government and failed in so many ways and disadvantages those who genuinely apply to come to australia through the UNHCR front door program.
author: TimOfAltona

text: The Labor/Greens cheer squad can't stand the government's win at stopping the people smugglers and saving hundreds if not a thousand plus lives along the way, so they resort to personal abuse directed at those who celebrate the government's success.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Good to see the government is not wavering on it's policy - this is the only way people smugglers will be shut down - they no longer have a product to sell.
author: TimOfAltona

text: Prisons are places where people are held either following  or have been charged with a crime and are held if it is deemed they are a danger to other people, themselves or are a flight risk.
author: TimOfAltona

text: You are correct Jim, western military intervention is not a long term solution - it is a band aid - but if it means in the short term saving perhaps tens or hundreds of thousands of people from a horrific death at the hands of IS it is definitely worth going for.

text: I hear your point, but I doubt IS fighters have much interest on who is the PM or which political party is in power in Australia while they go about their jihad - this same situation could have easily arisen when Labor were in government and Labor would be grappling with the same conundrum.

text: Labor supporters can argue amongst themselves all they like over whether it was Rudd or Gillard who brought the party to it's knees in the lower house last September , but the 3 key issues still exist that will keep them out of government for the next two terms at least, namely -

text: 1. Leadership dysfunction and factional infighting. The ALP go to great lengths to keep a lid on these two corrosive ALP attributes, but they are always just below the surface bubbling away. Disunity is death.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 2. The stigma of being viewed as nothing more than an extension of the powerful unions, some militant (Gillard was tainted by this). I get that Labor are the political arm of the union movement and all that but you only have to look at the makeup of the Labor senate and you pretty quickly see where all the old union hacks end up. Parachuting into the senate is a favourite pass time for ex-union officials looking for reward for their union stewardship.
author: TimOfAltona

text: 3. The ALP's reliance on the Greens to both get them into government and then staying in government. You only have to look at what happened across the Tasman last Saturday to see what mainstream voters think of Labor/Greens governments - Australia is no different. Everyone can see that the Greens having helped the ALP then hold them hostage to Greens policies (again - Gillard and the Carbon Tax) and we really don't want to go down that path again.

text: Marr, I remember the dismissal. It was a shambolic government on an idealistic spending spree. Government debt was unheard of in those days. Whitlam wanted to borrow the equivalent of 1 trillion dollars. Most hard working Australians were very worried where all this was heading. For most Australians the dismissal did not come quick enough. The landslide election showed what they thought.

text: Jeez! If you are working hard and obeying the law, no one is interested in your metadata anyway. Don't be paranoid. Just get out there and do the right thing.

text: I come from a long line of hard working Aussies. This judeo rubbish is just some academics trying to put labels on our heritage as a way of discrediting it. Trying to make us think other people's cultural heritage is better than ours. To diminish pride in Australia.

text: My kids hate art. They are crap at it. They will never do anything with. It's time better spent improving their reading and spelling, but because of political correctness and some out of touch academic, they have to do art year after year.
author: Moon007

text: Some of the nonsense my kids have to do that they will never use. No point teaching kids art year after bloody year when they have no ability. It is just a waste of time when they could be learning something useful. Something they can use in life.

text: Well Gillard and Swan kept lying that this budget would be a surplus. For 5 years they kept doing it. They had no intention of delivering a surplus, it is just what the electorate wanted to hear (not the rusted on left but the middle Australia that decides the elections).

text: It has now been spelt out that even under Whitlam the economy was not in as bad shape as most thought, including me. At this time there was a big oil crisis - UK and USA went into recession but Australia did not. Many problems and successes with the Australian economy are dependent on what happens in the wider world. Neither party has much control. Our manufacturing failed recently (cars) but this was mainly due to a sustained mining boom and the consequent rise in the dollar (which floats unlike China's currency). China pays low wages, very low interest rates on bank deposits and control the exchange rates. They do control their economy but their day of reckoning will come even thought they have achieve great things in the last 30 years.
author: Moon007

text: I think it is about time the ABC had a fund raiser to supplement the government grants. Then people can put money where their mouth is and fund to the level they want.

text: Mate, of course, scientists are paid to say there is massive warming. If they find there isn't massive warming, only moderate warming, half would be out of a job. I have never found a car salesman that doesn't think I desperately need a new car. Scientists are human too.

text: I presume you don't get X-rays, cat scans, fly jet airliners, and will refuse radiotherapy and nuclear therapy if you get cancer, because all of these are more radiation than a nuclear reactor in your back yard.

text: I have worked hard and done it tough. Much tougher than any public servant with paid overtime, RDOs and so much holiday leave they don't know what to do with it other than retire at 54.

Australian should make Australian laws, not some rabble of countries making up the UN, and most of those countries are not targets for economic migrants, so they don't understand.

text: And the more kids in a family the less likely they are to go to a private school. Therefore much more than a third of families with school age kids go to private schools, plus they are concentrated in some electorates more than others.

text: The government gets out of its obligation to provide an education by paying to a private school a fraction of what it would cost the government to provide the education.

text: The governments collectively give far less to private schools than public schools. Private schools save the government money. Any reduction in funding will see a move of people to government schools and costing the government more.

text: But the biggest sham in this argument is that all the extra money the author talks about is the parents money, and they money funds a lot of extra curricular activities such as rowing. That the activities are done through the school, the money appears as the schools money. To conflate that with the cost of providing the basic education is simply a sham, and obviously a Greens voter.

text: So keep your hands off the parents money, and as for the grants, well private school parents pay tax too, and they are not all wealthy, many are on middle incomes, and are swinging voters particularly if you start threatening their kids education.

text: And if the grants were stopped, substantial numbers would transfer from the private system to the public system, and it would cost the public system a lot more than $3.3b.

Problem being the corruption in the country is rife. Judges, police and politicians are routinely accused of being on the take.

text: To the nutters who try to draw comparisons between an offshore detention centre and painfully being executed by 3 bullets through the chest, why don't you ask Chan and Sukumaran if the would prefer to be executed or sent to Manus Island. In the meantime, keep your inane comments to yourself.

text: This has nothing to do with detention centres you are misguided. There is no comparison between the comparative comfort of a detention centre and slowly and painfully bleeding to death in agonising pain for 7 minutes though this barbaric torture!!

Combined with over 200 of its own citizens that Indonesia has gotten off death row in other countries, it is difficult to conclude other than Indonesia is racist and puts a high value on its own citizens lives an no value on foreigners lives.

text: There is an epidemic of callousness sweeping many people in Australia. From bashings where groups 'swarm' and repeatedly kick an unconscious victim, believing Australia should butt out and let ISIS continue to behead people, to no concern about the executions of these two.

text: Rubbish. People always had to start out buying a house on the city fringe. It is the same today except the 20 something's expect to buy an inner city house instead. You buy on the fring, and later you upgrade to a second or third house.

text: In period 1 co2 emissions were low and atmospheric co2 concentration was increasing slowly. In period 2 the co2 emissions are massive, and the atmospheric co2 concentration is increasing strongly. Just as you would expect.
author: Moon007

text: But the rate of temperature increase and rate of sea level rise is about the same in period 1 and period 2. If co2 was causing temperature increase and sea level rise, then the increases in period 2 should be much more than in period 1, but the increases are about the same. So co2 is not causing the temperature increase and the sea level rise.
author: Moon007

text: That is why only 1 of the last 6 executed was an Indonesian, and only 1 of the next 11 to be executed is an Indonesian.and that is why Indonesia asks clemency for Indonesians on death row for drugs in other countries, but won't grant it to foreigners in its own country.

text: This would match the crime, because no one is held down and a needle put in their arm, they do it by free will and even pay for the privilege.

text: It is standard Indonesia behaviour because of all the controversy. They will wait, appear that something is happening but don't say what, let you jump to conclusions that something good is afoot, and then when the controversy settles down and the journalists go home, they will have a quick execution.

text: The war on drugs is one sided. There are insufficient penalties for buying and using drugs. Only supply is heavily punished, hence the demand increases, and with constrained supply the price goes up and encourages people to enter the supply business for high rewards.

text: The charter is to house and provide for anyone you can't prove is not a refugee. So if you arrive, no papers, a BS name, a BS story, that can't be disproved, then in you come. Effectively that is open borders, and you have to let them in whether they are criminal, a terrorist, a hate preacher, or an infectious diseases risk. You don't decide who you let in. That is open borders.

text: Yes the times have changed. People are saying they don't want to live in their 3rd world country anymore, so they are packing their bags en-mass and heading for western countries that have good welfare systems.

text: With climate change events organised for Bonn and Paris this year, can we expect the routine socialist protests to be a little more organised than the amateurs in Brisbane ?

text: Not quite sure what Murdoch has to do with it. Or is that the only way you're able to cope with other view points - blame them on Murdoch ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Maybe our socialists simply aren't as resourceful and skilful as foreign socialists. Those Greek ones seem amongst the best around - even looks like they've almost achieved the economic end of their nation. What a victory that would be. Wait on ....
author: TheJediMaster

text: This reminds me a bit of the time a bunch of hapless young socialist students infiltrated a Q&A episode and unfurled their protest banner - upside down ! It's pretty hard to recover from there.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Seems more evidence based. The G20 predominantly has an economic focus. Climate change might be the only issue that matters to some people, the rest of us live in a rather more pragmatic world where many issues can be discussed concurrently.
author: TheJediMaster

text: A more likely reason was that it was a silly idea in the first place - they couldn't get anyone but the most committed of occupying lefties to turn up. Losers.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yes it has potential, which is good, but it's a storage device. Something will have to be the power source - solar or wind in some cases, but coal in many others.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Given that something like 25% of CO2 ever emitted has been done in the past 20 years, yet the changes in surface temperature over that time is next to zero, surely climate sensitivity is very much a young theory that needs much more work.
author: TheJediMaster

text: So why would we go spending tens of billions to address global warming when we have no idea what the real impact of CO2 emissions will be ? Take some cautious measures to minimise risk certainly, but dramatic action is far from justified.
author: TheJediMaster

text: I'd prefer to help people genuinely trying to juggle work and family, and helping grow the pie in the process, than others who expect the government to support them from cradle to grave.
author: TheJediMaster

text: So how is it that people become wealthy ? Is it purely luck, or do you think that working hard, working smart and taking a risk might have anything to do with it ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: 20% higher than AWE is hardly rich. Although they pay a large amount in income tax to cover all those Australians who think the government should be their primary source of income.
author: TheJediMaster

text: As for Sydney-centric conspiracy theories well there doesn't seem much basis for that. Abbott's living in the AFP College - a rather humble abode for a Prime Minister - while the Lodge is being redone.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Sure - each IPCC assessment report shows a reduced expected temperature increase. It started around 3 degrees and is now down below 1.5 degrees. They specifically stated there'd be a 1 degree rise by 2025, where the reality seems to be rather different.
author: TheJediMaster

text: So it's very fair to say that the original scenarios overstated the issues. But that's never stopped the CC zealots from trying to sell the rest of us their silly doomsday prophecies. 'The greatest moral challenge of our time" hey.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Frankly i broadly agree with Lomborg - climate change is an issue but its impact is being overstated significantly by those with the most to gain. And the science supports that - record high ice sheet levels, 18 year flat lining temperatures, plunging sensitivity predictions.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Had a quick look at your link. Couldn't see anywhere it suggested CO2 was bad. Significant warming linked to CO2 (as a greenhouse gas) may be bad, but is CO2 itself bad ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: We're a bit past that point aren't we ? Even the supposedly climate denying Abbott government is formulating policy for post 2020, they're trying to determine the strategy for Paris in December, there's a RET and Direct Action.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Are you saying that academic qualifications are the only thing that counts towards having expertise in a field ? Because many academics have rather limited real world experience, but are great in theory.
author: TheJediMaster

text: You're probably right. And climate science seems to ignore much evidence too like record ice sheets and flat lining temperatures, so we could probably get a politician to act as chief climate change scientist. Or we could get a railway engineer.
author: TheJediMaster

text: A few people think that climate change should be the only issue confronting health, transport, education, tiddlywinks and the production of widgets blah blah, but most of us are more sensible.
author: TheJediMaster

text: We've just given a bunch of money to some UN fund that Obama loves - they can handle to allocation of funds to third world countries. I hope our foreign aid goes on real projects like building schools, hospitals, housing etc.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Anyone linking the appointment of Lomborg to this UWA body and our climate change policies has failed to read past the headlines. Thinking outside the square only works for people who've realised there's a square. Clearly many haven't.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Don't you ever do your own research ? That research was in part based on current IEA stats. Why don't you go to the IEA website and tell us the share of solar and wind today to global energy supply.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Do you know the number ? Give you a hint, it fits on one hand. Actually one finger. How are you planning to increase it 100 times in 25 years by 2040 ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: The Australian Consensus Centre is designed to take a methodology of cost-benefit analysis to look at a whole range of Australian and global development challenges over the next 15 number of years to try and to work out where as a society we will get the best value for every dollar we invest.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Is it possible the reason that so many lefties are carrying on about the Lomborg appointment is because of the successful direct action / ERF auctions announced during the week ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: They've done everything they can to stop thoughts and ideas being shared. Even in the interests of then tearing those ideas down with their own brand of "progressive" logic. Pardon the pun again.
author: TheJediMaster

text: If the lecturers and students can't distinguish between the issue of climate change and foreign aid, then there's isn't much hope for either group. Perhaps they need a better education.
author: TheJediMaster

text: UWA has become a laughing stock. Laugh at the lecturers, who don't like ideas they don't understand. Laugh at the students, for whom education seems to be about learning nothing. And laugh at the VC, who crumbled under the pressure of the CC zealots.
author: TheJediMaster

text: You have to remember Marg, that the rich subsidise the poor to the tune of tens of billions annually. I was asking GMCB how he claimed the needy are being shafted - when the beneficiaries of this policy are the needy !
author: TheJediMaster

text: Level of disagreement you reckon - well then Lomborg deserves a citation or two. Perhaps you could provide examples where citations are sought for dissenting views, lol. Sounds like you can order them online anyway.
author: TheJediMaster

text: And that's the point - Lomborg is there to form views on foreign aid. Yet his views on climate change - perfectly normal views - got all these lazy lecturers all excited.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Good result for Australia. Certainty for the industry, a win for the environment and a victory for both sides of parliament working together. There is hope yet for better government.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But if true, Griggs should not be in charge of a troop of cub scouts, let alone a Human Rights Commission. To be the judge of other people you should have pretty solid credentials yourself.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Triggs seems to spend her life preaching at others about how to behave. If these claims about the child are true, it means Triggs should not be making value judgements about any other human being, let alone prescribing policy a whole nation.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Boats have to stop. But have we thought about what the consequences are of pushing people back to our neighbour Indonesia? Triggs said. Is it any wonder that Indonesia will not engage with us on other issues that we care about, like the death penalty?
author: TheJediMaster

text: I'm not sure which planet Triggs was corresponding from, but from today's media reports it appears she's back with us here on planet Earth. Wonder what her next ridiculous stunt will be, and when the resignation may come.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Not too good on evidence is the hapless Triggs. She reckons there's some sort of link between capital punishment in Indonesia and Australia's boat policy. How's that one work again Gillian ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: With the climate change battle being lost due to missing evidence, looks like environmental campaigners are now targeting our Barrier Reef for special treatment in the battle to drive climate change fear into all of us.
author: TheJediMaster

text: As for the NBN - well what a shining beacon of all that was wrong with RuddGillardRudd - no business case, back of the envelope planning, nationalisation of a market, a financial mess, secretive, years behind schedule and a market that the private sector was building anyway. Hair brained stupidity. And then of course, Conroy.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Sadly incoming Coalition governments always seem to have the same starting point - fix the Labor mess, stop the bleeding. Took Costello nine years to pay off the Keating debt. This one is far, far worse.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Oh yes thanks for the reminder, all that legislation hey. Not sure when more red tape became the benchmark of success, but Abbott has at least been able to get rid of the worst of it - carbon tax, mining tax.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Rather easily - besides the ABC promise, the Senate has effectively meant he hasn't broken any other promises, although i'm sure we can argue the toss on a couple of issues.
author: TheJediMaster

text: And whatever promises Abbott has broken, nothing can or will match the extent of the carbon tax lie. And Bill wants to bring back an ETS. He's Tone's best friend.
author: TheJediMaster

text: As we saw in the UK last week, the polls aren't all that flash at predictions, and Labour governments are quite rightly on the nose around the world. Two term Tone is likely.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Sounds just like last year when the ABC were convinced they were onto the "burnt hands" story. How odd that the asylum seekers told a very different story to that of the Navy Officers directly involved.
author: TheJediMaster

text: We'll never know of course, but if we had, there'd be no $350 billion debt, no massive deficits, no budget crisis and there never would have been a carbon tax.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Another question then - being able to negative gear allows for more owners and more properties being listed for rental. So how does that "contribute far more to the housing problem" ? Seems like a logic meltdown.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The whole episode this week has been quite revealing. In the last three months the polls have turned around for Abbott and the government. The budget has gone down well, Bill's personal numbers have tanked and he's well and truly on the back foot.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Then along comes the Union Royal Commission, and a bit of mud starts to stick to Shorten. It was always going to happen you'd reckon. But whack - all of a sudden there's some serious questions for the Labor leader to answer himself.
author: TheJediMaster

text: So how do Labor react ? Accuse the government of a smear campaign. Hilarious. Bill's been dishing it out for 18 months, then turns to jelly when he gets a bit of the spotlight
author: TheJediMaster

text: Clearly unfit for the highest office, there's now going to be some serious questions within the ALP, about who should lead them to the 2016 election. The answer may well be ABB - "anyone but Bill".
author: TheJediMaster

text: Agreed Tim - much as we'd love to see the Labor leader fall, the next question would be who next .... Chris, Tony, Tanya, Albo. They're all dreary prospects, but surely none of them would be as wooden and empty as Shorten.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Stolen $80m hey. Would you prefer the unions continuing on their merry way of driving up construction costs which contribute to housing affordability problems ? Or might it be an idea to clean them up.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's a real shame Bill didn't sign up for an interview or two on The Killing Season. He could have provided some great inside commentary on who stabbed who, why, and who was cheering at the time.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Come to think of it, he could have saved the taxpayers a heap of money too. If he'd truthfully told all on TV about the union and about the RGR years, we probably could have avoided TURC in the first place. Oh well.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Perhaps you should check out this article - it's about a bloke who spends his life criticising others and demanding all sorts of things - who, when the shoe is now on the other foot, complains like a spoilt child.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's possible it's the beginning of the end for him, although i'd prefer him to stay a Labor leader through to the 2016 election. Bill's the best chance of an another Abbott victory !
author: TheJediMaster

text: Bill's been carping at Tony's ankles like a little yappy terrier for months now. Yap yap yap. And the second he cops a bit back - entirely of his own doing - he screams "smear".
author: TheJediMaster

text: Slight difference between a North Shore Sydney seat and a rural Victorian one, but again it's nice you've got some hope. Not sure if the bookies would back Dick Smith too much.
author: TheJediMaster

text: You'd expect the Abbott haters to lap this idea of Dick Smith's up. A review of the Warringah electoral history might be a little more sobering - it's been with the Liberal Party since World War 2.
author: TheJediMaster

text: They seem fine to have taxpayers artificially fund billions of taxpayers money on renewable energy, yet have a problem with investors who then rent houses to those who can't afford to buy. How confusing.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Tell you what - why don't you go and read the transcript then tell us which of the three versions of the ALP meetings that Triggs put on the record was the accurate one. She did, she didn't she might have ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Triggs problem is that she takes some of the worst offenders - people who have seriously breached the human rights of others - and tries to turn them into victims.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Okay Barry so you're fully supporting the Triggs argument here. You've ignored that the Indonesians also appeal to other countries who have Indons on death row. Perhaps we can agree that the Indonesian position on the DP is conflicted at best.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Agree with your first paragraph Tom - it's complicated. On the priest - yes they should lose some rights, perhaps though not as many as the murderer. They do lose some rights when society throws them in jail.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Sure we've all made mistakes. But most of us have never made the mistakes that Basikbasik has. By taking a life, he's forfeited his rights. There's rules we have to abide by to have a decent society like we have. Child murderers should not have the rights to join our society.
author: TheJediMaster

text: May i ask you a serious question though. Imho a person who has taken another's life - as Basikbasik has done - has forfeited their right to be treated as any sort of equal. There cannot be any greater human right than the right to life. Anyone breaching that has committed, essentially, the worst crime it is possible commit (in the case of court determined murder).
author: TheJediMaster

text: Many pollies make changes to Hansard. You might want to refine your search to November last year, when Triggs changed her story to a Senate Committee three times in one day, around whether she'd had discussions with Labor MP's on an issue.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Boats have to stop. But have we thought about what the consequences are of pushing people back to our neighbour Indonesia? Triggs said. Is it any wonder that Indonesia will not engage with us on other issues that we care about, like the death penalty?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Right now Skippy the Bush Kangaroo would do a better job managing Australia's human rights affairs. We've had these statements, the Basikbasik affair, the lies to the Senate around detention centres, the baseless comments on asylum seekers / self harm.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Oh i don't know jimbo - the boats have cost Labor plenty of skin, part of an election, a whole heap of respect, and has probably been the greatest political policy failure in recent years. Yet they still want to talk about them.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Tony Jones would have to be the rudest person on political television and his show is overrun by left wing drearies much of the time. That transgender singer and loudmouthed obnoxious Yank last Monday were terrible.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Michael - it's pretty obvious that nobody is censoring the ABC. The free speech argument is nothing to do with it - this is about a moral compass. Spectacular fail by the ABC.
author: TheJediMaster

text: C'mon Ian, low blow. Yes he's that but also seems to be a rare case of going from that depth to managing thousands of people. That's about as much defence of Plibersek as i've got.
author: TheJediMaster

text: She seems so lost at sea in the shadow Foreign Affairs role. Hopeless Health Minister, even backed the clueless "Women for Gillard" thing. She''ll never achieve her goal of PM, best to give up now maybe ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Who are the options though ? Abo and Plib are lefties, and after the shambolic Jules there won't be a leftie PM for a decade or two. Bowen ? Burke has had a horrible week too.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Ha ha. Every PM (since Menzies) has been dragged kicking and screaming from the Lodge. Most have been cut down by their own team (Gorton, Hawke, Rudd, Gillard), some by the voters (Whitlam, Fraser, Keating, Howard). Johnny was hardly any different.
author: TheJediMaster

text: * It started with fixing the Keating budget mess* GST reform, setting the budget and economy up for surpluses and fairness* 10 budget surpluses* The Future Fund* Renewable energy target* Safe borders* Gun control* Record growth and employment* Stable government* Steered Australia through the Asian Financial Crisis and tech wreck* Set us up to navigate the GFC* Strong infrastructure record* Global leadership on foreign affairs* Strong humanitarian refugee program
author: TheJediMaster

text: Regardless, agree that national security ranks well above CC as a threat. The climate's been changing for billions of years. The death cult threat is far more of a clear and present danger.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Are these the same climate scientists who refuse to give us some analysis of how and why the models are wrong, yet demand we keep pumping trillions into climate schemes ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: What's so special is that IPCC AR1 came out in 1990, with its doomsday predictions. It told us that by now we would see a rise of 0.7 degrees (C) on a straight line basis.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Connor seems quite rational unlike a few of his buddies in Steffen and Flannery. He at least brings some hope to the enviro-lobby, lest it continue to reduce in relevance.
author: TheJediMaster

text: So John Connor wants a "A civil and constructive discussion". Excellent. Let's see how much he - and the other left-leaning alliance members - wants that discussion when a few contentious issues come up such as our post-2020 targets.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Barrie clearly wasn't prepared this morning, don't expect Scott will be too impressed with him. It's almost like these ABC-types float around like they're in an episode of Alice in Wonderland.
author: TheJediMaster

text: No doubt the outrage will subside - eventually - but sad to say that the ABC haven't yet worked out what they've done wrong. Maybe some common sense training might help.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Not sure how large that group is, but yes, Abbott certainly has his detractors. Dunno why you sprout the "frequent liar" stuff. There's been a couple but nowhere near as bad as Jules carbon tax porkie.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Groupthink is a fascinating concept though. Seems to be the place where even extremist viewpoints - as long as they're counter to the government argument - deserve plenty of airtime.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The problem with the ABC of course is that because the product is so biased, many Aussies don't bother consuming. Yet they still pay for it. Does that seem fair ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: What will Bill emerge smelling like soap from - TURC, Fairfax editorals demanding a resignation, his self-confessed lies, the political isolation or his new great big newer carbon tax ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Where to start .... for starters they removed the worst government in living memory, brought sanity back to the climate change debate, restored our borders, brought back some credibility to the budget numbers and made onion eating popular.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Not sure which game you're watching. In the one I'm watching when the election is called if Labor is less than five points in front, they're gone. Once people work out that Bill wants us to have a new carbon tax.
author: TheJediMaster

text: So basically First Dog has finally worked out that Abbott and the government will probably win the 2016 election, and it means more conservative government for 3, or 6, or maybe the next 9 years.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The Opposition Leaders personal ratings are the worst in his 21 months at Labors helm, just as he faces the trade union royal commission and amid rumblings over Labors policy direction and the struggle to find him a new chief of staff.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Before we sleepwalk to Paris - who's aware that it's quite consistent and logical to accept man influenced climate change and at the same time reject any need for carbon pricing ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Hard to work out what your point is Al. It sounds like you're quite happy to claim the carbon tax reduced emissions, yet reject that it increased unemployment. There's plenty of evidence to support both propositions.
author: TheJediMaster

text: If you're trying to argue the carbon was good - well it was for emissions but it was also bad for the economy. the fall in GDP growth numbers also support the negative economic impact.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Loving reading the comments about the $550 - "where is it Mr Abbott?". If electricity prices didn't fall then there would be a zero link between the CT removal and more electricity use !
author: TheJediMaster

text: Correct - and that premise applies equally to the relationship between the carbon tax and unemployment, as well as between the carbon tax and CO2 emission reductions being reported by Pitt & Sherry !
author: TheJediMaster

text: But in the same way the link between the carbon tax and unemployment is indirect, so is the link between the CO2 figures and the repeal of the tax. The only thing that changed in both cases was input costs - wage and energy.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Not even sure why people are surprised here - the carbon tax was always going to cost jobs in export markets and because of the rise in business costs. Qantas sacked 2,500 people at the same time as announcing a $106 million carbon tax bill, and two car manufacturers went under as well.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The cause and effect premise might be a little rubbery as you point out - but no different to the Climate Councils conclusions on the Pitt & Sherry numbers. Works both ways you see.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Did you see that "analysis" Steffen published the other day ? He took numbers from a poll in which most Canberrans did not support the crazy light rail project, then excluded all Liberal voters then tried to claim that most Canberrans supported light rail. Hilarious !
author: TheJediMaster

text: Looks like a ding dong battle over the next few months within the Coalition. Problem is if they vote no, the SSM issue will keep coming back time and time again.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The Tigers continue to give we supporters a coronary a week almost. We can beat Sydney in Sydney, Fremantle in Perth, Port in Adelaide, but then drop games we should win.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yes, i suspect that your understanding of terms in that charter including "impartial" and "according to the recognized standards of objective journalism" might be a little different to most Australians. (8 1 c).
author: TheJediMaster

text: It doesn't. But throw on top of that the orchestrated campaign against the government, the refusal to provide any balance, the lack of any conservative presenters, the failure to explore issues like the hiatus and present scientific balance, and you've got a mob who fail their charter which prescribes impartiality and balance.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Sounds like Labor are still shaking their heads as to why the Australian voters removed them two years ago. Shorten's spent two days this week making a complete fool of himself in a Royal Commission, and Fitzgibbons reckons it's the Prime Minister who's out of control and is trying to censor the hapless ABC.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's completely within the role of the PM to tell the ABC they have a charter and they should adhere to it. Between whacky zaky, burnt hands, Rudd phone tapping and chaser skits, seems like Aunty is completely out of control.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yes, we've seen how Greece is the shining light of what happens when you've got a fat, lazy public service and rely on borrowings to pay pensions. But i'm sure Annastasia knows better.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The Newman government had their problems, but at least they were getting the economy back in shape and the debt and public spending down. Palaszczuk has turned that around and shock horror unemployment blows out. Closely followed by growth and debt.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Those ABS stats that the top 10% of taxpayers pay 45% of income tax, and that the bottom 50% of families pay zero net tax must be wrong then. Perhaps you should tell the bureau.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Your point 3 might need some revision. Greece spends a whopping 16% on pensions, up from 12% in 2008. No wonder you want to try using long term averages and very dodgy comparisons.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Niall the climate changes with or without man. That it's changed since industrialization some 200 years ago means little. Around 25% of the CO2 ever emitted has been in the last 25 years.
author: TheJediMaster

text: And isn't that the whole point - weather patterns change. I happily accept that mankind needs to clean up the rubbish we put into the atmosphere. But we haven't seen measurable warming for almost two decades according to some scientists. Best to tone down the alarmism.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Greece's debt has been unsustainable for years. And now we have seen a developed nation doing the unthinkable and defaulting on it's debt. Which also means it won't be trusted for years. It can't issue bonds, it can no longer raise funds.
author: TheJediMaster

text: How the Greek people voted for such stupidity in terms of a government is beyond me. The "No" vote last week confirmed that the Europeans simply need to jettison them, lest they drag the rest.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Oh yes. The debt is coming from greed. Lazy greed. Greedy people expecting that the world owes them a favour, and they shouldn't have to lift a finger to help themselves.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Actually NATSEM did the modelling, and you're correct that it didn't include GST, but wrong in claiming 10% of salary would be spent on GST. As for super, it's funded by ourselves, nobody else works for it.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Wel Sophia "Tony's going to destroy renewables" might get a cheer at the conference but a little honesty might be better. Howard introduced the RET and the Coalition support it.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Seems to be mainly lefties that are angry, the old faux outrage waving their very inconsistent and selecive moral compasses. We can probably expect a few more days of it though.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's definitely not a good look for Bishop, not sure what she was thinking. But Labor are running a high risk strategy in chasing Bronnie. They've hardly kept a squeaky clean record themselves.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Oddly Labor and Shorten didn't call for scalps when Speaker Anna Burke had the government pay for her kids European vacation. When she was busted some time later, she repaid the money too.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Gillard on the other hand was divisive and a wrecker. Pick your issue - economics, IR, boats, education, socialist agenda, carbon tax. Nothing to do with gender and everything to do with competence. And she hid behind her gender, used it to attack critics. Pathetic stuff.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Sounds exactly like what Gillard said about the carbon tax. Joel's being a bit generous to Abbott though - it's pretty easy to distinguish the difference between an ETS and the crazy carbon tax.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Labor may with to have a quick check what's happening in Europe with the Germans and English reducing subsidies on renewables. The costs have closed down business and have industry threatening to head offshore. The cost impacts have been huge.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The climate change debate seems to have changed in the last year. Current government policy is a 20% 2020 ERT, a 20% 2020 RET, Direct Action, CEFC, ARENA. It's a pretty good track record.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Well besides a bit of bickering on boats, it's been a pretty dull affair. Maybe the protesters brightened it up a bit - maybe it was staged - but broadly it's just been Labor talking about Labor again.
author: TheJediMaster

text: We all know of course that it's just smoke and mirrors - even though Labor say they'll turn back, they never will. As we learnt from Gillard, if you don't believe it, lie about it.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Hopefully we all might be surprised on the government's towards 2030 plan. They would be smart to put a few strong measures in place like a 25-30% 2030 ERT. The RET at 24% is about right.
author: TheJediMaster

text: How dare the government suggest that wind power should pay its own expenses. Wind energy has been taking from the public purse for so long, it knows no way to deliver a profit. It should resign as Speaker for renewables.
author: TheJediMaster

text: So why do the bookies have the Coalition at $1.52 to retain power ? Wait til Bill starts really promoting his twin taxes - the ETS and RET changes, polls will fall.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Bronniegate has reminded us all of the way Slipper and Thomson were treated like protected species, innocent before proven guilty etc etc. Interesting that different standards seem to apply today.
author: TheJediMaster

text: I doubt it's the tip of the surface. The big gun was rolled out first - the chopper. Followed by the weddings, and lastly low hanging fruit like a plane ride from Sydney to Nowra.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It seems like this whole saga is becoming a stalemate. Bishop gets accused of something, digs in, a few days later agrees to repay. The next day either Fairfax or the Guardian discovers a new scandal, and it starts all over again. Today's is the Nowra flight.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The ship should be dead in the water, but unfortunately it's not. Brave move here by Abbott. He's also going to have to stand up and defend Bishop. Crazy brave perhaps.
author: TheJediMaster

text: We might have nuclear power and be 8% muslim in other words. Mind you the French are so bad at colonisation, you'd reckon we might be predominantly Japanese or Chinese by now. Wonder how they'd treat the Aborigines.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The DT also reported the Labor commissioned modelling found our standard of living would fall 6%, carbon pricing would trigger a recession and energy prices would rise 78%. Tens of thousands of jobs would go.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Well I'm not sure that every day has been one of good government, there's been a shocker or two. But it's been nice Jules G to pop up from time to time, to remind us all again what truly bad government looked like.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's also interesting that there's been zero 2PP impact of Bronniegate. Perhaps any negative impact was countered by Labor announcing more climate change own goals in the ETS and the pie-in-the-sky 50% RET.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Interesting that Abbott would take the moral high ground when it came to Burke. What a shame Burke clearly has a very different concept of that moral high ground. Helicopters bad, kids in Business Class good off to Ayers Rock good. Oh dear.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The once great LauraTingle hey. Given that the Prime Minister has spent the last week in the Torres Strait and the NPA, how do you figure that he'd be aware of an operation like this ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: History must be wrong then. It says Gillard was removed by her own party on 27 June 2013. Some hero, like Latham - who btw was rejected rather famously during the 2010 campaign.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Slashing the RET ? At 24% we have one of the strongest renewable energy targets on the planet. Seems like the truth hurts for some, far better to tell porkies.
author: TheJediMaster

text: And the fact remains Labor butchered the budget and has been too embarrassed to support any fixes to it. It's the main reason they won't see power for some time yet.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Oh I've provided plenty of opinion. Mine stayed away from the gutter though. Recommend you take Gillard's advice and have a good look in a mirror, some really disturbing comments.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Tim - do you remember how Australia was transfixed to the AWW with the knitting Jules story ? Half of women for Gillard went out in sympathy didn't they - Pen, Tannya, Kate, Jen Nicola and the gang.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Labor don't have a post 2020 ERT. But they do have a RET target. Treasury modelled the cost of the RET, just like the CCA asked them. Hope that helped.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Nobody seems to be able to refute the $600 billion that the Treasury modelling estimated. It's all very well to disagree with them but you'd want to have a pretty good case.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The polls will always tighten approaching an election. But once we get over these Labor distractions like today with Justice Heydon, the MUA strike and anything to deflect from policy debate, we might be able to start discussing reform.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The Treasury numbers confirmed that the $550 has been delivered - half in direct power costs and half in flow on costs. In my town the power cost reduction was $269 apparently.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Bob - you're very good at shouting, hope it helps. By the way if the polls are so damning, why do the bookies have Abbott as favourite to retain government ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: On CC, we've now got a credible and serious 2030 target, one that sits comfortably with many industrialised nations and puts the efforts of the world's biggest emitter in China to shame.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Abbott doesn't have a single conflict of interest, which is in stark contrast to O'Connor. But he and Bill have made their beds, and now they have to lie in them.
author: TheJediMaster

text: ChAFTA will not allow unrestricted access to the Australian labour market by Chinese workers. It will not allow Australian employment laws or conditions to be undermined, nor allow companies to avoid paying Australian wages by using foreign workers.
author: TheJediMaster

text: And yee shall not be judged harshly for it. It's a bit like being invited to deliver the Sir Garfield Barwick address, not even considering it was supported by the legal branch of the Liberals wouldn't you say ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: 67 pages they have no answer for. So Bill's picked up his bat and ball and wants the GG to intervene. Now that's laughable, if it wasn't so pathetic. And politically really stupid.
author: TheJediMaster

text: If i was Labor and the unions, i'd be thinking about cleaning up my act. Shorten has spent the day attacking Dutton for attacking the umpire, yet he's clearly not smart enough to realise the attacks on Dyson Heydon, a distinguished Australian, are no different.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Must be a few lefties with egg on their face after spending half a day trying to pin this on the government. Daniel Andrews Victoria Police might be a better place to start the blame game.
author: TheJediMaster

text: If you'd like a realistic Abbott character assessment, i recommend you read Simon Benson's article today. He's had the additional benefit of getting to know Abbott personally, putting him well ahead of the likes of DM.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Funny watching lefties like Marr try to psychoanalyse someone like Tony Abbott. Describing a bloke who has made it to the top office in the land as a "unique failure" doesn't suggest a level of analysis in tune with too much reality.
author: TheJediMaster

text: No, we know that because Josh Frydenberg has been the champion of red tape removal for two years. But it sounds like you're accepting that bad legislation gets passed, hence the reason for its repeal.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Abbott did put forward some bad bills, but also some sensible budget repair ones that were rejected regularly. Just because a bill is defeated it doesn't mean it wasn't sensible and responsible.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Also, the notion that volume of legislation is some measure of a good government is a bit silly. For example, those 10 carbon tax bills that Gillard had passed were nothing but an economic noose around the nation's neck.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Didn't know they could move much more left, but i suppose they could amalgamate with the Greens and well known commo Rhiannon could run the troupe .... into oblivion, and beyond !
author: TheJediMaster

text: Turns out that the Bureau of Meteorology has been monitoring the south Pacific for 23 years. And of the 12 locations they've monitored, how many have measured sea level rises ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Oh dear Kouk - if you choose to mention "the pre election fiscal outlook prepared prior to the 2013 election and based on the policy settings of the previous Labor government" as a basis for analysis, you should mention that Swan got every budget forecast wrong to the tune of over $106 billion in just four years.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Sure we need to manage our resources, but once developments like Carmichael have gone through state approval, federal approval, with all the research, analysis and environmental conditions that go with projects like it, seems really counter-productive to allow a bunch of bongovan-driving hippies from challenging it. Crazy stuff.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Australia did that in the 1960's, 1970's, 1980's, 1990's and 2000's. Look where it got us - being one of the top few producers of commodities in the world. And look how the jobs flowed as a result - unemployment of 4%.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Some of these rent-an-ambulance-chaser environmental outfits should be treated with the contempt they treat their fellow countrymen with. Unless they have some strong association with the issue at hand (e.g. live in the Galilee Basin), they shouldn't have any legal rights to halt development, once all the approvals have been gained.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But let's hope that the Coalition now run the show for the next ten years. Labor will need to find a messiah, and there's no obvious one in parliament right now.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Debt has to be paid. Right now the interest on our debt is $1 billion per month. That's one hospital, five schools or 6 F-35 Raptors per month on the interest alone.
author: TheJediMaster

text: So what Daisy. Do you really want to debate whether Abbott served as PM for two years, or a couple of days more or less ? Pathetic if you do.
author: TheJediMaster

text: He rid us of the worst elements of RGR - taxes, porous borders, finalised three FTA's, provided strong leadership of the UN Security Council. He forged a good relationship with India, is resettling 12,000 war weary refugees and provided a pathway for the introduction of SSM.
author: TheJediMaster
