text: Err the debt is issued as Treasury bonds. They're held by institutions and householders. Bonds are issued when the government has run out of money, which happens when you lose control of spending.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Abbott won't go down as our best Prime Minister, but nor will he be remembered as our worst. His heart was in the right place, but the own goal count was almost as bad as the Gillard government's.
author: TheJediMaster

text: True, that was the ETS plan. Funny thing in it all is if the Greens had supported the Rudd CPRS, we would have had an ETS for five years now.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The AWW gong came because of the power Abbott vested in Credlin. It was also his undoing because politically Credlin rubbed power hungry people the wrong way. She also seemed to reduce consensus by taking too much ownership of decisions.
author: TheJediMaster

text: * delivered the four highest ever Australian deficits* delivered the highest nominal debt on Australian fiscal history* missed every budget forecast by over $106 billion over 5 years (of half a billion bucks per week)* left the country penniless after the mining boom.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Of course spending is the problem. Swan gave us the greatest spending explosion in Australian fiscal history and we haven't even started paying off the debt. Malcolm and Scott's challenge is to start reigning in the deficits without upsetting the highly sensitive Senate independents. Joe's last budget didn't help matters much either. As for Labor and the Greens, well fiscal ignorance is bliss.
author: TheJediMaster

text: So you reckon a project that will help boost the living standards of millions of Indians won't get funding. I'd love to have this discussion again the day the first coal is dug out.
author: TheJediMaster

text: A medium term analysis 10 months old is out of date ? Don't think so. It's more current than IPCC AR5, and some people seem to think that's still relevant.
author: TheJediMaster

text: All about image ? It's all about deflecting from the LOTO's behaviour as a union leader. Common sense says you're gone Bill. But as a Liberal supporter i'm desperate that you stay until the next election.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Good post. Astonishing how the models keep predicting doom and gloom (just around the corner of course), yet the actual observations - ice, temperature and so on, don't support the models.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Ronald - well it's a good thing that we have coal providing our power needs at the moment. In fact in the 15 or so years it would take to get nuclear off the ground, we'd start seeing the decommissioning of some coal power stations - great timing.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Finkel's nuclear views are a breath of fresh air too. He seems to get that renewables, with their 6% current market share, will not be able to replace fossil fuels for decades to come.
author: TheJediMaster

text: And Bill better not say i never do nufing for him. Before he embarrasses himself in Kiribati, he might want to check out their sea levels for the past 23 years - they've gone down !
author: TheJediMaster

text: But surely you agree it's a bit hard to paint such a poor growth outcome over a quarter of a century as any sort of achievement. Let's face it - carbon taxes are economy wreckers.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Good to see Turnbull taking a pragmatic approach to climate change issues. The fear when he took office was a shift to the left - good thing the Nats locked him in.
author: TheJediMaster

text: He's not there for news, he's there to gather info. A far cry from the spin of the likes of Triggs. How on earth does she claim to represent human rights ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: If we want some objective reporting and feedback and a good outcome for Abyan, then good choice to let Chris Kenny provide it. He bring integrity and a non-partisan viewpoint (pardon the pun).
author: TheJediMaster

text: Wonder if Penny wants to recount the tales floating around after Gillard was booted out. There was a rather large bash at the Lodge we're told, with rather a large expense to the taxpayer.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Daisy - if your claim that she didn't have access to medical treatment or legal help is true then I agree that would be appalling. But something doesn't sound right about it. Why do you think that ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Do these clowns even have any way of trying to prove their theory correct, or do they just throw numbers out there like the bingo caller at the local country club ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Someone should mention to Lenore that we have a 28% ERT, a 24% RET and direct action. Good things come in threes. It's more than adequate - don't want Antarctica putting on too much ice, sea levels may fall.
author: TheJediMaster

text: As a kid i stood on the steps of the Old Parliament House on 11 November 1975 whilst Gough was delivering his tirade against the Governor General. Almost 40 years later, there's still plenty of contention and commentary about the dismissal.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Removing Prime Ministers these days seems a far less complex exercise. A few bad Newspolls and splut, off you go. If governments were removed for fiscal mismanagement like Whitlam was, Rudd wouldn't have lasted more than two years, and Australia wouldn't be $400 billion in the hock.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Deficits are investments - that's got to be one of the funnier lines i've read in these pages. Is the interest bill also an "investment" ? How do we decide whether it's been a good investment, or don't we bother ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: No one doubts Whitlam's brilliance and foresight. But turning this into practical outcomes proved more difficult. Within a couple of short years spending had exploded to an unsustainable level. (which has a familiar ring to it)
author: TheJediMaster

text: Whitlam was a larger than life character, and led Labor out of a 23 year wilderness. But he wasn't quite across many important issues, especially economics and budgets, and ended up as yet another failed Labor leader.
author: TheJediMaster

text: 1. Sea level rises are in the mm's (and some islands like Kiribati have observed sea level falls over 25 years), so not sure how they are vacating "drowning" land.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Another angry muppet. The article is about Bill - enjoy it, after next year we won't be hearing too much about him. In fact we'll be hearing about coal for many more years than we'll hear about Bill. Hopefully about nuclear energy too.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Really strong week by Turnbull. Managed to placate the coal, renewable and nuclear industries, started getting a vertically-integrated nuke industry off the ground, committed to Paris. Even sounded like Tone there for a bit - "coal is good".
author: TheJediMaster

text: Well good luck to him if he does. Religions of all persuasions seem pretty misguided these days. If Pocock is a religious nutter, well i guess that explains a bit.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Agree that Abbott's biggie failure was the inability to fix the deficit. He had to deal with an opposition in fiscal denial and a public unwilling to sacrifice anything themselves. But it was Abbott and Hockey's failure at the end of the day.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Budget 2014 contained broken promises, so he could then wear the liar tag. Like all Prime Ministers before him of course. He did some good, little damage (sir Phillip probably the worst). FTA's, carbon tax, boats, many positives. Tried to fix the deficit but couldn't negotiate a hostile Senate, or a hostile public.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Let's face it - Abbott will never be forgiven for his role in the fall of Saint Julia. Kev was never a real Labor bloke, collateral damage. But Jules, well. So can understand some anger at Abbott.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Budget 2014 contained broken promises, so he could then wear the liar tag. Like all Prime Ministers before him of course. He did some good, little damage (sir Phillip probably the worst). FTA's, carbon tax, boats, many positives.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The incentive is because the government taxes emissions under the carbon tax. Those taxes are then passed on to the consumer m who also pays more. Lose lose for Aussies.
author: TheJediMaster

text: So what if they run post 2020 ? Means more CO2 being taken out of the atmosphere, which presumably is the main game. Intensity and efficiency are also not the main game. CO2 reduction is.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Will industry process change ? Of course - that is exactly what DA does - pays for polluters to change their ways. Whether it's being funded by the government or by consumers through the carbon tax, there will always be a cost to the taxpayer (aka consumer).
author: TheJediMaster

text: In terms of waste our problems are rather bigger than couple of billion over a few years. Besides which the carbon tax took from us anyway - consumers directly as opposed to taxpayers.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Not at all, your post tried to link the two. My proposition was rather simple - the Climate Institute seems to be fairly blinkered in a desire for a carbon tax (or ETS) and nothing else. In Europe the ETS has been an economic brake, although it has helped the climate.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Perhaps if the CI are so dismissive of DA, they should propose no direct action at all, and leave us with the RET and ERT alone. Is that their preference ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Direct action is both cheaper that the carbon tax ($14 v $24) and by virtue of providing industry assistance, has a jobs growing aspect to it. So why would the CI be so dismissive of it ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: The problem here is that the ALP has never learnt any lessons from the disastrous RGR era. They reject their fiscal record, reject the lack of policy and direction, and haven't embraced any generational change.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yes of course it is. Wonder who reckons that reducing an expense item (fuel subsidy) can be claimed as a revenue raiser - was that the Library or the Greens themselves ? What a classic.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Compensation isn't that hard to work out. You figure out the impact of a broadening of the GST and the rate rise on lower income earners, and provide compensation in packaged up with welfare payments. At the same time you reduce tax rates for middle and higher income earners who will bear the brunt of the consumption tax.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Those nice people at the Parliamentary Library no doubt have a great book collection. But why the Greens are getting their economic advice from the Library is a little odd.
author: TheJediMaster

text: On the substance of the analysis, it's meaningless in the sense that ignores any lower income compensation package that would accompany a broadening of the GST. But of course the Greens won't mention that.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Well Daisy if you won't believe Treasury documents - the national report card on fiscal matters - then it's a bit hard to have a chat with you about the budget. Night.
author: TheJediMaster

text: One small problem with your argument - the budget numbers show the deficit peaked under Swan in 2013-14 and is reducing. See table 1 - revenue and expenditure over 45 years.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Have a look at the details. It was based on Labor's PEEFO in August 2013 and Abbott's first MYEFO in November 2013. It's pretty silly to use that example Daisy, it was badly flawed.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Some of those unions must be very confused with Labor and their CFMEU focus. The Shoppies for example who lean more to the centre than the left must be flabbergasted by the influence that the the hard core have. Can't say Shorten has managed it well at all.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Don't know which state you're in Jed, but in NSW those miners and developers have had a great relationship with Eddie O, Ian M and a bunch of other Labor types. Just ask ICAC.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Daisy - well i'm glad that you buy The Oz. Great read by the way. Particularly loved today's piece by David Crowe today on this very topic, what did you think ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Hmmm .... 90%+ posters are Labor or greenies and you think thumbs ups are a kpi to a Coalition supporter. That's rather funny, and a little naive if i may say.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The lesson Shorten needs to learn here is simple - don't oppose a building industry watch dog. If Labor hadn't shut down the ABCC, for reasons so obvious to most of us, there wouldn't have been a need for TURC.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Oh well. Besides the fact that TURC will save taxpayers billions by cleaning up the building industry. And let's face it, the $300 billion in debt left by RGR was the high water mark in waste.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Maybe they will. Yes it does seem odd dumping this late on a Friday night, but let's face it, everything TURC does gets criticised relentlessly by Shorten and the unions. You'd almost think they have something to hide ....
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yep, a few bad employers too. But TURC has predominantly exposed the union shams, potentially billions of dollars worth of them. The $80m price tag is a small price to pay to clean up this blight on our economic and industrial relations landscape.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The back room deals which helped the union but was detrimental to the workers, the too many "i do not recalls", the tag of a witness who lacked credibility, the futile attempts to discredit and shut down the Commission.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The International Energy Agency has certainly woken up to them. Australia on track to reclaim #1 coal exporter status, coal exports to rise 40%, 1,000 new coal fired plants being built in India and China.
author: TheJediMaster

text: One was something about more spending, one was something about bashing corporates and i can't even remember the other one. Oh that's it, a $600 billion 50% RET. What a zinger.
author: TheJediMaster

text: However granting control of a potentially strategic asset to the Chinese seems odd. The federal government is working on the development of northern Australia, the port will likely grow significantly. Presumably the new owners will be planning expansion.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It should be under majority national control, especially as it's a critical and strategic piece of infrastructure. It's also a supply chain monopolist through which much Northern Territory agriculture flows.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yes remember all the criticism. People laughed when Abbott said he'd stop the boats. They laughed when he said he'd turn them back. They laughed when he said he'd sell the boats.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yes, the carbon tax worked to reduce emissions. It also worked to reduce our standard of living, unemployment went up a full 1%, exporters lost contracts. There's a very good reason why no other country on earth put in something so punitive.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Direct Action was only introduced several months ago, and needs time to work. It really won't be able to be judged for a little while yet, so it's curious on what basis it's being dismissed already.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Abbott did a reasonable job, the couple of broken promises in the 2014 budget probably started the slide. Some good wins. But since the change over the government has quickly become more cohesive, communicative and objective. The change has been successful so far.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The rules were put in place almost 20 years ago in Kyoto. Since then we've changed our emissions profile, implemented counter measures and will achieve what we said we would.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Malcolm's going so well that the alternate Prime Minister is so flustered he isn't even able to keep his car on the road without hitting others. A three year car crash in motion, oh dear Bill.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Turnbull and Key know well that the Australia NZ relationship is based on far more solid stuff than arguing abut a few crims. Presumably we can agree that the less crims here in Australia the better.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Somebody must have forgotten to mention to this bloke that when economists want to crack a joke, the punchline always includes the word Greece. Go away mate, you're a sad joke.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Helen - okay will cop that one on the chin. The point intended was about the outcry any time a government mentions the word "welfare". Everyone needs to contribute to budget reform.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yeah, Howard only had to deal with the Asian Financial Crisis and the tech wreck, nothing major. The GFC was a blip in the middle of the mining boom, hardly dinted the finances. How badly did Rudd and Gillard waste the mining boom ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Seems remarkable that having had six years in government to address corporate taxation issues, the Labor party seem to have only decided it's a problem in the last year or so.
author: TheJediMaster

text: We all know that budget reform is needed on both spending and revenue. Everyone will need to contribute. Cutting outdated temporary levies which have a low impact seems like a good place to start.
author: TheJediMaster

text: One theory is that CO2 doesn't cause anywhere near the heating that's been predicted, and there's a much closer relationship between solar activity and the warming seen in the latter part of the 20th century.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The other thing COP21 could do is a bit of a refresher course on science and the models. Why have the models got a few key things wrong - temperature, Antarctic ice, climate sensitivity, and what's the plan to fix them ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: In that NASA evidence link, they claim the Antarctic ice sheet was shrinking in 2005. Should anyone mention to them the current record ice levels, right here in 2015 ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's hard to work out what the protesters are seeking. They didn't seem to be demanding anything in particular. So what message do they want to send to Paris ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Presumably then Malcolm is seeing a 28% ERT as a strong signal. Labor's 45% is way over and above what any country is offering, but i guess Shorten enjoys being Robinson Crusoe. Warwick McKibbon estimates to get the 45% we'd need a carbon tax of $200 per tonne. Ouch.
author: TheJediMaster

text: We can argue CT versus DA, but at the end of the day you can't provide a shred of evidence to prove that DA can't work. We'll have to wait until we start seeing emissions reductions to judge it.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Seems a bit odd to start having a go at the accounting rules. Commitments were made on our 2020 targets and Australia is going to honour them. Can't ask for more than that.
author: TheJediMaster

text: As for our 28% target - it's broadly in line many other nations - Japan, Canada, the Europeans. Haven't heard anyone proposing a target as crazy as 45%. Oh, wait on, the ALP has.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Well maybe, bit nervous about using the term "Paris" and "holiday" in the same sentence right now. But seriously, have we ever seen a world wide forum with so little in terms of purpose ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: It would be much better if we had some scientists standing up and presenting some current facts - refute the hiatus for example, explain the growth in Antarctic ice, the expansion of Pacific islands, the failure of climate sensitivity predictions, the impact of solar radiation. Get a bit of debate going.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The thing that strikes me about Paris next week is that there's no key objective. There's no headline goal (e.g. 30% ERT by 2030) that is being worked towards. Have a look at their website:
author: TheJediMaster

text: Sure it raises a bit of revenue in the short term. But it decreases growth in the economy, which reduces government revenues. (we didn't run surpluses during the carbon tax years you might have noted).
author: TheJediMaster

text: But that's yesterday's debate. Today with Bill putting a 45% ERT and 50% RET on the table, he's got to put some numbers against it. And if Bill won't do the maths, then the media and government should.
author: TheJediMaster

text: $600 billion over 15 years is the only starting point we have for the RET prediction alone. If people don't like that number, they should tell us why it's wrong.
author: TheJediMaster

text: If Shorten plans to borrow another fistful of dollars, on top of the $400 billion of debt they've already put us in, surely the ball is in his court to tell us how much it will cost and how he'll fund it.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Lenore - you don't seem too fussed that the ALP are throwing out big numbers like a 45% ERT by 2030, without even providing any ball park costs. Surely that's the starting point in any comparison between the alternative policy proposals.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Glad you raised Hartcher - oh how the mighty have fallen. Coincidental this week that Turnbull landed on a Parisian runway - and met Ambassador Brady - without any fanfare.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Exhibit A is Mr 15% - lazy, no ideas, thought he could walk to the Lodge of the back of Abbott. And look where it's got him - a national joke.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's fascinating the way that the left leaning press - the Guardian, Fairfax and the ABC - are trying to position the Coalition post-Abbott as a conservative version of the Gillard government post-Rudd.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The constant attention that remains on Abbott, the twisting of any small story into some sort of factional divide (e.g. this story) and the suggestions that Abbott still eyes a return to the Lodge.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yes the CT was effective in cutting emissions, but it was also effective in cutting employment, growth and export markets. Economics should rank well above before environment, as most Aussies agree.
author: TheJediMaster

text: There's something ironic about the Chinese complaining about policy stability in Australia. The only thing that's changed in the past few years is some tinkering at the edges with the RET.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Bit early for that stiff single malt, but by Friday night i'd expect Brough will need one. Clearly he won't resign so Turnbull will need to tap him on the shoulder.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Seems whatever the headlines unless there's a single or scaled binding target there won't be anything to enforce. Could take 10 years for that. Why don't they aim for something like 30% ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Not sure i agree with him on troops-on-the-ground but the debate that he stirs up every time he gets anywhere near a microphone is hilarious, with claims of white anting, undermining and so on. The bloke is entitled to his opinion, if people don't like it they should ignore it.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The budget debate in Australia seems to go around in circles. Everyone knows we need to get back to surplus but nobody wants to accept less spending or more tax.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Every government proposal seems to attract cries of"inequity" the moment it's announced. But the budget is badly broken and unless we want to pass a massive debt over to our children, we better start paying our way.
author: TheJediMaster

text: You're quite right about the economics. The more superannuation that retired people have, the less they will rely on the taxpayer. And that works at all income scales. A bit more incentive at the bottom end should be looked at too.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The Oz is definitely rightish leaning, in the same way the Guardian embraces left leaning issues like SSM, asylum seekers, climate change and bashing conservatives. Is there a problem with that ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: So it sounds like there's a few countries who are prepared to make life harder for themselves for negligible benefit. And then there's the rest of the world - the majority - who aren't.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Either way, Kyoto, Copenhagen and Paris are more about intent than anything. So far Australia has said that we would comply and it looks like we will. And we're on the ground in Paris as part of the discussions.
author: TheJediMaster

text: One middle-aged woman draped in an Australian flag caught in the crowd was surrounded by 20 to 30 Antifa members who shouted at her to take that fascist flag off now"."
author: TheJediMaster

text: The coalition for ambition sounds more like a coalition of division. Although does it now mean that Australia is in the good books in Paris, and the Chinese, Indians and House of Saud are the bad guys ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: The whole issue of the models and how their predictions have stacked up needs to be reviewed. Start with climate sensitivity predictions. Then come back with a new 2 degree forecast.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Good to see business taking a common sense approach to energy financing. From the carry on around this issue you'd reckon renewables are the only energy show in town. In reality they're only about 6%.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Is anyone else rather surprised that Bill - at 14% PPM and an approval rating of minus 38 (worst in 12 years) - is providing image lessons and character assessments ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: We're all unusual in our own way i guess. But honestly Bill, boasting a 14% PPM rating, do you really think that you should be dishing out character assessments and image analysis to Tony Abbott, or anyone else for that matter ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Coal's market share might be declining, but because energy markets are growing, the amount of coal demanded is still expanding. The ASEAN nations for example expect coal demand to rise 40% in the next 25 years.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Climate conventions like COP21 really should be presenting facts and forecasts, not become an ideological opponent of existing fuel types. When will they start going after petrol for example ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Boy oh boy this is one confusing climate change conference. One moment Australia is being praised for backing carbon markets, and on the same day we're being slammed for pointing out the obvious - coal-powered power generation isn't slowing down anytime soon.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's probably better if he does move on, but if Abbott does decide to stay then hopefully it would include a good long chat with Turnbull beforehand. If they can reach a mutually acceptable working relationship, then Abbott could continue to make a positive contribution to the Australian parliament and people.
author: TheJediMaster

text: That's odd - when Obama was here in Australia a year ago for the G20 he was rude enough to suggest to our conservative party that they weren't doing enough about climate change.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Beside a bit of complexity and the names of the revenue and spending items, how does managing the household budget differ from the national ones ? The principles remain the same.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The ABC on the other hand - with their 45% of journos confessing to be Greens supporters - is far more about pumping us full of their progressive ideology than anything else.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The bad news is they're an appalling results for Australia. Over a decade of deficits, half a trillion in debt. We're leaving the kids with a noose, not a golden goose.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The ANAO recommends that, as a matter of priority given the significant amount of Commonwealth funding that is involved, the Department of the Treasury recommend to the Treasurer that he make a determination requiring the return of the $1.5 billion paid to Victoria in relation to the East West Link project.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Australia was built on roads and coal mines. The latter will phase out over a few decades, but you make roads sound like a bad thing, in a country as large as Australia.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Ha if your point is that an incoming Federal government might want to support their state counterpart, and make their predecessors look even worse than they were, well I guess they're guilty as charged !
author: TheJediMaster

text: Actually John the accounting principles are rather straight forward - dodgy accruals. In 2011-12 our spending had exploded to a whopping $371 billion. To give the illusion that spending had fallen during the "we've returned to surplus" fairytale, Swannie transferred a heap of expenditure to the 2013-14 year, taking it out of 2012-13.
author: TheJediMaster

text: As a result spending in the latter was reported as $367 billion (lower than the previous year). But of course by robbing Peter to pay Paul, spending bulleted back up to $ 406 billion in 2013-14. As a result we got wobbly looking deficits:
author: TheJediMaster

text: Of course anyone with half an accounting brain knew exactly what Swan was up to at the time. You should have seen some of the other tricks he was up to as well.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Or you could look at it the other way around - consumer demand for fossil fuels grew exponentially, and suppliers did just that. Meant people stopped suffering from hunger, cold etc. Glass half full approach.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But given the goal is now 1.5 degrees and we're apparently two thirds of the way there already, is there any detail on how the world (Indians and Chinese excepted) plan to get there ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: You're looking at emissions projections, not the inventory But what is amazing is how we've been on a downward path for years, but apparently emissions are going to explode in the next 15 years. What baseless crap.
author: TheJediMaster

text: We must be looking at different tables. The one here is a 2013-14 to 14-15 sectoral summary. Nothing to do with 2030. That link you sent doesn't look the same.
author: TheJediMaster

text: If your point is the carbon tax reduced emissions, nobody disputes it. Nor that unemployment shot up as a result, GDP growth fell and exports were hammered. Which is why nobody else has one.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Well we all know how wrong the projections / models have been, but it's confusing what you're reading. The NGGI is a stocktake of the current state of play, not a forecast. The term 2030 doesn't even appear in it.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's a brave person who claims that Australia's emissions are rising. The NGGI report clearly shows a downward trend in CO2 emissions overall, and in most sectors over the past ten years.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Not quite sure what you're on about, but don't you find it fascinating that the article fails to mention that the last quarter was 0.3% below the 3rd quarter, or that our trend is firmly down ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: In fact we're over 10% below 2005 levels, not bad. This report seemed to neglect that, speaking of cherry picking. Did you get a chance to read it btw ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Had a good read of the NGGI this arvo, and you'd have to question some of the measurements. When the headline numbers are "Seasonally adjusted and weather normalised", it's hard not to smell a rat. Notably the unadjusted emissions are below the reported outcomes.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Duck for cover, cue the cries of "work choices". Of course any sensible IR changes will be nothing of the sort, but we can hear Ged and Dave yelling already.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's one thing to have a go at Hunt, but people seem to have forgotten that ultimately the Queensland government are responsible for the approval of the port, and the mine. Perhaps they should be the object of any outrage.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But the suggestion that coal kills is pretty ridiculous - how many lives are saved by heating, lighting, clean water, cooked food etc ? Not to mention quality of life.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Don't you just love the advocates titles - "community campaigner" from 350.org. Campaigning for which community - the unemployed of Bowen, Indians without access to clean water or energy, Australian taxpayers who'll benefit from royalties and income taxes - which community ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: But also think hard about those New Years resolutions for 2016 - an explanation of the hiatus, the record high Antarctic ice (both sea and land), the climate sensitivity problems in the models and those expanding Pacific Islands could be just the tonic for the new year !
author: TheJediMaster

text: Well you'd have to agree that evertime the Coalition return to power, there's always a big Labor debt to repay. Happened every time since WW2 (thankfully only four times though).
author: TheJediMaster

text: Perhaps if you stop thinking of our tax system as a bunch of concessions, things might seem fairer. Don't forget that the top 10% pay 50% of all income tax, and 50% of families pay zero tax overall.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Hardly an excuse Rhonda, just a simple but sad reality. Labor started with a surplus, and turned it into the greatest spending spree ever seen in this nation. In their genius they didn't even work out it would mean years of record deficits.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's pretty hard to criticise a healthcare system which produces numbers that good, but of course we'll hear that the government is deliberately targeting the frail, the poor, females, the aged. Rubbish. If Labor hadn't wrecked it, the Coalition wouldn't need to fix it.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Why would you make such as silly statement as claiming the deficit is doubled ? Swan left a $48 billion whopper, it's below that now but has a long way to go before we can start repaying debt.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But where should the public stop funding, where's the line - should the taxpayer be paying for a smoker's quadruple bypass, for laser eye surgery, for a motorcyclists prosthetic leg ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: How kind of you. The government does fund most of it anyway, but if we keep adding some of the specialised additional services to the public purse we'll be broke faster that you can say "elective surgery".
author: TheJediMaster

text: No certainly don't want a US style system, but there also has to be acknowledgement that the government can't provide all health care costs. We gold plated our electricity supplies and look at the cost - now we're heading down the same path with health care.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The spending has to be curtailed at some point. Even King knows this, but refuses to admit it. She's just cherry picking here, going for the most emotive argument available - the potential cancer patient.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Windsor claims he's a better than 50% chance of contesting this year's election. Not sure why he'd bother - but would he be an independent or a Labor candidate ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Next she might start up on fiscal matters, where her own estimates were out by half a billion bucks each week, every week of RGR. The $106 billion woman according to Janet Albrechtsen.
author: TheJediMaster

text: You're not going to get much innovation or progress with a nationalised health system. Having a strong private sector medical market raises the bar, and pushes down the cost to government.
author: TheJediMaster

text: There they go again - Labor and the Greens simply refuse to acknowledge our disastrous spending levels and dangerous deficit. Fiscal pygmies. Good thing they won't get a say in the changes.
author: TheJediMaster

text: And to think, with a pap smear required every 2 - 3 years, the impact of this will be less than fuel excise indexation, which was about 7 cents per day.
author: TheJediMaster

text: I'd wouldn't be conflating issues like the Matildas with Mel. The Matildas get paid a pittance because they can't draw a crowd, which is the real barometer of popularity (and value) in sport.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Mel copped some stupid comments - it was cringe worthy to watch live. But unless the author here has spoken to her, it's just as disrespectful to describe what emotions she should be feeling. Almost as bad as the Gayle suggestion that Mel shouldn't be blushing.
author: TheJediMaster

text: There's still an upbeat mood flowing from Paris amongst the climate change lobby. The last day deal was a solid achievement although there's plenty of skepticism on the real climate impacts. Either way, getting world leaders to all agree was a triumph in diplomacy by the French.
author: TheJediMaster

text: If that's the case then Clements is going to make getting his next job rather trickier. The alleged incident was bad enough, not recognising the transgression even worse. Is he trying to make this a he said / she said ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Given Foley's missing in action, it won't even be good enough for Shorten to hide in the vegetable section of Woolies and pretend this is a state matter. The issue has been around for a while now and it's time for Bill to show voters whether he is a person of principal, or a mouse full of hot air.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Turnbull has set the benchmark here forcing Briggs to stand aside. Let's now find out if Bill "i want a report" Shorten treats the matter with the same seriousness that Turnbull did.
author: TheJediMaster

text: He might even find some frozen zingers in that aisle too Tim. After which, Bill might proceed to the kitchen accessories aisle to show journos his favourite type of GST-cutting knife. Or is that a RGR backstabbing knife ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Did he happen to mention to any of them that his new carbon tax and renewable energy targets would send energy prices through the roof again, or is he saving that one for a rainy day when nobody might notice ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Most Aussies recognise that we need to fix the budget, but nobody's prepared to take a cut themselves of course. Shorten offers nothing by way of spending cuts, when it's at 25.9%.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Worst of all - in Bill's first day back from holidays after the year of ideas, his first action was to head to Queanbeyan and complain about the GST. Wow.
author: TheJediMaster

text: No Daisy, Kev was guaranteed an election thanks to the leadership rules. Bill could fall on his sword of course. Abbott - yep still reckon he would have beaten Shorten, but alas we'll never know.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Nope didn't say that - everyone's going to have to contribute to budget repair. But it's pretty stupid attacking the GST when the impact of an ETS / RET would likely have a worse effect on poorer Aussies.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's such a silly and transparent line Shorten runs - he wants to attack a potential GST rise but ignores the obvious comeback - his new carbon tax with its price, growth and jobs impacts.
author: TheJediMaster

text: You'd have to ask Malcolm, I just said i'd love to see it. Bill struggles to string a structured sentence together much of the time, can't imagine Malcolm would be too worried whether he goes first or second.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Credlin had quite a ball at the snow a few months ago, she even stayed in a nice house with a river view, quite apart from Abbott, and sans Brian. A little bit of insight for both yourself and Bernie.
author: TheJediMaster

text: As Malcolm pointed out - perhaps you weren't listening - the main benefit of the Cayman investments is no chance of conflicts of interest arising. The tax is paid here in Australia.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Oh well, Bill's year of ideas has fallen pretty flat. He should probably try to hold the volume-11 scaremongering until the election campaign, but it looks like he's got no other option left.
author: TheJediMaster

text: You couldn't really call it luck - Abbott's done well to make the seat his own. His best move now would be to retire, go out undefeated inhis seat at least.
author: TheJediMaster

text: WA Labor became aware of this following a query from The Australian. Having become aware of this omission, WA Labor has disclosed the donation to the AEC as an amendment to the 2012-13 disclosure.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Flintoff is right - Gayle did make a pork chop of himself. But it was hardly a hanging offence, and certainly shouldn't exclude someone that exciting from being part of BBL6.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Ruddock shouldn't be pushed but Bishop should. Abbott made many mistakes but being loyal to her was his final downfall. Her helicopter exploits and treachery was a stain on the principles of the Libs.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yeah, that showed just how much she's lost it. My sister used to work for her and I've been in her APH office a couple of times but what an embarrassment she's become.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Even as a Liberal supporter I'd have to say to Bishop and Jones, the damage you've both done to the party has been significant. There's no place for either of you.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Channel 10 isn't exactly known for its vibrant and extensive political coverage. Having leftie hacks like Bongbongo running their political coverage never helped either. So there's every chance that the Bolt report has been close to their most successful political program.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The ABC on the other hand run wall-to-wall left wing partisan group think. That it costs we taxpayers a bunch of wasted dollars is disgraceful. Might be even better to put it into health or education, at least there might be a national benefit.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Mal's made a pretty good start in many areas, although national security hasn't been one of those. Good move to head over to Iraq and show his face on the ground, meet the troops.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Has anyone heard Shorten actually say the words "15 percent" ? Since that December Newspoll he's been very reluctant to say the words. Although speaking through a lettuce seems to help.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Surely by now he should have leapt out from behind a lettuce leaf to attack this proposal as harsh, unfair, cruel, impacting working Australians with Labor values (read: unions) and the disadvantaged.
author: TheJediMaster

text: There's so much talk about the impact of "concessions" on the budget. Apparently these include the difference between the capital gains tax rate and top marginal income tax rate, the difference between the top tax rate and the superannuation tax rate of 15%.
author: TheJediMaster

text: With 800,000 people taking $17 billion per year on the DSP, perhaps there's your starting point. The notion that one in about 14 working age people being unable to work due to a claimed disability is a joke.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Possibly, although remember that Australians acknowledged in 2013 that Labor had left a fiscal disaster. People recognise the need for budget restraint and repair, but how best to do it is a bit trickier.
author: TheJediMaster

text: If the government presented a case to the voters where either GST is increased by $30 billion a year, or welfare is reduced by $30 billion a year, wonder which way Australians would go.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Whether the report was truth or not - i'll lean towards the not - it was such a blatant partisan attempt to have a go at the conservative government, that whatever words it contained were largely meaningless.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Had she of course prepared the report in 2013, when the flow of asylum seekers was at its peak, it would have been treated as objective. Not real smart, an own goal.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Nobody wants kids in detention Daisy. But if the choice is to separate them from their parents - often dad can't pass security checks - or keep them all together, what do you do ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Possibly the worst thing that's happened to the asylum seekers over recent years was the Human Rights Commission's dreadful and political kids in detention report. By making such a blatant and partisan political issue of the detention facilities, Triggs polarised domestic opinions.
author: TheJediMaster

text: She probably thought she was being smart and would force the government into a corner. Triggs didn't think that one through too well, and after the three different stories to the Senate committee, finished up with a fair bit of egg on face and a public firmly behind the government's policies. As a result, reports like this one are generally ignored for the most part. That the boats have stopped is the key.
author: TheJediMaster

text: These people knew that Australia's border protection policies meant that they would probably never make it to the Australian mainland, yet they tried anyway. They knew the risks, yet they came - quite possibly after paying to fly into Indonesia, ditching their ID papers and jumping on a boat. So sadly their role is to be a deterrent to others.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Harsh ? Yes. Ideal ? Not at all. But if it means that others won't drown on the way here, especially kids, then the policy makes sense. Most Australians agree.
author: TheJediMaster

text: We all want the detention facilities to be emptied, but there is a process to go through. National security issues involved too of course. Labor left a disaster and Abbott fixed it up. Hopefully soon we'll never need to talk about Manus or Nauru again.
author: TheJediMaster

text: People donate to all sorts of causes because they generally believe in them. Some of us hope that our contributions mean kids eat more food and live in shelter, but to be honest we'll never really know.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Sure, and I'm not having a go at the workers. But it is a fine line between activism and aid provision. It would be pretty easy for SCA to get that instruction to the troops.
author: TheJediMaster

text: No you are quite right, i'm not claiming any direct evidence. But there's plenty of examples of NGO's crossing the line from aid provider to activist, e.g. Oxfam. That's the point.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yes I read the words. Over the last 15 years I've donated thousands and thousands of dollars to StC, so feel I have the the right to comment. Had also done the same for Oxfam, until they started spending my contributions on bashing corporates and governments.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Lol - based on the carry on we hear from the enviro-lobby here in Australia a few people must be shocked that we rank inside the top 10% of countries for our environmental actions. Tony Abbott would be proud.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Naysayers can cherry pick particular categories - top 8% overall is pretty good, far better than you'd expect based on all the talking down our environmental policies receive from people.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The forest burns, so what does enviro-champion Bob "the clown" Brown do ? Why he goes and creates enough trouble close to the bush fires sufficient that the local police have to divert their precious resources to go and arrest him.
author: TheJediMaster

text: A most ignorant post. Whether it was the Chinese, Japanese, Spanish, Portugese, Indonesians, Indians, Dutch, Americans, Mexicans, Chileans - take your pick - Australia would have been colonised at some point along the way. It's always been the way of mankind. Reading articles like this one you would think that time should stand still.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Beauty is in the eye of the beholder i guess, but Australia has become the best country on the planet according to most Australians. It is multicultural, plural and diverse.
author: TheJediMaster

text: That Aboriginal people would begrudge that, some would call selfish. As for backwards and primitive - the world has not stood still over thousands of years. Time to join in ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Frankly it's just reality - Aboriginals were never going to be able to stop the march of human progress. Other races and cultures have developed, expanded and for better or worse, colonised. Every corner of the earth.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Aboriginals seem to think that they should be able to - right now - have and own the entire continent of Australia for themselves. Thousands of years of human development suggests they're dreaming.
author: TheJediMaster

text: If the British hadn't landed in 1788, one suspects the Chinese or Japanese would have within the following century. We can only speculate on the status of the current Indigenous Australian under either scenario.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Think about a satellite hundreds of kilometers above earth trying to measure temperatures. The satellite data has to be adjusted for humidity, rain, solar activity, atmospheric shifts, all sorts of things.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Howard was perfectly within his rights to do so Daisy. Besides, being a Lodge resident has had no bearing on the quality of Prime Ministerships, so not sure why it's a big deal.
author: TheJediMaster

text: When Gillard was booted out in June 2013, there was a huge party that night at the Lodge (right around Australia too, but we digress ....). Rumour has it that the wine cellar was emptied in the process, and Swannie's name kept popping up.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But Johnny didn't live there, so he wasn't responsible. And that's despite voters telling him to live there on no less than four separate occasions, that his house was in good order.
author: TheJediMaster

text: No, the possums weren't a problem in those days. There was a brief storm in 2008 which some think did some damage, but Howard had left the Lodge in good shape to manage it. All the problems started well after that, and compounded quickly.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The extent of the damage was significantly worse than expected and Australians paid a heavy price. The repairs were too much for a single Prime Minister to handle, so it has taken two PM's.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The public system can live without private, but not the other way round. Either way, funding for the private system is independent of Medicare. The government manage and fund Medicare, but they also want people in private cover. They all coexist which benefits all of us.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Private insurers are there to provide a service to consumers who are happy to pay money out of their own pocket to get a better service to protect themselves and their children. If you think that's bad, then capitalism clearly isn't your thing. It's pretty basic market driven stuff.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Open your eyes a bit George. If you read a bit more about this issue, you'd learn that Sussan Ley has asked the insurers to justify their request for a rate rise by opening their books and walking through their projections.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Medical providers are currently trying to drive down costs, which presumably then should be passed on to consumers, meaning insurance premiums could be kept lower. Frankly that's just good governance and good management.
author: TheJediMaster

text: And what do we get from Shorten - the suggestion that higher rates are already locked in. Ley will ultimately make a decision - she's the arbiter - but Shorten suggesting it's locked in is yet another fabrication. And you seriously wonder why some of us are cynical ? C'mon George.
author: TheJediMaster

text: We had the kids through private, and the difference was big. Stay for five days rather than kicked out after a day, sweated over all the small stuff, definitely worth paying the extra for.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Public is hardly more efficient or effective. Private hospitals like private schools - provide a better service than the government, reduce pressure on public system, makes sense for government to fund them.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Bongiorno, funny one. Did he happen to mention in his expert analysis that the ALP under Gillard had a conscience vote too, and it was defeated just three years ago ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Good to see Abbott happy to accept the will of the people. He was, after all, the PM who made the plebiscite central to the Coalition policy on SSM. Gay Australians may ironically owe Abbott a big debt of gratitude if and when SSM becomes law.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Frankly most Australians are bored senseless by this issue. It might rank amongst some, but in the lead up to the election you'd hardly see it as any real vote changer.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Besides, if it is going to change any votes, which way would they go anyway ? Under the Coalition policy we'd probably get SSM introduced much faster than under the ALP plan.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It'd be great to see a conscience vote on SSM in parliament, even a secret one if that's an available option. Use one of the private members bills. Shouldn't that legalise it if successful ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: For the record in a plebiscite i would vote yes, mainly so we could move on. Gay people surely deserve to be as miserable as every other married couple. (sorry darling, joke!)
author: TheJediMaster

text: In terms of the major issues facing us - the budget disaster, national security, getting growth and unemployment sorted, the upcoming election - gay marriage doesn't even rate to most Aussies.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Just imagine if it started being taxed - it'd mean that whenever a family decided to sell their house and buy a new one (say they moved cities), they would lose a certain percentage of their home and would only be able to buy a cheaper one. In reality, they'd be poorer. What a stupid suggestion.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Turnbull and Morrison will need to do much better than drop spending 0.6% in four years - that's pathetically unambitious. They should be aiming for something that starts with 23.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Having said that. the battles lines for the election are taking shape. We've got a government that is at least committed to fixing the budget, and we've got an opposition that want to return us to the carnage of the RGR years. A return to Gonski, a return to the carbon tax. They'd probably even start the boats up again. Will Labor never learn ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: A fistful of dollars ? The nation's budget certainly can't afford that. Next someone might ask - did the Treasurer fire five shots or all six ? Well in all that post-GFC excitement, Swannie fired the lot, reloaded with more borrowings, and emptied the chamber again. There's no bullets left for the next threat.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's good to see a bit of restraint being practiced by the government at least. In 2008, 65% of all DSP applicants were assessed as unable to work. These days it's around 35%, saving the budget $1.2 billion per year.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Swan left a deficit of $48 billion. Since then it's gone down. Not by much, not by nearly enough i'll agree, but down. Pretty simple really. Perhaps you'd even like to fact check that one.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yeah sure, going from debt free to being $300 billion in debt in six short years in the middle of a mining boom was a most impressive effort wasn't it. Took us from wealthy to mediocre, that's some achievement.
author: TheJediMaster

text: They might have started with Treasury number, but Swan and Wong took their own special ownership of them. How do you think they cumulatively missed their forecasts by about $140 million over six awful years ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: I always love reading that ABC "fact check", which uses Swan numbers from mid 2013 and combines them with MYEFO numbers in 2013 - before a budget had been handed down - and claims a doubled deficit. Gold.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Give you a hint - Labor never once got within cooee of their forecasts, the only mob that want to believe them are the ABC, naturally ! Oh, and you.
author: TheJediMaster

text: I criticised an increase in public education funding. As we all know, the private sector are far smarter about the use of resources and outcomes than public, which is why they get better education outcomes.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Fascinating analysis, but it ignores the simplest of stats - private schools appear far more regularly at the top of the MySchool rankings. It doesn't take a genius to work out why !
author: TheJediMaster

text: My goodness you just made an argument rather than the standard insults. You'd have a point except the first comment refers to the public education system. The private system benefits from more money because they use it to provide better teachers, resources, programs and facilities.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Think you've had a logic failure there, all I said was banks will fund it. Let's watch this space and see how it works out. One suspects you're going to be rather disappointed.
author: TheJediMaster

text: If you're trying to say that Adani won't proceed, that's a bet i'm more than happy to take. You seriously think that banks won't touch an investment bringing energy to tens of millions for decades ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Our commitment today is simply this: the people smugglers will not prevail over our sovereignty. Our borders are secure. The line has to be drawn somewhere and it is drawn at our border.
author: TheJediMaster

text: FD raised the past. The issue of kids is particularly confronting, but one of the reasons people struggle to see the parents as victims is they've country-shopped and chosen Australia (rather than the first safe haven). Plus they've ignored all the warnings.
author: TheJediMaster

text: * the jobs ?* the export revenue ?* the hundreds of millions of Indians who want to rise above poverty ?* the use of cleaner coal ahead of dirtier coal ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Haven't mobs like the ACF worked out that the scare mongering isn't working ? In fact, that sort of rubbish loses them sympathy and support. Perhaps they need some better lobbyists.
author: TheJediMaster

text: As for solar - we all look forward to the day that solar under prices and coal, on it's own two feet mind you. But you need to realise that's some years away.
author: TheJediMaster

text: That's a real stretch - Carmichael hardly represents all the earth's coal resources, which is the extension of your argument. No forests means a heap more CO2 and less oxygen to breath, bad idea.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Our coal is high efficiency and low emissions. Remember when Abbott said that our coal will actually reduce Indian emissions (and was laughed at of course by a few ignoramuses) ? This is what he was talking about:
author: TheJediMaster

text: If you really are committed to Australia becoming a republic, then you want to be sure that the manner and the timing of the referendum is ... such that it is successful and that it unites rather than divides Australians, Mr Turnbull said.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Maybe, but it's hardly a vote changer. The SSM lobby will try to make it a big issue, but economics, national security, health and education will be the main issues.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Sure, ppm doesn't mean that much, but to suggest Shorten's had a win here is a real stretch. Most Aussies remember his January as being the guy who stalked shoppers in the vegetable aisle and wanted to know their lettuce preferences !
author: TheJediMaster

text: Tim - looks like you might be getting slogans confused. The "$80 billion health and education" was a slogan that never appeared in any budget statement. And it was raised during the Abbott years, long after Howard and Costello had moved on.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The analysis was refuted at the time, and strangely enough the only time we hear it these days is by the odd commenter - you won't hear it from the ALP or any politicians. Have you worked out why ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yes, the MYEFO where Abbott had made no - zero - major changes to the budget. The ABC picked up Bowen's figures showing the Labor would deliver a surplus next year if they were still in government. Like i said, humorous.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Okay Daisy so you can't provide any details. That's okay, because in reality, none exist. But i'm sure you'll keep using the line. I'll just keep asking for an explanation, which can't be done. Find a new line maybe ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: So are you suggesting universal healthcare is a right, but universal education isn't ? Why should the government not make a contribution to private school funding, but provide Medicare to the rich ? It's a very confusing position.
author: TheJediMaster

text: I always laugh when someone uses the "doubled the deficit" line Daisy. Abbott inherited a deficit of $48 billion. It'd be great if you could talk us through how it's doubled (and that pathetic ABC analysis using Swan's numbers doesn't quite cut it).
author: TheJediMaster

text: Might i suggest you have a read of the budget as it stands. With spending sitting at 25.9%, it's a pretty ignorant suggestion that spending isn't the major cause of the deficit.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Good decision Malcolm - revenue is a bit of an issue but spending is a whopping one. He might be wise to use the few months leading up to the budget to educate and convince Australians of the need for serious expenditure cuts.
author: TheJediMaster

text: There seems to be some sort of inbuilt mindset amongst the Premiers that education and health spending need to rise. Why can't we be smarter with what we spend already ? It's not as if there aren't a heap of inefficiencies in the systems at the moment.
author: TheJediMaster

text: I know it's been condemned by a lot of people but if you look at the return per dollar investment, a lot of what's been achieved through the Direct Action plan is as economically effective as any other scheme it's ever come up with, including regulation or carbon pricing, Dr Finkel said.
author: TheJediMaster

text: That one's easy - removing the carbon tax reduced the input costs for those who rely on energy to run their businesses, which meant they made more money and paid more company tax.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Not only that, they employed more people so they paid more income tax. Unemployment went up a full 1% during the period the carbon tax was in place. And it's come down almost half a percent since. Not all of that is due to the CT, but much of it is.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The government might have taken a short term revenue hit by ditching $6 billion a year in revenue, but they made it up in spades through growth over the medium term.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Doubt it. For all his budgie smuggling, triathlon competing water activities, i don't think we ever saw him patrolling the Timor Sea or Christmas Island area on a Border Force frigate.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Marshall is being pragmatic at least - why do we need 350 people studying climate change observations ? The satellites and computers can do much of that. We'll still get the analysis and reports. And on the raw data hopefully.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But the smugness and arrogance of the enviro-lobby, to polarise and dumb down the debate as they did, should never be forgotten. And it's not as if the models have proven them right.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Great to see the Nats get a bit of airtime tonight. As a couple of speakers noted, it's a big change for them traditionally. Hopefully Barnaby and Malcolm can work well together.
author: TheJediMaster

text: You're quite right, and yeah I got a bit fired up. We read plenty of deeply personal and insulting comments about higher profile government members in these pages. Politics is an emotive business, passion is understandable.
author: TheJediMaster

text: A Minister who has been neither controversial nor vocal, who's delivered a number of trade successes and is bowing out graciously, shouldn't be subject to low grade attacks. Have a look below.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The ALP did contribute Mary, as did the Howard government. Though it sounds like you haven't noticed that the Australian industries which will benefit include aged care, farming, legal as well as mining.
author: TheJediMaster

text: There are times for a bit of humility. I can understand the hatred of Abbott, pathetic as it was, but someone like Robb shouldn't be subject to the same. Especially with his documented issues.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Honestly you progressive types are a miserable mob. A bloke who's served admirably for years retires and you carry on like a bunch of angry school kids. Primary school kids.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Good on you for honesty. Sure there's the corporate greed component, but greed also means growth, more jobs and competition, which balances the greed. And if people don't like price rises, they'll shop around.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Not sure if Marr's captured the sentiment of the average Aussie here. Remember last election that western Sydney, outer Melbourne were all demanding action on asylum seekers. 50,000 came and the people were ropeable.
author: TheJediMaster

text: He discusses kids with "no prospect of release". Well guess what - they can return home via the jumbo jet or A380 that many arrived in, any time their parents like. Stop using children as an emotive weapon - it's becoming counter productive. The 70% of Aussies that First Dog quoted last week that support strong borders are testament to that.
author: TheJediMaster

text: David - nobody likes incarcerating people fleeing persecution. But we want controlled borders, and orderly migration program, no loss of life at sea and not to be dictated to by the people smugglers.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Both the Coalition and Labor now support the current policy. Labor learned the hard way, refusing to adopt the Howard strategy. To stop the boats, all sugar has to be off the table. Harsh it is. But the asylum seekers knew the risks, and many had country-shopped, reducing sympathy.
author: TheJediMaster

text: You annunciated the dichotomy sadly but well - "punish or we will be overwhelmed". Well look at Europe. They're probably wishing right now that they'd gone for the former a year ago.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Labor's sitting on 35% which can't get them over the line, and it's not as if there's a bunch of winning policies waiting there to drag voters over to the Labor cause.
author: TheJediMaster

text: As far as the models go it's well acknowledged that they haven't been too accurate - large warming discrepancies, expanding ice, climate sensitivity variances. And all that with adjusted data too.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Why are people upset about this decision ? Surely if climate change is such a scary beast, then retasking CSIRO staff to plan adaption strategies - whatever that means - provides more value than collecting raw data.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Professor Watson, who served as chairman of the IPCC from 1997-2002, said: "The mistakes all appear to have gone in the direction of making it seem like climate change is more serious by overstating the impact. That is worrying. The IPCC needs to look at this trend in the errors and ask why it happened."
author: TheJediMaster

text: As for Windsor, if he had any guts he'd front up this year and cop his medicine, but it doesn't look like happening. Maybe Tim D can fire him up.
author: TheJediMaster

text: And as for the Tony Windsor references, well at least Barnaby stands for something and has been true to his electorate. The people of New England would love Windsor to stand this election, just to give him the thank you present he gutlessly denied them in 2013.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The debt and deficit disaster remains quite real. Since Labor gave us record deficits and hundreds of billions in debt, not a single cent which has been repaid. Dunno about you, but i'd definitely call it a disaster when we're going to be asking our kids to pay for our lifestyle.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The problem is fairly simple - Labor are telling us they'll make a few a few more bucks tinkering with NG policy. What they won't dare say is that they'll spend tens of billions on other programs.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Think this one takes Bill's "idea" count to about three, or four. And here's the problem - most of them are completely unfunded, not even so much as costed. Here's a link to a couple of the Labor "ideas":
author: TheJediMaster

text: Last time we were told about a "temporary deficit", the nation suddenly had $300 billion in debt, and permanent deficits. Australians won't be hoodwinked again by these fiscal flops - when we hear words like "big bold policy reform" from Labor, most of us know that just means more debt.
author: TheJediMaster

text: And as a result we've had record deficits - about ten year's worth - ever since. If that's an example of good fiscal management i'd hate to see a bad one.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Actually it was Labor Daisy. Handed a $19 billion surplus in 2007-08, within two short years Labor had turned this into a $54 billion dollar deficit, and spending of over 26%.
author: TheJediMaster

text: I can't recall a single plan there, certainly nothing to address the structural issues in the budget. Although of course there'll be plenty of new spending, e.g. the worthless Gonski program.
author: TheJediMaster

text: If Bowen reckons that Labor have funded policies to take to the election, he mustn't have talked to Bill about the 50% renewable energy target, which has not even been costed let alone funded. Ditto the next version of the carbon tax. According to some estimates, the RET would cost $600 billion over ten years, which rather negates a saving of $32 billion over the same period on the negative gearing numbers.
author: TheJediMaster

text: He was speaking metaphorically of course, but about 14 days later the ALP did knife Gillard and reinstall that messiah, Kevvie. And that was the end of Australia's worst PM in decades, what an embarrassment.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Either way, the small dent that they'll fill kin the budget won't even pay for half of their proposed spending increases. where's the rest of the money coming from ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: In some regards yes, but causes like SSM and climate change would hardly be his cup of tea. Not to mention the influence of unions, and how The Age has been a friend of the CFMEU.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Well you might be nostalgic Gay, but spare a thought for David Syme who'd be turning in his grave at the thought of left-leaning progressive fest that The Age has become.
author: TheJediMaster

text: There's every chance that by this time next year Dio will be an independent. Palmer will lose Fairfax, then may well lose party status if he can't muster up 500 signatures. Then we might get to see the real Dio.
author: TheJediMaster

text: They've had their chance to show the people they are worthy of their votes - and in some cases they've been spectacular failures. Lambie, Lazarus, Muir, Wang - here's looking at you.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Wong and Conroy have never been the sharpest knives in the drawer (think budget deficits, media and free speech crackdowns). Looks like a divided ALP has fallen over on the wrong side of the fence on this one. Again.
author: TheJediMaster

text: That is not the business of doctors. But if you want it to be, then extend it to telling the government to stop the drownings at sea. That saves far more lives.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It'd be nice though is Tony Windsor made his mind up - either he opposes mining, or he loves it. Selling his farming land to miners made him financially rich, something he doesn't seem to declare much. Mind you, selling out his constituents made him somewhat less rich, in a people sense.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The government should really ditch any talk of revenue matters. Spending remains the most significant and disastrous structural legacy of the party of fiscal carnage, and spending is where the repair needs to start.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Back in the day the law was put into the relevant Act, one suspects there wasn't any real demand for marriage between people of the same sex. T'was rather hidden away for the most part.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Well it's a pretty pathetic argument you put there, the most stupid of which being that it's the "Tories" whodunnit. The last time there was a SSM vote it was Labor who ensured it was defeated.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Actually budgie you've shown that you know nothing of anything too much legal - free speech is one thing but the right to free speech doesn't include inciting violence. Which your post did.
author: TheJediMaster

text: 1. Marriage is a legal issue. The government makes laws. They are subject to the will of the people given the government's role is broadly to support the will of the people (doesn't always work that way of course).
author: TheJediMaster

text: Fast forward to today, whilst nominally the majority favour SSM, it's not really a conviction issue. There's a fair chance that SSM will be defeated at a plebiscite, which is presumably that's the main reason that gay lobby aren't too keen on it. Why else wouldn't they support the will of the people being tested ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: On some of those marginal issues like SSM, border protection, climate change and the republic, left-leaning voters might have expected some immediate change in government position. Perhaps they thought we'd immediately change from having a Prime Minister to a President.
author: TheJediMaster

text: For we on the centre-right, it's very pleasing that Turnbull hasn't caved into the pressure of small minorities and flipped the national policies. As he's said several times, he's running an inclusive, Cabinet government. Let's hope it continues.
author: TheJediMaster

text: You really are a dill. But I'll give you another one you'll also love - when Whitlam gave his dismissal speech on the steps of OPH, I was standing about 5m away. Knock yourself out ! Adios.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Not a long bow at all - once Windsor started seeing the polls in the lead up to September 2013, he scurried away like a rat down a drainpipe. He'll do the same this year - talk it up a bit then run away.
author: TheJediMaster

text: And look at the poll numbers today - barely 15% would vote Labor / Green - yet that's who Windsor (and his equally disgraceful mate Oakshott) supported in 2010. Astonishing.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Hardly - the bloke was too cowardly to face voters in 2013. Given Windsor turned his back on them by supporting the failed Gillard government, no doubt there's many looking to give him their own personal verdict at the ballot box.
author: TheJediMaster

text: 20 years since Howard, almost makes you want to cry. Reminds us of prosperity, surpluses, national pride, the Sydney Olympics and common sense government. It sure came to a screeching halt in 2007.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Howard had plenty to say this morning, including noting how out of touch a certain LOTO is with middle Australia, using the safe schools issue as a prime example. It's hard to argue.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Car industry subsidies - Ford and Mitsubishi had announced their exits during Gillard's term. There was no point throwing more money at it. If the unions had agreed to negotiate there may have been a different outcome. It's a shame but our high wage costs mean we can't compete any more in mass market manufacturing.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Most of it is automated these days. But let's not mince words - the main reason car subsidies existed - still do right now - is to keep union workers employed. And the unions are so stupid that when even the Toyota workers asked to renegotiate their pay deal to save their jobs, the union sold them out.
author: TheJediMaster

text: I dare say Clive and i had the same people as lecturers and tutors, albeit a few years apart. Notice that you haven't mentioned any of your economic credentials ....
author: TheJediMaster

text: Each car worker was costing we taxpayers $50,000 each in government support. Between the tax received and any welfare paid, we are still better off, and that assumes they don't find jobs, which many will.
author: TheJediMaster

text: There was a bloke called Henry who i did a bit of work for. Fraser wasn't there - he's a newbie. Either way, when you make such a stupid statement as "errant claims" about a subject of which you know little, it shows a pretty closed mind.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Had a quick squiz at your links. But given they didn't even bother to acknowledge the original source of the $600 billion figure - and simply tried to peg it on Hunt and Murdoch (how dreary).
author: TheJediMaster

text: Shorten released his krazy RET policy without so much as a costing. Until he does tell us how much Labor expects the budget impact of this stupid policy to be, they haven't got a leg to stand on in terms of refuting other costing predictions.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Are you saying that you can't distinguish between a policy being properly and fully costed, and in the absence of that using Labor own numbers to propose a cost to their policy ? Think a little more broadly maybe.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The funny part of this article is nobody will ever be able to prove Abbott wrong - he may well have won the election in his own right this year.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But yes i'm loving this weeks debate - apparently according to the lefties we have no spending problem. But as soon as Malcolm commits to the Defence White Paper recommendations (thanks Abbott), all of a sudden we do have a spending problem. Hilarious.
author: TheJediMaster

text: How do you make up rubbish like that - "doubled the debt" ? Can you point us to the pages in Treasury documents to support that dribble ? (hint: no)
author: TheJediMaster

text: As for the budget - i agree, Abbott left the budget in the same poor shape that he inherited from RGR - tens of billions in deficit. He did at least try to fix it - and couldn't, largely due the the dopey clowns on the cross benches, and Labor of course, who remain in complete denial about their 2007-13 performance.
author: TheJediMaster

text: What about it ? A little blip almost a decade ago, which Rudd used as an excuse - in the middle of a mining boom - to launch the biggest spending spree in Australian history. Added 36% to spending in four short years.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Abbott won't go down as a great PM, but he did try to stop the bleeding. The age of entitlement is so entrenched it seems - most of us know that the budget needs fixing, but nobody is prepared to open their own wallets to pay for it.
author: TheJediMaster

text: After the fiscal wreckage of the Rudd and Gillard years, history will be kind to Abbott in comparison. Whilst ultimately unsuccessful, at least he had a go at fixing the mess.
author: TheJediMaster
