text: Turnbull looks more interested in being popular, which doesn't necessarily bode well for making any dints in the deficit any time soon. Let's hope the more fiscally sensible members of the Coalition keep the pressure on for the spending cuts that were ultimately denied to Abbott.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The only lie around the 2014 budget was about no new taxes. And given they hit the rich only, does that mean you're opposed to tax hikes for the rich ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yes Hawke is the greatest living Labor Prime Minister - about the only competent one. But even he never achieved Howard's longevity, and was rolled in the standard Labor way - sacked by his own people.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Fully agree with Abbott - once the election campaign started people would be looking at Labor and their plans for another spending spree, another carbon tax, more RET. They would have seen RGR mark 2 and promptly re-elected Abbott.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Labor's "policies" are mostly the discredited Gillard-era ones - Gonski, a new carbon tax, no changes to IR, hardly anything inspiring. Funny how the big headline is for a revenue measure that won't even pay one quarter of the interest bill they left behind.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It could be a cracker of an election year - there's threats of double dissolutions and Senate reform. With recalcitrant independents holding balance of power in the Senate, maybe the answer is both.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Banks lend money, inter alia. Coal generates more than half our domestic energy. Why on earth wouldn't banks invest in mining projects - just because a few greenies start bandying around the word "ethical" and think they have some proprietary ownership of it ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: That depends on your reference point. For most people the nuclear family has been something we've been involved in at some point. Parents separate, life changes, but it's a starting place.
author: TheJediMaster

text: We've been hearing for years how we've got a housing bubble, and it's about to burst. Strangely housing just keeps powering on. If you think that's due to "double entry accounting", perhaps you missed the capitalism part of the economics course.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yeah renewables are going so well that they might even reach 15% of global energy production in the next 25 years, and will never provide baseload. Real strategic outlook right there.
author: TheJediMaster

text: No doubt SSM will happen. But the results of a plebiscite will be interesting. People seem to think it will be an overwhelming yes - and it may. But if it isn't 50%, wonder what the Coalition party room would do then.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Abbott's woes have come from policy issues - mainly that he couldn't get the budget fixed. He's never been popular - even if he had an affair most voters would have yawned.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Well that's a relief Daisy, guess you don't work for the member for Sydney. In her office posters of Tony in speedos were pretty popular. Almost seems appropriate on Mardi Gras night !
author: TheJediMaster

text: Mano - CFW told Abbott there was a perception about the relationship with Credlin. She didn't accuse him of having one. Not sure if you can spot the difference there, but let's give you the benefit of the doubt.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But if you're thing here is to claim Abbott was or is having an affair with Credlin, might i suggest the onus is there to provide a bit of solid evidence. Do you have any ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Ah yes, how silly of me. You lefties all seem to sprout the same stuff, it's hard to tell the difference. Although Schlomo does seem a little more across the issues.
author: TheJediMaster

text: As for the snowfields, yes they spent a couple of days skiing, but they spent their nights in separate lodgings. Maybe you're suggesting a quick lunchtime rendezvous up at Eagle Nest or Kareela Hutte ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Savva wants to sell a book, good luck to her. She's come out with a new story, but it doesn't have much credibility. Don't forget Abbott had ditched CF-W as a Minister.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But Abbott seems holds a fascination that people can't let go of. From sculling a beer to eating an onion to making any political statement, pages of journalistic analysis follow in the progressive press. It's bizarre to watch.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Progressive media fascination with Tony Abbott continues unabated. Hardly a day goes by without a microscopic focus on any utterance, defence of his government or comment on the state of the current one.
author: TheJediMaster

text: More curious to know why Shorten has put expensive climate change policies on the table when they were roundly rejected just three years ago. On top of the other taxes.
author: TheJediMaster

text: With Turnbull announcing last week that defence spending will be restored to sensible levels, the Coalition are likely more than happy to have any defence related debate. Under RGR, defence was treated similarly to the way Chamberlain dealt with Hitler, and we know how that worked out.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Oh wait on .... you're actually trying to have a go at Abbott .... the guy who's restored border security, defence spending, commissioned white papers, and is treated defence seriously again. Oh i see - the Secretary and Mr Abbott disagree. Careful, a debate might break out, and we might finish up discussing both sides of the issue. Imagine that.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Dunno about exceeding judging by the sorry scoreboard, both sides have been shockers in the last decade. But yes Bill's safe leading up to the election. Wonder if Rudd's rules weren't implemented ....
author: TheJediMaster

text: The survey suggests the ALP vote is now being adversely affected by Mr Shorten's plans to reduce generous superannuation tax breaks for the wealthy, and to limit the scope of negative gearing tax breaks on investment properties by restricting it to new investment housing exclusively, and halving the capital gains tax concession on them.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The last time an ALP leader was safe within six months of an election was probably Beazley in 2001. Since then there's regularly been leadership changes before an election. Noteworthy.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Grumpy - the GFC was a minor blip in Australia, mainly due to the mining boom being in full swing at the time, zero debt, a budget surplus, strong growth and yes, Swan did what all year 10's are taught - if faced with a recession, stimulate.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But of course the $50 billion "temporary stimulus" turned into an additional $100 billion of recurrent spending annually, and $300 billion i debt. And here we are, eight years later, still paying for his recklessness. A wrecker of historic proportions.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Shorten has had plenty to say on running the country, much like he did during Rudd and Gillard's rampage. Sadly, not much of it is well informed or even common sense.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Ha ha - Abbott only has two budgets to be judged on, and his spending has never reached the RGR epidemic proportions. And he inherited 25.7% spending. Good try though.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But right now he wants to blow out spending again on education, climate change, health, without a single reduction proposed. Get back to us later Bill once you've worked out the easiest way to fix the budget.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The Xenophon proposal looks sensible and would help restore the voter's faith - give it a go. Both major parties are as bad as each other and it hasn't gone down well, whether it's helicopters, weddings, Tour de France soiree's, fact finding tours etc.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Speaking of old travel rorts - a moderately humorous story for those who've followed politics for a few years. Back at Xmas time i was up at Mount Nelson in Hobart - which overlooks the delightfully named Opossum Bay. As it turned out who were we parked next to at the time - none other than former Tasmanian Senator Nick Sherry. A quick chat and we were both on our way, one of us with a wry chuckle.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Yep, do all of those. But you're sprouting on about rejecting genuine science, lobbyists etc without any substantiation. Now that's - to use your words - some "personally-held beliefs getting in the way"
author: TheJediMaster

text: Windsor's motivation is a perfectly valid question. I'm not sure he's got the ticker to sit idly in the House of Reps with a conservative government in power. And it's unlikely he's banking on Billy S to win government.
author: TheJediMaster

text: There was another one wasn't there .... something about 97% of scientists claiming something like the science is settled ? Big call in a discipline where the only constant is change.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Might be more a case of money not growing on trees. Gonski and the NBN are sad fiscal jokes. In fact all Gonski represents is more spending. Nothing about quality of education, just more money for unions. So why would Windsor think he's on a winner with that ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Don't break your keyboard - all I asked was why. Of course he's entitled to, but is his motivation pure, or is he just doing it because of anger, malice and revenge ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Why is Windsor really doing this ? It's not to represent the voters of New England. He didn't represent them in 2010, when he supported the socialist Gillard government over the conservatives. And he didn't represent their wishes when he signed off on the carbon tax, so unloved by the NE voters.
author: TheJediMaster

text: He's unlikely to be in a position to influence the government nor to push unpopular private members bills, so why's he doing it - ego, to be a wrecker, masochism ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: On what basis ? Her only two achievements were the child abuse Royal Commission and the carbon tax (the one she said wouldn't introduce), the latter being an economic wrecker.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It may have felt like good government to you Rhonda, but to many of us it was three years of chaos and mayhem. Carbon taxes, mining taxes, media clampdowns, Malaysia solutions, porous borders, McTernan, red underpants - what a mess.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The revolving door of Prime Minister started in 2010. To be fair to Gillard her successors have all created their own messes, but after Rudd was marched for no real reason surely you'd agree the role was cheapened.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Windsor's represented the electorate for a decade so must be taken seriously. You'd reckon it's his last tilt - with a three year interruption - so he's going to give it everything.
author: TheJediMaster

text: We can debate the Abbott years 'til the cows come home but one thing's for certain - it won't be through the discredited rantings of Savva. This week she's successfully been able to unite government members, Labor figures, political commentators and even other book publishers to ridicule the flimsy attempt at political journalism.
author: TheJediMaster

text: This is Swannie's article so why don't we ask him - spending increased $100 billion bucks (36%) in just 4 years under your stewardship, which parts would you cut now ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Don't forget Swannie had a full union contingent cheering for him too. If he was trying to work with employers, the oddly named fair work act was a poor offering.
author: TheJediMaster

text: But that was all known. Savva's nasty little piece made silly personal accusations e.g the affair, it went too far. It's pretty much been written off already, and she won't ever regain the trust of government members. Stupid stuff.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The ABC took Bowen's very rubbery PEFO numbers, then added Hockeys more realistic MYEFO numbers - when the new government hadn't made any major decisions - and tried to pass it off as factual. Remember the Bowen numbers claimed Labor would return to surplus in 2016-17, a laughable suggestion.
author: TheJediMaster

text: It's hardly a surprise but 7.30 are running hard on this story tonight. Despite all the supposed "sources" for the Savva book, the best protagonist they could offer is John Hewson. Quite funny.
author: TheJediMaster

text: All members except the PM have a mandate ? Wow that's some theory. So you don't think Abbott had a mandate to stop the boats, or axe the carbon tax ?
author: TheJediMaster

text: Looks like Abbott is relishing the opportunity to defend his legacy. He wasn't able to dint the RGR deficit much - a little bit at least - but there were several other good deliverables as he points out.
author: TheJediMaster

text: You'd think a journo might be interested in a few more facts and a bit of substantiation. This is probably the end of the road for Savva as a respected journalist.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The funny part of course is we're been yelled at for so long - "the science is settled". And here we are in the middle of a barney about the science. Doesn't sound so settled.
author: TheJediMaster

text: What evidence is there for claiming that inequity is rising ? We've got high tax rates at higher incomes, compared to the rest of the world, which we should be looking to reduce.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Im not aware of the case. If what youve said is accurate, I certainly support protests and direct actions but I think actually damaging an office is not advisable but I would check up on what the facts are.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Year on year that may be true, but over the space of a decade a government should not be building national debt, to be bequeathed to the kids, who didn't ask for it anyway.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Labor busted the budget using the flimsy excuse of the GFC to add $100 billion annually to spending. The Coalition are going to have to fix it, although they better get cracking. The sooner we start talking about spending cuts again, the better. Turnbull needs to take a punt.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Indicate to your students that you are talking aboutgender and not sex by asking them to considerwhat makes them female or male. Most studentswill mention their genitals. Extend the discussion byasking students what it would mean in terms of theirgender if they were to lose that part of themselves.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Children are even asked to imagine losing their genitalia, in a lesson on transgender experiences. Indicate to your students that you are talking about gender and not sex by asking them to consider what makes them female or male, the teaching manual says. Most students will mention their genitalia. Extend the discussion by asking students what it would mean in terms of their gender if they were to lose that part of themselves.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Humanity - spare me. I'm far more concerned for the 99.99% of kids who through this stupidity are told they shouldn't think they're a boy or a girl. It's pure lefty victimology, and it's quite welcome to bugger off.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Mainly the state premiers, with a little help from Chifley. But as with any infrastructure project, it needed a plan, a methodical approach, resourcing and basic hard work to get delivered. And what a great job Menzies et al did.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Full employment - given Bill represents the Labor party - it's a little odd that we need to be reminded. Oddly enough, the Coalition remain committed to full employment too.
author: TheJediMaster

text: As for Chifley - well good thing Menzies was around to really get the place going after WW2. No doubt Bill will try and feed us the "light on the hill" line, but we all know who really got Australia powering ahead by delivering schemes like the Snowy.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Labor will help level the playing field for first home buyers competing with investors and we will put the great Australian dream back within the reach of the working and middle-class Australians who have been priced out of the housing market for too long.
author: TheJediMaster

text: We have to be clear about this, rebutted Opposition Leader Bill Shorten. The Opposition have outlined a plan which will see the price of houses go down. We will see a downturn in the price of housing. Its as simple as that.
author: TheJediMaster

text: 16:24 - Labor look all at sea again regarding house prices. Will they go up, will they go down under the negative gearing proposal ? Bowen doesn't know, Bill doesn't know.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The survey suggests the ALP vote is now being adversely affected by Mr Shorten's plans to reduce generous superannuation tax breaks for the wealthy, and to limit the scope of negative gearing tax breaks on investment properties by restricting it to new investment housing exclusively, and halving the capital gains tax concession on them.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Good to see all that excitement Katharine. Yes a nice poll to greet the week for Turnbull, suggesting the Coalition is close to the 2013 election levels, but the real test remains the budget.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Fully agree with the poll - the budget needs to get back to surplus as soon as possible. And the best way to do that is spending cuts, including education and welfare.
author: TheJediMaster

text: On the ABCC, Shorten's going to have to do better than the monotonous "Labor is against corruption", because in six months he's not lifted a finger to back that up.
author: TheJediMaster

text: The problem is that the personalities are rejecting the mandate the government has to reign in the unions. Even today the likes of Madigan and Lazarus have thumbed their nose at Turnbull. There's every chance they'll pay dearly for it.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Will the DD threat work ? We'll know by the end of April - if the independents don't play ball, most of them will be gone in the double dissolution.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Good decision by the government to review and redesign the program. If the aim is anti-bullying, then introduce an anti-bulling program, not one that forces kids to imagine life without parts of their anatomy.
author: TheJediMaster

text: You got a few choice, direct quotes above. Feel free to refute them. Flannery became a joke years ago, except to those who worship at the shrine of climate science.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Shone ? The bloke is a walking train wreck in parliamentary terms. Who could ever forget the Mike Willesee interview where Ricky asked for a new start. Got voted in on 1,500 votes.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Half your luck, you'll have a few hundred friends too most likely. Ricky is the poster boy for why the system needs changing - a real rabbit in the headlights, completely out of place in parliament.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Of all the independent Senators amongst the ranks of the unrepresentative mob, Day and Leyonhjelm have been the most sensible and pragmatic, along with Xenophon. Hope their challenge fails but they get themselves re-elected regardless.
author: TheJediMaster

text: On the other hand the likes of Lambie and Lazarus have been nothing short of an embarrassment, without a double dissolution we'll have to put up with them for another four years. Cringeworthy stuff.
author: TheJediMaster

text: Some people will be happy with a day of battery power when it is cloudy in the middle of winter, and then they will use candles. Others want to never run out of power and will wants 2 weeks of power reserve, but they will pay dearly for the batteries, and they are prepared to pay.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Once it is a grid based system there is no personal responsibility. People will use the power and complain when the batteries run out. So more and more batteries will be put in and the electricity prices will rise.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: I don't think anyone would complain about a solar PV farm next to them, unlike wind turbines. But base load is the problem. And if you are going to have batteries, that is better managed at each consumers premises than trying to have enormous grid based batteries.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: But the politicians should be convincing the public of why they want to sign such a treaty, and spell out in detail, not motherhood statements, exactly what the benefits are to Australians. The benefits should be quantified and backup up with evidence.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: I would hate it if I bought my idyllic country home and then had an industrial complex of grotesque 110 metre high rotating monstrosities stuck around my house.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Also if you look at any nation that has significantly better emissions and a similar lifestyle, they all have large amounts of some form of low CO2 power like nuclear, hydro or geothermal.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: As for being drawn into whether it had ever happened, he refused. Fair enough, he probably cannot answer for others as he has only had this ministry a short time.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Company directors only have a duty to the shareholders that elected them. The company does not have any legal interests other than the shareholders interest. The correct term is corporations law
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: That is the silliest thing I have heard today. Corporates have no duty to be advocates for sections of the public. Other wise if the didn't they would be failing their duty? Are Hungry Jacks and Subway failing their public duty?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: How about McD gets back to making burgers, and the 4 banks get back to trying to work out how to reduce our fees, and let the voters decide the government direction and policy?.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Umm we are Australia, not Thailand or Malaysia. If you want to have a conversation about it, I suggest you take a trip over there and discuss it with them.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: All the refugees want to live in Sydney and Melbourne. It doesn't matter how much uninhabited desert we have, no one, not even a refugee wants to live there. So forget that idea.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Nah they were from Sri Lanka. Not refugees. Economic migrants. No reason in 2015 to be leaving Sri Lanka other than for economic reasons. Even the UN is repatriating people to Sri Lanka.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Shorten said those with significant assets should not get a pension. So the Libs are cutting out higher asset people from getting the pension and at the same time boosting the pension for those with modest assets.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: The whole ISIS issue is because Obama prematurely and pig-headedly removed all the troops that were ensuring security and safety in the region. He was warned but did it anyway, just to appease pressure groups.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Your statement is not relevant in this case because they were not refugees, they were not even asylum seekers (a difference in case you didn't know), they were merely economic migrants from Sri Lanka. There is no reason in 2015 to be leaving Sri Lanka, even the UN can attest to that.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: That is a myth. The reality is that 85% are still on welfare 5 years later, as you would expect. We already don't have enough jobs for everyone in Australia. More people will just be on welfare, and with poor English, no skills, and no experience, of course it will be the asylum seekers on the welfare.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: It is a neo-Marxist philosophy of open borders to set up a one world government all under the control of the UN and reporting to Moscow. There is much worse that the loony left want but don't put in print these days as it will frighten the natives.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: They also believe that land shouldn't be owned by individuals, and we should all be living in tiny little apartments so there is no suburban sprawl, leaving most of Australia for the animals and Aboriginal ownership. Yes Aboriginals are allowed to own land, but no one else. No cars, just public transport.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: The Lefties invented group-think. Comes from them being a collective, where you have to fit in, and dissenting views indicate you might not be one of them. So independent thought becomes a forgotten skill. Just like a paddock of sheep.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Not Dutton but the credit needs to go to Morrison. Going by Labor's death rate, there are probably 1000 to 2000 people alive today thanks to him stopping the boats.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: That's why you have the Senate. When 0.5% of the population wants to vote a particular way they have influence and will be listened to as can get a couple of people in.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: But I see right though your arguments. You are really wanting Aboriginals to have their own elections for their own members in parliament. Just forget it, it wont happen. That sort of discrimination by giving a minority a greater vote will always be rejected, and I will be one of the first to reject it.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: This isn't getting anywhere. You keep saying in vague terms that the electoral system is wrong. You say the boundaries are wrong and that it was done by white man, but what does that mean? What precisely is wrong? Do you have an example?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: You seem to be claiming the boundaries are gerrymandered. Do you have any evidence/examples as I find if difficult to believe in this day and age that it has gone unchallenged?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: To get an idea of how this would work in the grand scheme of things, for instance, how much are you personally prepared to pay to contribute to these historic wrongs you talk about?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: How will separating Australia into 2 groups in the Constitution lead to equality? The only thing that leads to equality is putting everyone in the same group, that is Australians.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: We agree to reduce import duty on goods (and destroy our own industry making those goods), if they agree to reduce import duty on farm products, so farmers can sell more product.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Wait until he appears in the Royal Commission. Though I expect he will answer everything with 'I cant recall', but that will just end his PM ambitions quicker as who wants a PM that cant remember?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Their messiah that rose from the ashes of Rudd and Gillard and who they expected to win in 2016 with the exact same failed policies from the previous term in government, is now starting to look like another failed ALP leader, just another Mark Latham.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: If Mark really wanted to achieve something, instead of a loose coalition with the Greens, he should arrange a full merger with the Greens, and bring their 2 constitutions together and create a united and democratic party not run by the union heavyweights.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Yes but who will pay to get on a boat knowing the crew will try and get more money from Australia and take them back where they started from?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: I am not racist, I want nearly all migration stopped. Only let in a restricted number of migrants of up to 25,000 per year of any nationality for family reunion that also meet the requirement of skills that are needed and a good prospect of supporting themselves and accumulating enough money in superannuation to support themselves in retirement. Australia is not a charity, our charitable money is via foreign aid.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: So all the unpopulated land is a moot point Refugees only want to live in Sydney and Melbourne and by world standards for comparable lifestyles they are very big cities. By all measures, without reducing lifestyle, Australia is full.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: It is not just the manufacturers that charge Australia more, but the distributors in Australia have added much higher margins by maneuvering themselves into a position where they can be much wealthier than their overseas counterparts on the back of lover sales volume then their counterparts. Just because you have a small business in Australia seems to mean a Mercedes and a weekender at Portsea.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: A classic example was photo film processing. We paid much more in Australia than overseas did. And we paid subsidies to Kodak. When digital cameras came in, Australia had the worlds most rapid uptake of digital cameras, not because of tech savvy, just because of being ripped for so many years.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Australia is a captive market. It is like buying a meat pie at the AFL Grand Final. Expect to pay far more than could possibly be justified just because you are trapped within.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: I find it strange that people are against being able to carry a concealed weapon, but they support the right to be out in public with a potentially dangerous dog.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: So didn't you a Prius is not green from cradle to grave, or did you know and didn't care and so used it as an example and perpetuating the myth?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Anyone with half a brain will know that the Prius was a long way down on the list of green cars when assessed from "cradle to grave" due to its very poor recyclability and enormously high energy costs to make it.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: It is the high cost of music that drives piracy. $2.11 for a song on iTunes!! If you bought a collection of 2000 songs, that is $4220 dollars!
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: As the Guardian reported last week, an Australian radiologist was stripped of his licence to practice in Australia. There was no court case. He can appeal if he thinks it was wrong.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: So citizenship can be treated the same. You get stripped of citizenship, but if you think you have been wrongly treated, you can come back and appeal to a court.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Good to see they can put aside their partisan politics and do what is in Australia's interest and what nearly all Australians want, regardless of the very vocal but tiny minority.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Gillard would be the most useless PM of modern times. She took Rudds 52% and reduced it to 50% in a matter of months, and over the next 3 years took the party to what would be the greatest arse caning at an election a sitting government has ever had. Luckily Rudd stepped in and saved her sorry arse from a very embarrassing defeat.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: At the last election the ALP were out-flanked on the right, that is why LNP won. Now they want to move more to the left and vacate more of the middle ground, leaving it up for grabs. Fine.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: It is the last week before the winter break when the knifings often happen, and Shorten is on political life-support. So this is not a good time for Plibersek to make outrageous comments in the media like this.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: No it exists here. You want me to say sorry and pay compensation for what my ancestors did a couple of hundred years ago. I wast even born yet, but you want me to be responsible. What is the difference?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: It is only a matter of time before Sharrouf's children are into some form of radicalization as they will consider their father to be a martyr and want to avenge his death.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: What I want is an administrative decision. Like the decision a minister has to let someone stay. Sure have the right of appeal, but don't need an unnecessary court case.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: You are off topic. This is not about poverty. This is about a government that cant control spending, with the youngest retirement age and highest pensions as a percentage of previous income in all of Europe.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: You make no distinction between those who died from being part of an offensive action, and those who are innocent victims. When is your would view going to grow up?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: So I say there is not much new technology in the car, and you submit what is car of the year awards as your counter argument. Really? Did it win because of more legroom and a bigger sunroof?So what are the technological break throughs? List please?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: So there is no way to get the price of the car down to the price mortals pay, even with high volumes. You cant make a Ferrari for $20k no matter how many you make.

text: That will work when very few people have batteries, but as soon as the numbers get higher it is a problem for the generation companies. It is not financial.

text: So they will include minimum kwh in a bill. Or your account will have load shedding where in a severe demand day you can only take 20% more than you average consumption or the smart meter cuts you off etc.

text: Then it's a pity qanda couldn't get Pol Pot or Joseph Kony on for you so you could hear what they are on about. Would you settle for Adrian Bailey?

text: The ABC needs to review its procedures as they have clearly failed by letting Mallah on the show to ask questions and get some publicity for his cause.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: In the real world you have limitations, and the limitations are cost and time. Taking unproven people who have never been a pilot, you don't know how they will go at it. Will be a higher success rate with those who are already a pilot.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Probably why Australia has such a high safety record. eg Landing the crippled A380 QF 32 in Singapore, and landing QF1020 and QF1949 which both landed safely with the auto throttle problem while others such as Turkish Airlines 1951 crashed.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: The key point with the list is that it is only based on the last 30 years, and for a small airline it could be unsafe and taking risks, but statistically its number has not come up.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Air NZ has come from the depths of the list to No 1 because its big crash of controlled flying into the side of a mountain in Antarctica has just fallen out of the 30 year period.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: In that part of the world they don't start out recreationally flying Cessna and progress up. They get taken off the street and into commercial or military flight school. Many have never flown a plane without fly by wire and auto pilot.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: If you notice there are no structures in the grounds that can act as protection. I am sure a few gazebos in the yards would have come in handy in the recent riots.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: I am not for more compassion as I think we are being taken for a ride with people claiming refugee just because they want to move to a western country. I want more reality. Like when asylum seekers are granted PR and then go back home for a holiday. Time for Australia to wake up that we are being conned.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: The issue is, if Shorten doesn't announce where he stands on boats well in advance of the election, and I mean announce it now, then come the election whatever he announces at the 11th hour will not be believed.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Where he stands needs to be announced now, and the public want to hear the rest of Labor standing behind that for the test of time, then they will believe it.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: There is also the issue of working out the tax if it is on earnings above $75k. How does a fund do that, as they don't know what other super you have? What if you have 3 funds? What if you have 2 funds you have forgotten about many years ago?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Huh swashbuckling? But Swan should have taken a sword and slashed his spending. The Libs would have supported it. The Libs keep trying to do it now but Labor blocks it.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Most of the budget problem is from spending. The next problem area is corporate taxation with dodgy profit shifting offshore, and also when they off-shore their work then less income tax is collected in Australia. These are the real problem areas.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: There is no tax free money going into super, if you haven't paid tax on it the super fund pays 15%, or you can put in money after you have paid tax on it. There is no way around it.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: It is strictly limited how much you can put into super as tax free money as $25k for under 50 yo and $35k above that, and then the fund pays tax on it.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: So these days you really cant get a big super fund because of the limit on contributions. Anyone with a big super fund is usually because they have taken high risk investments that have paid off, when most people have lost their money in high risk investments.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Which get to the next point of the reason for super. It was not only to provide retirement benefits but to provide a national source of funds for investment in Australia. The bulk of super funds is in Australian shares. If they tax the big returns which are usually from risky speculative investments, then those investments will not me made. Funds will just invest in bank shares instead. For Australia's benefit someone has to invest in the riskier investments.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: If super is taxed on earnings above $75k, many average income people will pay it, because in super you make very small profits most years, and then you catch up with a boomer year. Considering most years the returns are about 2.5%, then you get a boomer year of 12%. So to never pay tax you can't have more than $625k in super, which is about the average amount people have in their super when they retire.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Sharks have been protected for a number of years now and so there are plentiful large sharks but insufficient fish due to fishing. Hungry sharks are seeking alternative food ie human.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: If they can only afford a cheap run down house, and you want cheap run down houses banned, have you given the slightest thought to where they will live? Or don't you care?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: So you think I should be able to buy the car off you for $100 even though I know it is stuffed, and then you should be made to fix it at your cost?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Mouldy houses are probably 1 in 500 I would guess. Removing 1 in 500 from the market is not going t affect the overall prices of the market, it will just remove the very cheap houses.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: They didn't do what they are legally required to do. And that is to apply to VCAT or whatever to break the lease. It is in the tenants hand book.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: So you go to VCAT and the landlord say the mould cant be fixed, or the tenant is not opening the windows often enough, and you so are allowed to break the lease without penalty.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Any sane person would renovate it and turn it into a freshly renovated place which people pay are willing to pay a lot of rent for. Everyone likes newly renovated.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: I will give a simple example. Say the migrant was coming from Sicily, then profile would alert possible Mafia member. The migration application then goes through an intensive investigation to see if there is evidence they are not mafia, and the onus is on the person to provide the requested information.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: You are being distracted. Look at what the really serious offence is, and that is terrorism. A little white lie is not in the same category as Monis who wanted to and did kill people.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: As I said earlier, the Australian Police forces have sophisticated methods and data for profiling the risk of offending. If these methods and data had been used for immigration, then probably Monis would not have been able to get into Australia in the first place. It is about making Australia as safe as it can be.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: You mean lies like "no carbon tax under a government I lead" and promises for 5 years in a row that the budget would be in surplus, but all were massive deficits?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: So with any downturn, the reduction of high growth will affect the share price a lot, and with many people wanting to reduce their gearing and with margin call the price will drop more.

text: The Social Left faction are now the dominant force in the ALP and will move policy further to the left. and they will not support boat turnbacks, instead they want to welcome the asylum seekers with open arms and encourage many more to make the sea voyage.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Shorten knows this is an election killer, so he is very non-committal in front of the cameras, but he can only fob off the questions for so long. People are figuring out where he stands by what he doesn't say.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Why so many. Sure it is a great impost for most people to be on a jury, but also being called is an impost. Peoples lives are put on hold while they wait to find out if they are to be on the jury or not. Surely there is a better way.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: As she has paid the penalty, I am expecting Finance are probably going to say the matter has been corrected, she has been penalised, and the matter has finalised according to the rules. End of story.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: The difference is that Slipper lied on the cab charges to try and cover it up. There was no question that he thought it was acceptable. There was no grey area.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: With Bishop we don't know because the information is not out yet. We don't know what she said on the form and what the circumstances are. There appears to be no lying or trying to cover it up.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Even if the new Top Gear has only half the viewers, it is still a success. According to CBS's 60 Minutes, Top Gear's unique storytelling method and irreverent attitude helped the show generate 350 million viewers a week worldwide, as well as a place in the Guinness Book of World Records as the most-watched factual TV program.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: It's important that it puts inspections in place. Inspections are not always designed to catch you red-handed but rather to elicit a response about what it is that you are up to. The threshold for pain is so high that you don't want to break the rules, and I think this puts that in place while also making it extremely difficult to cheat.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: But if you consider that it is flow forming machines are how you make centrifuges. If you have one stashed away out in the middle of the desert in a facility, we would have no idea. In the agreement, they have to account for all of their flow forming machines, give us a list of where they are, and then put them under monitoring. The counter to that is they just won't tell us, they won't declare everything. That's to be expected, so don't trust that.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: I think you are right. If it was a restore they would not keep the weather shield on the drivers door. No self respecting restorer would have that.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: The satellite can determine the position of your EPIRB to within 5km. The coded message identifies the exact vessel to which the EPIRB is registered. This information allows the rescue services to eliminate false alerts and launch an appropriate rescue.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: GPS-enabled EPIRBs have a built-in transmitter which will typically alert the rescue services within 3 minutes and to a positional accuracy of +/- 50 metres (updated every 20 minutes) given a clear view skywards.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Some EPIRBs also have a secondary distress transmitter. This transmits on 121.5 MHz and is used for "homing" purposes. When the rescue services get close, this allows them to direction find on the signal. Some EPIRBs also have a high brightness LED flashing light that aids final visual location.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Manual activation brackets will cover the water sensors, preventing them from activating the EPIRB if, for example, a wave breaks over the boat, and keeping it in a handy location should you need to access it quickly.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Auto Float-free housings, automatically deploy the EPIRB when submerged to a depth lower than 2 - 4 metres in the sea. They work by means of a Hydrostatic Release Unit which cuts the EPIRB free from its housing, causing it to activate. The EPIRB can also be removed from the auto housing to be activated manually.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: With being a little less lazy, people can get information and make better quality decisions. But like you say, it is heavily influenced by past experience, but it is over used.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Intuition is heavily promoted in management courses as a legitimate decision making process, like a black art. Unfortunately many take that to mean a licence to not bother obtaining readily available information before making a decision.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: At the G20 and at Lima, it was agreed by all member states that China and India could increase their emissions, and in China's case that was to increase emissions until 2030. And increased emissions essentially means one thing, more coal.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: So the member states cant agree China and India can have more coal, and then not let them buy it.However the coal mines should not be at the expense of prime agriculture land.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Someone on the highest tax rate pays 49 cents in the dollar, and this will be 15 cents on the remainder. A total of 56.7 cents in the dollar.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: You are trying to argue the divide up of states and Feds. If you want Feds to take on more state responsibilities, the Feds will need more of the funding.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: But the PoM should be shutting down and moving to Hastings as this will provide lots of housing near the city and get trucks off the roads and ease congestion.

text: But he doesn't want to do this because all the port workers are concentrate on the western side of Melbourne vote ALP and makes them safe seats. If they were dispersed further afield as would happen with a port relocation, he would lose safe seats.

text: I agree. HFC is still FTTN with a coax cable into the home. HFC already runs past 40 % of homes. HFC runs fibre to the node and coax from the node, that is why it is called hybrid.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: For the last 3 years I have had HFC with 100 MBit down but only 2.5MBit up. The 2.5 is to allow more on a single node and also to stop servers.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: To get faster up speed they need to reduce the 600 or so they have on a node so more resources are allocated to up. Means running the fibre deeper into the network with more nodes.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Which is all the debate is really about, how deep into the network to run the fibre, because once the network is in your house and computers it is back to copper anyway. No such thing as a computer without copper.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: To provide FTTP will increase the base price of all NBN internet speeds, so people will spend about the same, but will get a slower plan for the same money. So FTTP is counter productive.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: But now there is a structure whereby those who want it can get it. In 10 years time there may be a use for extra speed, and those who have that use can pay for it.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: People talk about reliability of copper, and with FTTN the copper reliability should be excellent because it is only a short run to the node, not a long run back to the exchange.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: I expect you will come to the conclusion that there is nothing you can use a faster connection for, and the money will be a waste. But by all means, spend your money and find out.
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: And how much do you think FTTP would cost, with the added expense of having to run cable into every single home, instead of just running the cable to the node at the end of the street?
author: InfinityAndBeyond

text: Pretty transparent what Plibersek is trying to do. She is trying to get gender issues festering away so that gender will be a factor in the selection of Shortens replacement.

text: A re-think indeed. The post WW2 to early 1980s attempt at bringing multiculturalism to Australia was very successful, even if it may have been accidental. This multicultural schooling that I am advocating was essentially a product of socio-economic demographics rather than careful planning. Since the 1980s. however, a social policy re-think has led to a greater 'enclave-isation' by allowing access to schools that are both monocultural and religious. The students at such schools don't have a multicultural experience, but are forced to navigate a multicultural society upon early adulthood.
author: Applaudanum

text: Robert Borger, presumably, went to the same sort school as other children in his family's socio-econmic demographic. There, he would have mixed with children who, despite being of a different cultural background, were just like him. There would have been kids who were good at school, good at sport, good at socialising, and good at whatever else kids tend to be good at. This experience would have set up the young Robert for a future of agreeable social interactions with fellow citizens on the basis of a shared upbringing.
author: Applaudanum

text: Multiculturalism works in the same way, yet the children need to attend multicultural schools rather than schools that are both monocultural and religious. When children attend multicultural schools, they encounter each other on their own level. Cultural background matters less than being good at sport, good at maths, good at jokes, good at whatever else. Young Antonio, for example, realises that John, Con, Tran, Piotr, and Gurwinder are just like him. Sure, their parents might look different, they might eat different foods, visit odd churches and have to go to another school on the weekend, but all that doesn't matter when in comes to class time or the schoolyard shenanigans.
author: Applaudanum

text: Immigration of the last 30 years however, hasn't worked exactly like that just described, unfortunately. By allowing children to attend schools that are monocultural and religious, those children are prevented from having the full multicultural experience. Such children get the experiance that Iqbal, Mohammad and Ahmed are good kids just like them, good at maths, good at sports, good at jokes etc. They just don't know that Antonio, John, Con, Tran, Piotr and Gurwinder are just like them as well.

text: If Cosslett really wants us to believe that victims shouldn't be held responsible for these types of assaults (and they shouldn't), then why does she go out of her way to convince us that a mere warning or tut-tutting, even clumsily worded warnings and tut-tuttings from celebrities) about risky and dangerous behaviours automatically absolves the perpetrator from committing a crime? Can't thoughtful members of our society keep two opinions on a topic in their head at once? I am fully capable of understanding that a warning or tut-tutting about a risky or dangerous behaviour does not mean that criminals then get a free pass to do what they like. The two ideas are, clearly, not mutually exclusive.
author: Applaudanum

text: Cossletts' contribution here today risks adding to, or confirming, the view that she is arguing against (that victims are responsible if they don't heed a warning). By being angry at Hynde's warnings, Cosslett is demonstrating that the warnings do indeed give criminals a free pass. If the surrounding culture picks up on such an idea and allows it to gain traction, then judges, juries and the rest of the law enforcement system, will gradually come around to that way of thinking. The argument will become the norm (why didn't you heed the warnings? Tough!), rather than regarding it as something only sociopaths would say.
author: Applaudanum

text: Is the expression of your outrage really worth the risk of allowing a clearly sociopathic sentiment to take hold in the community? Wouldn't it be better to keep the warnings as well as the criminal blaming? I can do that. Why can't you?
author: Applaudanum

text: We can all empathise and recognise the feelings that come with being surrounded by people who are like us in many ways. Yet many of us don't believe that race is going to be the key characteristic that makes people similar (or dis-similar) to ourselves. Heck! Even someone that has the same race, age, gender, sexuality, socio-economic status, education level and at least 5 shared entertainment interests, isn't even a guarantee that I'm going to be comfortable with that person.
author: Applaudanum

text: Rather, it is about how people 'are', how they 'behave', what they say, and how they respond to various situations that makes us comfortable or uncomfortable. Such things can't be codified, quantified or described accurately with labels, which is why we don't get articles on them.
author: Applaudanum

text: Political dynamics, and political ideologies for that matter, are never sustainable in that sense. In all cases, they are eventually challenged by an outside/new influence that requires some form of change or mutation. How they respond to these challenges is down to the participants in the political process.
author: Applaudanum

text: I think 2 is the more accurate representation of what generally happens to female graduates. text: The 'someone or something must be behind it' hypothesis was born when early man formed his first tool. He look at it in his hand and thought, in his rudimentary way, 'I made this'. He looked around and saw all the things he didn't make, the trees, the mountains etc. and added 'but I didn't make that. Someone else must have made that. They must have been pretty big, powerful and smart. They must also have been a man, seeing as I'm a man and I made this tool.'

text: I wasn't asking because I wanted to know if I was part of the set. Yet you have confirmed my long-held suspicion that this is one of those phenomena that is best viewed from the 'outside' rather than the 'inside'.The markers of culture, traditionally, were available only to the economic elite, and a few chosen practitioners. As the products of popular culture and consumer capitalism begin to satisfy the needs of the economic elite, their own grasp of the cultural elite slips. Practitioners and administrators of the cultural elite need to entertain new markets, due to funding shortfalls. These new markets, the mix of different socioeconomic viewers and participants, brings with it a dulling of distinction.
author: Applaudanum

text: Is it the people who have the most money? Is it the people who live in the best areas? Is it the people who know which way is 'up' on a Rothko? Is it the people who work in culture industry?

text: Economic Liberalism:The ideological belief in organizing the economy on individualist lines, meaning that the greatest possible number of economic decisions are made by individuals and not by collective institutions or organizations. It includes a spectrum of different economic policies, such as freedom of movement, but it is always based on strong support for a market economy and private property in the means of production.
author: Applaudanum

text: White people *can't* understand what it feels like to be a black woman, no matter how well meaning they might be. For example, someone might be all of gen x, white, male, heterosexual, university educated, working class, doc marten wearing, Megadeth fan. But that doesn't automatically mean I'm going to understand the experiences of that person does it?

text: Whilst referring to the experience of friends and associates, that quote is only a self-diagnosis. It is quite common for people not to be aware of their tone of voice when talking about things they feel strongly about.

text: I was asking you if you were doing Satire, Lagasse. After all, you did finally come around to agreeing with me that you were resorting to gender based assumptions and then tried to claim for yourself a special commitment to facts.

text: I find that the "Richard quotes" are helpful in pointing out a problematic use of a word as used by those bring argued against, yet maintaining its presence in the argument for the purposes of clarification. In doing so, they demonstrate an awareness of the vague-ness inherent to particular expressions along with a thorough comprehension of the specific issues pertaining to the surrounding comment.

text: The comment histories of every poster on this board whom you identify as male and as having a word or two against the author? That's some dedication. text: You missed a couple of crucial words on your quote there. It wasn't an 'as good as stated report', but a multinational agreement to withhold the public release of any findings should the investigation point to the Ukraine (or EU) as being complicit.

text: Online political debaters often use the 'But they did it too' type of comment as a means to deflect attention away from the individual currently being discussed. It's an odd form of argument that suggests that an act or event is wrong, but only when talking about 'them', 'they', 'those' and 'you'. Whether it was wrong for 'we' or 'us' to do it doesn't matter because 'them!'. But this would be pretty familiar territory for anyone who dabbles in online commentary. What is truly remarkable here is that you actually try a variation of the form where 'But they  do it too'. Who says we can't be innovators?
author: Applaudanum

text: Exactly right. The term 'accident' implies that it 'could have happened to anyone' or 'I was just unlucky. In the wrong place at the wrong time'. If discussions of traffic collisions were instead centred around the concept of 'negligence' as a behaviour that is chosen as an alternative to 'diligence', there would be a gradual effect on the wider community.Negligence: It's not an accident.
author: Applaudanum

text: I'm saying that there are people who say that those who challenge gender equality are feminazis.You've got a spelling mistake here that has unintentionally pointed to a possible solution.People who challenge gender inequality are feminists.People who challenge gender equality are feminazis.

text: They were the words of our response to the commodification of teen angst and rebellion. Sure, in our mid teens, we might not have been able to roll the phrase 'commodification of teen angst and rebellion' off our tongues with ease but we could recognise the concept and observe it in action.

text: I am not making the comparison at all. I am trying to be practical regarding law enforcement after face coverings become permissible. I am commenting about the object and what it looks like and how that same object can be distorted away from the 1500 year cultural traditions of billions of people.

text: Exactly right, JDF. The function of communication was fulfilled. Anything else is a matter of class distinction.Do we really think that 'correctionistas' go about correcting the diction and spoken grammar of their friends and colleagues in public?

text: That's a simplistic reading of my post, WowSignal. It is noted that you didn't address any of the concerns presented, or try to answer the given example, but instead went for a wild interpretation of my post and then answered that interpretation yourself. Sure, I'll admit to fear being in there, but it is not fear of muslims. As you may have missed, or deliberately ignored, the people committing crimes in my above scenario aren't muslims. They are instead opportunistic westerners looking for the best way to achieve their ends. Covering their faces gives them (opportunistic westerners) that edge. Who is to say that the only people wanting to cover their faces are muslims? The niqab isn't a religious requirement, as claimed by the author and many advocates of the niqab. It is instead an expression of freedom. That means anyone and everyone can wear it, right?

text: By the same token, can my buddies and I get about town in the shopping districts and entertainment precincts wearing American Football padding, a roller derby helmet, an ice-hockey mask and carry a ceremonial baseball bat? After all, such accoutrements only express a personal freedom and a dedication to a sporty lifestyle. When the time comes that CCTV footage shows rampaging hooligans running around causing havoc wearing the exact same sorts of outfits, well that's got nothing to do with my buddies and I, does it?

text: I eat meat on good Friday does that mean I am not a Catholic? Such a view would indeed be ridiculous, which is why I said nothing of the sort.

text: Advocates for the Niqab can't seem to get their story straight. If wearing the garment is an expression of freedom, then the banning of it can't be 'islamophobic' because everyone will be denied access to this particular expression of freedom.The links between Islam and the Niqab are further eroded by the fact that 10s of millions of Muslim women get by without it everyday. Is anyone claiming that Niqab-less women are less devout than those that do wear the niqab?Lastly, seeing as so few would be affected by the ban, then there's minimal harm in retaining such a ban or maintaining the ban where civil requirements are typically performed without the garment.

text: Exactly right, Duke. One could always have gone to another cultural quagmire dedicated to of the power of collected capital that's surprisingly devoid of other punters on Grand Final Day. The NGV would have been a good one, but the cinema still operates, as does IKEA and Woolies.

text: Lancelot was talking about people selling up and making money from the difference between their purchase price and their selling price. Like I said, it doesn't happen unless one owns more than one property. The people you are talking about own more than one property.

text: Unless they have to buy somewhere else to live, at a price that has gone up as well. 'Like for like' at a high price is exactly the same as at a low price. The only people who can clean up and go on a spending binge are the people who have owned more than one property for some time. Oddly enough, these are generally the same people who can afford to go on a spending binge without selling a property or two.

text: 1.2 billion customers? Surely you mean 1.2 billion non-paying subscribers. Facebook's customers are another set of entities entirely. The subscribers are merely the 'product' that the customers pay to access. Facebook's genius is to design a 'space' that attracts more of this 'product' to itself, thus demonstrating to the paying customers how valuable access to the 'product' is. Another example is google. How much have you paid to use google today? If your answer is 'nothing' the you, sir or madam, are part of the 'product' for Google's paying customers.Who says we're not leading 'product-ive' lives?
author: Applaudanum

text: The only people who resemble bankers and speculators in this situation are the insurance people who are making a mint out of all the extra public liability insurance that now has to be factored into everyone's cost structure.

text: That's a fair comment, but the bigger picture of what, exactly? Social issues and current affairs perhaps. Certainly not the bigger issues of maths and grammar. Are you sure we haven't lost some of the capacity for both by watering down the detail in favour of discussion? The 18-19 year olds I've taught, generally speaking, have a poor approach to detail, and their grasp of bigger picture issues relies on regurgitated pronouncements of existing ideas that they a) regurgitate badly, and b) appear to not really understand but instead go though they what they think the motions are.

text: I think Spike Lee is saying that he (Tarantino) may not handle black characters with the insight, sensitivity and unique perspective that a black director might...I agree with this interpretation of Lee's general point, not that I agree with Lee's point itself. Note the use of the words 'may not' and 'might' (yes, I know Lee didn't say them himself). Note how they allow scope for the existence an individual who 'may' handle black characters with the insight, sensitivity and unique perspective that a black director 'might not' command. That would be a description of Tarantino, would it not?
author: Applaudanum

text: Do you mean the US jets that have been bombing ISIS for four years whilst seeing ISIS go from strength to strength? Oddly, they've got a free pass. They should stop now') and the pieces of the supposedly complex conflict start to come together.
author: Applaudanum

text: Astutely observed (see also David Moss' contribution above). It is one of the great tragic ironies of our post-Warholian epoch that his legacy has become distorted with so much misinformation and misunderstanding. Warhol's transgressive achievement called into question the concept of the gallery and museum that stood apart from the 'outside' culture. His call, which was also the achievement of Cage some ten years before him - but Cage did it on the quiet, was to take the gallery experience 'outside'. The current (post 60s) interpretation has been to turn this legacy of artistic transgression on its head and bring the 'outside' into the gallery experience. Thus the gallery retains its authority as the arbiter of status in the art-world whilst only content has been 'freed' and, ultimately, made impotent. Modern artists, despite their claims toward transgressive content remain subservient to the gallery space.
author: Applaudanum

text: Sorry, Dingbat. I was punning up on the phrase 'we're getting less wrong' in order to present my metonym of contemporary education.By the way, all those multiplication tables and spelling tests weren't just about maths and spelling. They were about improving the mind's capacity for memory and learning.
author: Applaudanum

Afterwards, you have to come up with some kind of positive commentary for what you've spent 3 hours avoiding to watch.

text: The Industry may use the label 'plus-size', but that doesn't mean the media has to use the term when writing for a wider readership (chortle alert!). Aren't such writers meant to be professionals? author: Applaudanum

text: Men indeed look for markers other than thinness. Yet it seems that a move towards thinness 'plays the percentages' (so to speak). Those other markers that men look for, were you to pick only one or two, are more specific and their appeal across the board is limited.As for being outdated, if mistaking a figure of speech for a literal event is what it takes to be 'up-to-the-minute', then I'll wear it my outdated-ness with pride.
author: Applaudanum

text: Thanks for the considered comment, MistaSyms, and I agree with what you say. The 'thin-o-matic', to my mind, comes about when women assess what the men are looking at approvingly, yet they don't see the same thing. Their focus is different. Thus they get a different interpretation of what men prefer, and thinness becomes a kind of distorted 'catch-all' for attractiveness. There are also other cultural identifiers in the mix that are not necessarily related to looking attractive to men. The cultural identifiers that come to mind here are those that fall under the 'not looking like you have to work for a living' type. These get brought into the mix of what women consider to be attractive, and I daresay thinness is part of the template.
author: Applaudanum

text: That talent show become the template for Hip Hop and 'RnB' music videos post-2004. That template will also be coming to a teenage dance eisteddfod near you any day now (unless it's already been).

text: It's easy to poke fun at people when we know for certain that AtL and BtL commentators won't get a documentary made about their AtL or BtL escapades. Neither will said non-existent documentary be revisited every so often for people to gloat online about how 'we've come so far'.

text: I really hope this is true, but it is claimed that infamous film-director John Waters once called Heavy Metal Parking Lot the 'scariest film ever made'. For me personally, I just had a sudden urge to become Glenn Tipton.

text: The only profit increases will be for retail and business landlords. If I was in their position and worked out that my business tenant was suddenly $500 a week better off, I'd sure as eggs put the price up. What are they going to do, move? Risk their current location and their regular clientele? Pay to get their business moved? This is a clear case of money being directed upwards from the worker to the capital elite. Where's the middle man? He's helping it along even though he won't see any of it.

text: The oddest thing in all this is that it's not just the worker being taken for a ride.What do you think the landlord who leases the premises to the business is going to do when they find out that the business will have $500 a week extra (or whatever the figure is depending on the size of the business) on hand? Put their rent up to match? You better believe it.

In other words, the body is secondary to 'me' being 'me'. The body is still here but it could be any body.

text: How do Greer's comments on this topic generate increased dangers and obstacles to transgender people? When you hear a provocative comment that changes (or reinforces) your view on something, do you rush out commit violence and indulge in harassment and intolerance of people or things described in that provocative comment? If you don't rush out on a spree of harrassment, violence and intolerance, why do you assume that others will?

text: Who can forget? You seem to have forgotten the very next sentence following the critique of Gillard's clothes where Greer said it didn't matter. You remember 'Get on with it. Who cares?' don't you?

text: People who complain about political correctness just want to go around calling people 'paki' or 'homo'. That's all there is to it. I see this type of comment more often on social justice issues. It does have a particular old world charm about it: 'She's a witch''No. I'm not a witch''She denied it. That means she is a witch!'
author: Applaudanum

text: Exactly right, BFG. The 'enforcement' of political correctness, as it plays out today, relies on the politically correct to assume the worst of the people they are attempting to correct. Assuming the worst of someone, who most likely has a very different set of experiences to the one doing the correcting, doesn't seem like a politically correct thing to do.
author: Applaudanum

text: I tend to agree DaveGee. Can I, for example, identify as another gender purely by 'thinking' it, or do I have to 'act' it out as well? If it's the former, then there doesn't seem to be any real change, but rather a change of awareness, which I could undertake in the blink of an eye. If it's the latter, then wouldn't acting out a presumed definition of femininity or masculinity be reinforcing more tightly defined gender boundaries?
author: Applaudanum

text: Hockey always reminded me of the sort of bloke who would sell his grandmother to the workhouse just so he could get his Mercedes chammied (spelling?) every week. He'd even go as far as justifying it by saying 'She was terrible at it. She couldn't reach over the roof or anything'.

text: Indeed. What are they going to do? Change leaders and play 'catch-up'? Follow their current course and get hammered?Personally, I don't think they can change leaders now, Shorten hasn't been tested, and subsequently failed, in order to justify bootage.The only solution, as I see it, is for the shadow cabinet (with the help of the backbenchers) to get thoroughly competent at their portfolio. text: If there were 60, 70 or 80 independents on the floor, they'd have to hammer out their policies upon each other's heads before it even gets kicked up to the Senate for another hammering.
