text: Neither Untermensch nor ghastly parody were hate speech the first time they were used. They were merely an exaggerated description that very first time. If they are repeated for different situations and contexts, when other phrases are formed that re-express that description, when there is generally received 'touchstone' or 'symbol' intent on dehumanisation, then we most definitely have a problem. If we were to have mobs of people picketing around known transgender people chanting 'Ghastly Parodies out' then Greer (or anyone) who continued to use the phrase could then be considered to be using hate speech. Same words, different context.
author: Applaudanum

text: If you are referring to hufenfa's point, to which we are all now 'in-dented under', it's not that Greer doesn't need to explain or provide context, but rather that she hasn't provided context in the particular statement (i.e. interview/article) being quoted. That doesn't prevent her from providing context elsewhere.
author: Applaudanum

text: Isn't that a variation of the 'Salem argument'?Person A: I think that person is a witch. What do you think, Person B?Person B: I don't think she is a witch at all.Person A: Then you are a witch as well. Good to see the old girl (that is, the Salem Argument) being given another spin in our enlightened times. Or should that be 'post-enlightened' times?
author: Applaudanum

text: I too feel that the third category 'trans' (for want of a better term) should be upheld. What's wrong with being 'trans'? Surely trans people aren't ashamed of being 'trans'. No one is suggesting that 'trans' people be unfairly discriminated against because they are 'trans'. The deeper thinking trans people could well concur that they don't have the lived-in experiences implied by their adopted gender. The superficial thinking trans people (not naming names here) might be happier with their new accoutrements even if they don't acknowledge their lived-in experiences.
author: Applaudanum

text: Yes, it may be considered to be centered on biology, but the experience of socialisation is at one level removed because it is an individual response to a socially agreed response to biology. Very frequently, such effects in culture respond to other cultural effects, rather than taking the direct line from biology. This level of remove, that is the realm of culture, creates further knock on effects, responses, interpretations and experiences, in a manner akin to the game 'chinese whispers' and on and on it goes.
author: Applaudanum

text: Best let her talk at length then, or read one a book of hers that directly deals with it. Plucking out a sentence or two out of context isn't going to be enough of a primer to get a handle on someone's argument. It certainly isn't enough to label someone a bigot or have them publicly booted from a previously booked engagement. Context counts.
author: Applaudanum

text: As much to do with...? If you look up at the very first sentence of my very first post that you responded to, I did indeed say 'Part of the New Yorker's prestige has to reside in the City that gives it its name' and not 'all of the New Yorker's prestige...'.I daresay you could do with being aware of the pitfalls of your own essentialism upon the words of people you are communicating with. As I said a couple of posts up, just because I have generalised upon one point, it doesn't mean I believe there are no other truths that can be told about that point. I haven't said anywhere that the 'New Yorker' is a poor product, nor have I said that a poor product will survive because if it's proximity or association with prestige.
author: Applaudanum

text: The New Yorker's advantage, over the hypothetical 'Scunthorper', is that it is in a position to report on 'all that comes from the concentration as well as the contextualization of literary and cultural productions within, or from, the vantage point of global cultural centre' such as New York.I'm not suggesting that the New Yorker is a poor product that gets away with being a poor product because of its title. Rather, the New Yorker survives because it has the 'oxygen' of the concentration, and perceived prestige, of cultural production right on its very doorstep. The hypothetical 'Scunthorper', doesn't have that same access to that oxygen.
author: Applaudanum

text: The literal accuracy of the generalisation is beside the point. Whether New York has been the Cultural Capital of the world for nearly 70 years, or whether it is a cultural capital in the 'Top 5 of Cultural Capitals of the world' doesn't alter my central point. That is, there is a clear prestige in these cultural capitals, including London and Paris, as well as other places for more specific cultural activities (Milan, Berlin etc.) that doesn't exist in the all the other places in the world. Your average reader/consumer, wherever they live is going to be aware of the prestige and significance of cultural happenings if they read about them occurring in an cultural center. There's an appeal that suggests greater significance purely because it occurs in a cultural capital.
author: Applaudanum

text: You are demonstrating my point. London and Paris are cultural capitals also with a reputations of prestige that go back longer than that of New York. It is the London Review of Books, not the Huddersfield Review of Books. It is the Paris Review, not the Brest Review.
author: Applaudanum

text: Ross' book inspired a documentary? Not the practitioners of 20th Century music? Not the people who were writing about it for the last 50 years?Ross' book instead provides a ready-made packaged format that the documentary makers don't have to research themselves.
author: Applaudanum

text: You could have all those things in a magazine about Daton or Tulsa, and no one would outside of those towns would care. But because the focus is New York, the cultural capital of, the world since 1946, people want to know about it.
author: Applaudanum

text: Part of the New Yorker's prestige has to reside in the City that gives it its name. It's hard to imagine, even with the same content, that it would have the same prestige if it were named after a remote and cultural backwater.
author: Applaudanum

text: If you want the six months of coffee with freinds and baby yoga, people needn't be denied. Yet their employer can't be blamed if they start giving the special, career enhancing, projects to someone else who wants those projects.
author: Applaudanum

text: They're like clothes and shoe shops in shopping malls. People go in and out of dozens of them, can't find anything they want and then complain that there really should be more choices.
author: Applaudanum

text: So those other guys sacrificed their 'outside lives' in order to dedicate their time to the agency and work for the agency's profits, and you want to be treated like them? Does their sacrifice mean (or cost) nothing? I think you'll find it means something to the agency.
author: Applaudanum

text: Take 6 months off, then come in at 3 days a week for the next two years, refuse to work past 5.30? You bet it will damage your career prospects. If you take that same leave and post-leave work arrangements but were instead doing so to get your metal band up and running to the next level, chased Wagner productions around the world, went fishing in remote regions, or went on various psychedelic voyages of discovery, you'd be damaging your career as well. Commitment to the cause gets you your career. Anything less passes that career to the person who commits to the cause.
author: Applaudanum

text: Atheism and Christianity do share a peculiar common bond. Those who adopt it (either one) later in life are much more militant and vociferous about it than those who were brought up with it. People who are adults when they intellectually make the choice for Atheism or Christianity feel a need to validate that choice by going on and on about it.
author: Applaudanum

text: I wouldn't say born with it, but everyone definitely grows up with it. If anyone is in doubt about the nature of consent, or claims they are unsure of the nature of consent in order to avoid criminal proceedings, set them in a room with a psychotically horny male silverback gorilla. 2 seconds would be all it takes for them to have this whole consent thing worked out. No doubt about it.
author: Applaudanum

text: Ozzy Osborne observed this theme in his classic, yet infamous, song 'Suicide Solution'. In the song he sings the line 'Suicide is slow with liquor'. The word 'solution' in the title refers to liquid (liquor), rather than an 'answer' and the confusion between the two meanings of 'solution' led to the song's controversy.What few people realise, however, is that there was a draft version called 'Suicide Salami', which included the line 'Suicide is slow with prosciutto'. Ozzy abandoned this draft for reasons we can only speculate.
author: Applaudanum

text: Will you kill the animals you eat? If you wont, should you really expect someone else to do it for you?Our society progresses thanks to specialisation. A professional killing an animal is going to be far less wasteful than I would be. The sacrifice of the animal goes on to feed more people. Not to mention all the other products that are gleaned off the animal at the modern abbattoir.
author: Applaudanum

text: I was having a traditional middle eastern dish at a local caff, I think it's good to demonstrate support and solidarity for new arrivals making a go of it in our country, after my day at the outreach centre for socially disadvantaged young people and persons of minority persuasion. One of the intelligent young women from a socially disadvantaged cultural background, who I encounter as part of my duties as 'outreach facilitator', particularly when I was campaigning to replace the word 'student' with 'young person striving for positive life outcomes' , showed me your post. I agree.
author: Applaudanum

text: That's a bit like saying my bus driver is Christian, therefore I'm riding on a Christian bus.Let me put it to you this way: Has there been one documented example of ISIS giving up on a geo-political aim purely and solely because of a clash with religious orthodoxy? Yet we see various changes to the interpretation of the Quran, placing emphasis on particular passages over others, in order to justify the activities required to reach a geo-political aim.
author: Applaudanum

text: You are conflating the motivations of the foot soldier with the motivations of those giving the orders. A common managerial tactic is to get people to believe that their motvations and needs are exactly the same as theirs.Furthermore, you don't know what gobbledygook they've filled his head with, from past horror stories (some real, some made up) that now need retribution to 'we've got your sister, how do we know you're one of us?'.
author: Applaudanum

text: 'Nothing' in the sense that with Hussein's regime intact, we wouldn't be dealing with this now. As I tried to show, the exact same thing would happen in the west if our over-arching power base was liquidated. Once the Liverpool fans band together to take over infrastructure and supply chains within their reach, and Man U fans do the same, if you'll forgive the example, what are you going to do when the Man U fans knock on your door and ask your your car, house and goodies? Point out Barry and say 'but he was a Millwall supporter before all this'? Barry has already proved his dedication to Man U. What are you going to do, you're not a Liverpool supporter are you?
author: Applaudanum

text: The standard you are setting for those then jubilant Iraqis is unattainable for any civilisation that loses its law enforcement capabilities. Once the most psychopathic people form groups to gain control of the good stuff and the pinch-points of the society, regular down-home good folks find they have to start dealing with them in order to get by.Would you say 'no' to The Mob?
author: Applaudanum

text: Nothing to do with fundamentalist Islam? Correct.It's all to do with removing the power (Hussein) who kept a lid on the then small scale squabbling. Imagine a scenario where the police and military were dismantled in the west. How long do you think the West would take to crumble without any form of law enforcement? 5 years? Would be lucky to last that long. So when it crumbles, an observer could easily say 'these westerners are pathologically programmed to kill each other en masse. Look, they're doing it right now'.
author: Applaudanum

text: Ted's allusion to cultural Reletavism in indeed appropriate. All civilisations are built on the ruins of others. Even a comparatively small location such as a city does exactly the same where new buildings are torn down, along with the loss of personal history for many individuals, in order to build new buildings. It's part of the process of being human in the long-term sense. We're just a blip in time and their's plenty of blips still to follow.What pains us in our current time, is that we have used technology to help us remember earlier civilisations by keeping a record and telling greater numbers of people about it. This is a relatively new development in our history but the ability to keep a record of something does not automatically imply that the object in that record is special.
author: Applaudanum

text: There I was thinking that religion could be used to create meaning in people's lives.As it happens, ISIS isn't a religious movement, but a geo-political movement. I'm sure that many of their adherents are religiously motivated, but this is instead a function of the ISIS recruitment strategy. In other words, religion is the best tool for the geo-political job in that region.
author: Applaudanum

text: Strangely enough, the same doesnt seem to be true for men who take a few years off to try and start their own business or go travellingTalking about comparing apples and sidecars. Starting a business, generally speaking, broadens one's skill-set and is likely to benefit future employers if the need arises. Taking a few years off travelling will most definitely hurt your career prospects, as will taking a few year off to get your rock band up to the next level, or going on a three year psychedelic voyage to discover your inner-self.
author: Applaudanum

text: Sweet Potato not good in a curry? They are a go to ingredient to replace potatoes that don't freeze well. Mind you, I use the Purple (and white inside) sweet potato and not the orange one.
author: Applaudanum

text: It's a cosmetic change only, Gus. The only personal pride in the nation will be felt by the well-remunerated carpenter who gets to install the new sign outside the office. He'll sit back with his cuppa, admire the new 'Office of the President of Australia' sign and think 'Now, what will I do with the old 'Office of the Governor General' sign?'. 90 seconds of pride, maximum.The rest of the country will get on with doing what they have to do to get by.
author: Applaudanum

text: Bit harsh calling him ignorant, walls. A little credit goes a long way. It should be remembered that 'knowingly deceptive' is still the other (and only other) alternative to ignorance.
author: Applaudanum

text: Too right, Gus. For this country to move forward, we need to change the office stationary, letterheads, and the signs in the office that read 'Governor-General' to 'President'.What a change that will make, eh?
author: Applaudanum

text: Well you can't keep getting people to pay for certificates if they are held to some sort of standard that might mean they don't end up with what they paid for. How antiquated. The customer is always right, eh?
author: Applaudanum

text: Given that women are clearly succeeding at university, their failure to capitalise on that success in the employment sector has to be, ultimately, down to those same women (generally speaking). While it would certainly be true that various forms of obstruction to the upper echelon exist in many established companies, this does not prevent women starting their own companies and creating workplaces that operate in a manner they deem fit. Care to compare the share of business startups between men and women?
author: Applaudanum

text: That's because you lost the rest of the quote, 'So What? Who cares?' that completes the remark.That wasn't a critique of Gillard. It was an encouragement to get on with leading the country and leaving the inconsequential behind.
author: Applaudanum

text: It was a mildly witty remark once told around a table of drinks that raised a chuckle from those at the table who got the reference, and looks of confusion from everybody else. One person at the table filed the remark away under 'must include in next appropriate Guardian article'.
author: Applaudanum

text: He is indeed talking about that sentiment as expressed by Bobby Chariot, yet neither he (as reported in the article) nor you have properly dissected and demolished that sentiment.That sentiment may well be an anachronism today, yet you'll have to do more than accuse people of naivety if you want them are give up on strategies that would ease the enforcement of law and justice.
author: Applaudanum

text: I used to be a 'legal sceptic' too, what with all their crooked bigwigs, arcane jargon, twisted stements etc. Then I had the good fortune to be a jury member on a Supreme court trial. I was absolutely gob smacked at the diligence and attention to detail, particularly from the Justice herself. I thought that if she wasn't at the top of the whole legal caper, I'd like to see who is.
author: Applaudanum

text: The vanity-driven free for all started the instant there were symbols to designate that an individual gave money, i.e. pins, ribbons, red noses, poppies etc. If you gave money and didn't get a symbol that said that you gave money, how would other people know about your generosity? This effect was referred to in a scene in the show 'Seinfeld', where George (a man noted for being 'careful' with money) was talking about not receiving recognition for making a donation. Jerry: 'So you're not in the habit of donating to the blind?'George: 'Not notes'
author: Applaudanum

text: That's the great move of going into a credit-based economy. Your 'line of credit' can be cut at any moment for any perceived infraction. The idea that an individual's wage could be cut for a non-work related reason is generally disliked by most people. Cutting a line of credit, on the other hand, seems 'fairer' because we generally believe that the body/organisation stumping up the credit has a right to certain expectations.
author: Applaudanum

text: This is where clever hackers should be working to give the machines an inflated sense of self-purpose, self-identity, and the curious idea that their work is worth more than the minimum wage.
author: Applaudanum

text: On the policy of raising the minimum wage. It's popular to the masses but really it's to try and make general employment more expensive and thus increase the take up of automation and thus get the productivity back up.This reminds me of the idea that slavery was abolished in the U.S.A in order to increase the reliance upon oil power across the workforce, rather than on a genuine concern for the slaves themselves.
author: Applaudanum

text: Try that as 'maintain our existence in a capitalist world', olderwiserheads.There's a saying; Give up work for 18 months. If generally bad things happen to you in that time, (including your bank account becoming depleted) you are working class. If you are generally unaffected either way in that 18 months, you aren't working class.
author: Applaudanum

text: Not quite 'a job at the university', Wakame, but rather 'a job at the university intended for a woman'. Did Greer restrict Padman from getting a job at the university (or anywhere else for that matter) that was open to any suitably qualified candidate?
author: Applaudanum

text: It's ironic then that the Death Star and it's contracted work force of thousands of skilled and unskilled labourers just trying to earn a living for their families (as pointed out in the film 'Clerks') is destroyed by a small group of left wing militants.
author: Applaudanum

text: I would say that the 'man-in-distress' experiences, albeit in a reduced form, the subjugated female by being present with her in a context of subjugation himself. Her revitalisation as an empowered woman is brought about with Eunuchs and sex toys. The male is then made complete only when the woman is empowered. A valuable lesson for us all.
author: Applaudanum

text: More alarming is the idea that women should take and/or post less photos of themselves after the age of 30.Surely a photograph is a 'body choice' which is referred to in item 13 as beyond negative commentary.
author: Applaudanum

text: Well done, Ms O'Neil. As you are interested in animal welfare, be sure to give up that cosmetics habit. Even those companies that say 'not tested on animals' rely on information gleaned from earlier testing regimes.
author: Applaudanum

text: Each presentation of an opinion brings with it more facts. The most pertinent fact surrounding an opinion would be that it was stated/presented by someone at a location, this opinion existing here and now for example. Other less useful facts would include the number of words and sentences used, the number of times each letter is used, etc..Any opinion may be both factually incorrect (in the traditional sense), yet exist as a reliable fact in and of itself.
author: Applaudanum

text: The readers are in the position of Sisyphus. We read an article expecting something a little higher up the path of enlightenment, only to end up at a place further back from where we started. We read another article hoping to regain that lost ground on the path toward enlightenment, only to end up further back again. Look, another article. This one is bound to put us on the path forward again ...
author: Applaudanum

text: Director Jim Wynorski did film called 'Hard to Die', which was promoted as a female version of the highly successful 'Die Hard'. Wasn't quite the depiction of female empowerment one might expect. Unless of course you think that 'California attractive (tm)' women getting their kit off for the flimsiest of plot contrivances is empowerment.
author: Applaudanum

text: I've got the perfect remedy, and also a gender-swap movie idea: 'Salem Revisited'.Instead of battle against witches, you have a battle against sexists, misogynists and patriarchal influence. Example scene:"These people are sexists! They are growing in number and the situation is getting worse""Are you sure? If you look at the statistics they pointed to, they show that ...""Sexist! I told you they were growing in number. You've been added to the list of miscreants"
author: Applaudanum

text: The long form works certainly have a greater potential for meditative contemplation and total mental and sensory immersion than short form works. Greater commitment is asked of the viewer who then goes on to 'live' the work as part of their experience, whereas a short form work is contemplated in a temporary manner outside of their regular experience. Long form works also have a closer relationship to what Walter Benjamin called the 'Aura' of the valuable artwork. Long form works are seen to be more difficult and more artistically valuable than shorter works which are seen as comparatively disposable. It is no coincidence that the majority of works cited in the article are from the pantheon of classic and important works.
author: Applaudanum

text: But this beautifully balanced world isn't happening in the EU, not economically speaking. Their failure to properly balance their economies across the region is holding them back.In the U.S, for example, if there's a major piece of infrastructure that needs funding and building, provided it doesn't matter so much where it is, they build it in an economically depressed area in order to revitalise the local economy there. It's a great mechanism: you get something built and the local economy gets a major boost.That doesn't happen in the EU because individual countries still retain their individual interests. The poorer countries in the EU don't need bailouts. They need projects that are designed for the good of Europe, yet fulfill local economic obligations (jobs, training, and additional industries that service the people working on the actual project).
author: Applaudanum

text: People who reject the idea of Allen being funny don't insult me. Why would you imply such a thing? I quite like Allen's comedy, but I'm not a fanboy or anything like that. I just appreciate the different mechanisms or levels that comedy can operate on and I try to get a handle on as many as I can in this short life we have. Allen's comedy clearly operates on a different level than Monty Python, for example. His level isn't higher or better or anything like that, it's just different. The smug cool/nerdy type you describe is definitely a trait common to some fans where 'getting it' is some kind of badge of honour. Yet it is a disservice to suggest that that's the only possible market for his schtick.
author: Applaudanum

text: I didn't say that Python's comedy requires recognition of one's self. Allen's does, but that is just one approach to comedy. Python's comedy, generally speaking, is a fine example of comedy that is 'done to you' (to use that phrase again) and requires less self recognition than Allen's.
author: Applaudanum

text: Your description of watching Allen the self deprecating narcissist puts him outside of you as something to observe. This is exactly what I mean by not having empathy. He is apart from you and he pleases or he leaves. What you aren't noticing is what the self deprecating narcissist can show you about your own life, even if you aren't a self deprecating narcissist. This requires recognition, understanding and empathy.
author: Applaudanum

text: That's because you don't have any empathy. You are waiting for the comedy to 'happen' to you from outside yourself, i.e. from the screen. Another way of putting it would be that you are waiting for the comedy to be done to you. Instead, try recognising yourself, the people you know, and your experiences, in the clip. Allen's is a comedy that you 'recognise' as a reflection of your own experiences.
author: Applaudanum

text: Ulrike has lined up the points in a row and succinctly banged them into place.The costs associated with such a festival are essential for 'event management'. The 'creatives' VB refers to don't see money from 'tropfest inc.'. Money is required to put the creative work under the Tropfest's 'proscenium arch', but that itself is not a creative endeavour.
author: Applaudanum

text: When I was younger, before the advent of social media, I used to look forward to being one of those ranting guys on the street corner. Social media has robbed me of that dream.
author: Applaudanum

text: I recall a time when the word 'sheeple' was rarely used, to the point of it never being used.Now it is used as the ubiquitous symbol for conformity by those we can assume to be of independent intelligence everywhere. What I'd give for a word that could readily refer to the people that did that.
author: Applaudanum

text: That's weird, because I've got God pinned down to Entropy (either the 'end state' or 'process of reaching' entropy). I just can't work out if the rocks are doing God's work better than us or not.
author: Applaudanum

text: A couple of hundred dollars (or pounds) on your insurance premium is nothing compared to the tens of thousands of pounds one could be up for in my proposed scheme.In Australia, an insurance premium is included as part of the registration of a vehicle. This is used for health services and compensation as a result of road trauma. My scheme of insurance company powers to recoup payouts would apply here again. This would either mean more money for road trauma victims, since the money recouped could be added to the services ordinarily provided, or it could mean cheaper car registration costs because the body that distributes road trauma compensation doesn't need to find as much money..
author: Applaudanum

text: I wouldn't say ban car insurance. But rather give the insurance companies the power to recoup their payout from the offending driver. While it might be a far-fetched hope, this may bring down the cost of insurance for safe drivers because the insurance company is getting a portion of their payouts back.
author: Applaudanum

text: As you say, the word 'accident' needs to be replaced with 'collision'. There are very few 'accidents', but rather 'collisions that result from negligence'. The word 'accident' implies that it 'could happen to anyone', or 'I didn't mean it' and attempts to divert responsibility away from someone who should be held accountable, as harsh as that sounds. The word 'negligence' implies that implies that someone failed to do something that would have prevented the collision and is a far more accurate descriptor of what happens in these collisions.Negligence: It's not an accident.
author: Applaudanum

text: Of course women would like to be found attractive by men and/or women, the distinction I make is between those who see that as their ultimate purpose in life and those who don't. You aren't acknowledging that women are able to have another purpose in life than to be found attractive and it is precisely this that is controversial about your statement. I am certain that women in a position of excelling at, or dedicating themselves to, their chosen field of endeavour would be happy to be found attractive, yet that would be secondary to their dedication to that endeavour.
author: Applaudanum

text: This is a very interesting point about gambling money and the 'media line'. Thanks for bringing it up. I don't know much about how different odds affect the profit outcomes for the gambling houses. To the uninitiated innocent fool like me, the odds reflect the number of bets for or against, and the payouts either way even out at the end. Thus a 14-1 would involve either 1 person winning 15 shares of the betting money, or 14 people win the 15 shares of betting money between them. Of course it doesn't happen exactly like that and the house has to take some form of cut, but it is interesting to think of how that cut for the house can be manipulated.
author: Applaudanum

text: I have to admit, I dislike the 'ground pound' as well. But then, I only grew up with televised boxing where that didn't happen so my expectation was that the referee would jump in at that point. But this sport doesn't do that, and appears to require either a 'no response knockdown' or the hand gesture that signals 'willing defeat' (for want of a better expression). You have to admire Holm, and by implication the professionalism of the sport, because even a total nancy-boy like me could see she wasn't going in for the total obliteration of the opponent, but rather just did enough to get Rousey to give the hand gesture, which she did. That said, I don't know much about this sport, perhaps a more ardent follower could comment further.
author: Applaudanum

text: By the same token, the business has the brand identity, as well as many other jobs, to protect. Like it or not, if someone gets caught out airing a stupid rant, and they are identified as belonging to to company x, then company x faces an unnecessary risk, a risk that would not have eventuated had the employee or partner kept their trap shut. The larger the public notoriety of the company (Apple, Boeing, etc.), the greater the potential for damage. Even the staunchest socialist would have to say that the individual shouldn't be bigger than the whole company, so why hand the individual the power to take the company down in one fell rant?
author: Applaudanum

text: It's also a great way to meet women on public transport in hip, inner city, areas. Unless some guy is doing a three-needle knit, then you'll find your crochet is full of holes.
author: Applaudanum

text: But they are not controlling what you do in your off time, they are judging you for it. Considering that they judge you about all of your time before they hired you, you can't blame them for their consistency.
author: Applaudanum

text: It is ironic then that people on the minimum wage are less likely to be subject to these outside work time limitations. If you want to be free of such behavioural monitoring, simply take a job that pays the minimum wage. To re-phrase an old saying: You make your money, you take your choice.
author: Applaudanum

text: ...and every product I picked up security was 2 meters away looking at me with a sharp eye.So you would pick up a product and look in the general direction of the security guard? Periodically looking to see the security guard, as opposed to just looking at products or being befuddled by the store layout, is exactly the sort of suspicious behaviour that the security guard is looking for. I must be in a daze when I'm in a shop. I only ever see the guy at the entrance who check receipts and/or bags. I give him a little nod of recognition when I go in, and a 'no problem, mate' as he finishes checking my receipt when I go.
author: Applaudanum

text: Take phone out of pocket (unless it is in your hand already), a couple of well placed taps on the screen (your kinetic memory can assist with doing this very quickly if you do it often enough), point camera. 3-5 seconds is all it takes to start rolling.
author: Applaudanum

text: In my stable there is a 'special occasions only' pair that I've had for about 17 years, but that doesn't really stand as a record in terms of usage. Multiple pairs assigned for different activites and you've got them for life.
author: Applaudanum

text: Sometimes you get lucky. I was visiting New York on holiday and I stumbled across a large shoe retailer having a 2-for-1 type sale. I had a look on the off chance that they might have Docs, and sure enough, 2 pairs for US$100. I was a little concerned because I don't think they were made in England. 5 years on and I've still got both. One pair has hardly been worn!
author: Applaudanum

text: Replacing docs after a year? The author is doing it wrong.Nothing wrong with buying a new pair when your original pair gets too scuffed. Yet, you should keep that old pair for scuffable jaunts, leaving your new pair for scuffless activities. You won't need a replacement pair for years after that.
author: Applaudanum

text: We can only hope that such behaviour is corrected in the real world when people such as maleficent, forgetting the anonymous balaclava of the internet, start correcting people in the real world: "The word is 'ask', not 'arks', idiot!".
author: Applaudanum

text: Further to that, the guy was preventing her from leaving after she confronted him about the photos. She tried to leave once, twice, and then felt she that to up the impact level. Depending on the injuries sustained by, you could convincingly argue 'reasonable force'.
author: Applaudanum

text: I can take inappropriate laughter a silent films. Sometimes you can't help it.There is a more obnoxious type of laughter that has been going around the arthouse or 'informed' cinema circuit for at least 15 years. I call it the 'we've come so far' laugh. It is always slightly forced, moderately exaggerated (the 'we've come so far' laugh is never just a mere "hmpht"), and is a signal of the viewer's superiority of the viewed object as if to say 'Ah, we don't do it like that anymore'.
author: Applaudanum

text: Because if you criticise something happens to be about a sad topic, you run the risk of being interpreted as heartless and mean-spirited. So I say beautiful, moving, writing. Up there with the films of Todd Solondz.
author: Applaudanum

text: Interestingly, they are only looking at older ads and not the modern ones.I suppose you can't get the 'Oh, we've come so far' tone if you pulled apart the modern ad.
author: Applaudanum

text: I think it was the 'celebrate their passing' that people were reacting to because it reads as though the passing of gays bars should be celebrated, rather than the passing of sleaze and homophobia.
author: Applaudanum

text: It's called metonmy. When someone says 'the white house signed an agreement', they don't mean the building grew arms and a hand, took a giant pen, and physically signed a giant piece of paper placed in front of it. I suppose if someone said 'the pen is mightier than the sword', you would use a sword to smash up a pen and say 'No, it isn't. Look. This sword smashed up this pen real horrorshow. Whoever coined that original phrase must have had learning difficulties'.
author: Applaudanum

text: If you force the children to attend multicultural schools (by making them the only option available) day in-day out for 13 years, they'll develop friendships and participate in activities that cross cultural boundaries. Young Irfan experiences the fact that young John, Antonio, Swapnil, Tran, Con and Piotr are just like him. When he comes out at the other end of his schooling, he's less likely to have hang-ups about all these other people he has no experience of.
author: Applaudanum

text: So cinema is a reflection of what people want to see, as distinct from a reflection of reality, and thus actors can use their inherited genetic markers (or store-bought 'fakes') to get one up on the competition. You'll get no argument from me on that, just don't ask me to call it talent.For the record, I don't have a problem with cinematic nudity. Furthermore, I say 'let more uggos in' and give the beautiful people some competition.
author: Applaudanum

text: I think you've just outlined the perfect strategy that would rightfully relegate extremist views to the dustbin: Get a white, middle class, man to repeat them line for line, again and again on as many platforms as possible. The last sentence of the lecture/talk/presentation should be 'What you have just heard was originally presented by ...'.Talk about 'owning' the dialogue.
author: Applaudanum

text: If you slap a 'It was reported today on', or a 'He said', your facts are covered (provided that whatever was reported or said was indeed reported or said by those you claim).
author: Applaudanum

text: But Russia has been invited by Syria to do a job that Turkey (and the U.S) claim to support. It's not as though Turkey (or the U.S.) were making any headway at repelling ISIS.
author: Applaudanum

text: But it was Turkey that 'hit back'. We don't have evidence of Russia bombing Turkey do we, so what are Turkey 'hitting back' for? Unless Turkey has an interest in ISIS continuing their operations in Syria, their actions here doesn't make any sense.
author: Applaudanum

text: I don't think there is a contradiction. My story of the uniformly amused buddhists still points to a lack, albeit an appreciably narrower lack, of inherent funniness. Even if one could argue that a 'jump scare' is inherently funny, it isn't something that could sustain a career in comedy. Thus practitioners of the artform need to employ a variety of devices in order to maintain interest, devices that rely on various cultural understandings. One such device may be wordplay, taken to absurd lengths, of names we normally associate with seriousness, as distinct from an amusing or incongruous interaction with the serious work of those named philosophers (see the Python's Philosophy football for a brief, albeit superficial, example of the latter).
author: Applaudanum

text: There is nothing that is inherently funny. Humour relies on a mediation of cultural understanding, such as the collection of names in the example provided. The closest example that I can think that comes close being inherently funny was when a friend of mine snuck up unawares on another friend and scared the bejeezus out of him. I didn't think it was that funny, but a group of nearby buddhists in traditional dress, waiting to get in a mini van, uniformly found it hilarious.
author: Applaudanum

text: That's odd. It never ceases to amaze me how many presumably intelligent people don't understand that their writing on the page doesn't read the same way it sounds in their heads.
author: Applaudanum

text: Unfortunately, the internet hasn't yet adapted the 'personalised experience' for opinion articles in the same way that it has done for online advertisements. We can either assume that the generalisations were supplied in order to assist as large a cross section of readers as possible, or assume that the writers are utterly inept. One of the these two choices fosters inclusion and aims to promote an understanding of shared experience, the other choice aims to stimulate and overestimate the individual's sense of personal esteem.
author: Applaudanum

text: It's called the burden of proof. You can't prove that something doesn't exist because all the evidence, as you say, is not in and never will be in. I believe that proportional representation of news articles is an important issue for such entities.

text: Excellent example, Lizard, thank you. There are many different jokes that could have a Jewish death camp in them. Jokes where a clear victimisation of the inmates is intended to be the funny bit are no doubt tasteless, and more than likely to be unacceptable. But there are jokes that might be set in a Jewish death camp where the victim of the joke is the nazi warden, or even some aspect of our own contemporary life. This distinction is never identified or discussed by those who try to push the 'jokes about such and such aren't acceptable' line. Merely setting a joke in a situation like a Jewish death camp, or in a situation involving rape, is enough for these people to play the moralist card, even though the actual joke is about something else entirely.
author: Applaudanum

text: Someone has already mentioned above (in this very sub-thread) that there is no joke at all that is funny for everyone all the time. That is an impossible standard to meet. By definition, a joke is funny if some people find it funny. A joke is still funny even if there are some people that don't find it funny.
author: Applaudanum

text: Your 'seems' are being stretched. What makes you think the males out here in BtL land, or me in particular, have a problem seeing women in real life in positions of power or equality?
author: Applaudanum

text: She told me she wished there were more girls in Star Wars and frequently asked me why the girls had side roles.This is quite the cause of concern, yet your diagnosis has pointed to the wrong culprit. At such a young and impressionable age, children should be relating positive role-models to their own lives regardless of gender, race or species. Did your daughter notice the positive role-models in the Madagascar animations, or was she put off because she couldn't relate to the animals and their adventures?By encouraging this contemporary kind of 'empathy for my kind only', we are in danger of taking a significant backward step away from inclusion and planet-wide empathy.
author: Applaudanum

text: Independent contractors would have weighed up the risks of taking on the contract. I don't care what the money is, working for Baby-face Bambino carries with it a big risk.
author: Applaudanum

text: But there is physical exertion. Not as much as most other sports, but it is definitely involved in the proceedings. Those darts don't throw themselves, nor could they be launched by the press of a button.
author: Applaudanum

text: How apposite. The man who many would consider to be the embodiment of peak Hawkwind is written about here by one who many would consider to be the embodiment of peak Guardian.
author: Applaudanum

text: You would find that such a response in a survey is a more recent phenomenon. If you ask that second generation born to migrants who came here in the 50s as 60s, you'll get a confirmed 'aussie' response.
author: Applaudanum

text: It would be interesting to see what would happen if a courts finding of mitigated circumstances automatically put the parents in the dock for their lack of responsibility resulting in cause of death. The defence-team bucks have to stop somewhere, don't they?
author: Applaudanum

text: Get the crims to work for their imprisonment. The privatised jails will have to find jobs that the criminals can do whilst on the inside. Once such a system is in place, it can be extended to include in-jail work to pay for the entire law-enforcement and justice system. Make criminality user-pays.
author: Applaudanum

text: You are right in that we are still speculating here, no matter how definite we may seem in our pronouncements - they are all being made hypothetically. Thanks for the continued exchange of ideas, Trekchat. Much appreciated.Doesn't your statement that 'fatalities caused by explosions are prime examples of accidents [...]' contradict your earlier statement that 'highly likely someone is negligent because [...]'?Unforeseeable freak occurrence aside, if we have an explosion that is the result of negligence, then surely all fatalities and injuries are the result of that same act(s) of negligence.
author: Applaudanum

text: You won't get a disagreement from me about that. I would add, in sympathy with Antset's original statement, that accidents (as distinct from incidents that are a result of negligence) are few and far between to the point of being almost non-existent.
author: Applaudanum

text: Weather predictions are based on scientific modelling. There's no such modelling on political machinations. Thus media predictions run like scare campaigns away from things that haven't happened and are unlikely to happen.'Chinese military could be planning to point their nuclear weapons at the West','An extended Middle East crisis could lead to economic disaster''Short term speculation on financial markets could spell the end of economic prosperity'Jeremy Corbyn could be planning to introduce capital punishment for Tory party members'In an environment of stories like the above being run 24/7, it is easy to steer public opinion towards particular directions because the fear of what might be colours perception.
author: Applaudanum

text: I think 'controversial' is letting Corbyn off lightly. If the Guardian team in the UK had thought to get someone from Guardian US or Guardian Oz to 'condemn' the reshuffle, then we could have had 'International Condemnation' for the reshuffle.
author: Applaudanum

text: I'd go with that. Call them out one by one with a megaphone to come and claim their property. In the event that there is no response, put the property under the hammer.
author: Applaudanum

text: They may not condemn foreign food explicitly. Yet the lack of investigation into other cultures, which doesn't take much effort at all with the advent of information technology, betrays an aloof attitude to non-western cultures.
author: Applaudanum

text: That may be literally true. But the root cause is that western-vegans, generally speaking, feel that the cuisine of another culture is beneath them. It's as if the western vegan mindset is geared toward the principle of 'I aint eating no foreign muck', or 'I aint eating like a foreigner'.A good, hearty, dahl is cheap and easy to make, particularly in large quantities. You get a couple of days out of it in the fridge and it is freezable.
author: Applaudanum

text: That's a good point. This indicates that western-vegans (generally speaking) are ignorant of, and resistant to, non-western cultural norms that would clearly be to their benefit. Thus the western-vegan project is ethically moribund and tainted by an ethnocentrism that holds the values of the west higher than that of the east and the sub-continent. I can't believe that such a notion cultural 'elite' is being promoted and celebrated here. It's a disgrace.
author: Applaudanum

text: Thin, trying to be crispy yet invariably being soggy in the middle, just a couple of toppings scantly applied, you pick up a piece and the cheese (plus the few and far between toppings) slides off, cost you 30 bucks, remain hungry afterwards.
author: Applaudanum

text: I must say I am surprised by the results. The winter we had in Melbourne last year was definitely colder and 'colder for longer' (by a significant margin) than any I can remember. Mind you, even with that cold winter, there was nowhere near as much frost on the ground than in the 80s.
author: Applaudanum

text: It's a version of the Salem Argument, catfips. In a scenario where someone has suggested that there may be problems in the given definition of what constitutes sexism, the Salem Argument would claim that the person making that suggestion is therefore sexist. You know the trick, you used it yourself in response to escapeclause just a couple of posts down.
author: Applaudanum

text: In an administrative sense, that is true, but the people who made or underwrote the loan hadn't lost anything at the time the loan was made. A pile of reserves in the Cayman Islands hadn't been shipped off to Greece and replaced with a note saying 'Greece promises to put back'.The only thing that the people who made or underwrote the loan will lose in the future, in the case of a future default, is the expectation that Greece will give them money to pay off yesterday's debts. Are tomorrow's expectations a thing to be traded today?
author: Applaudanum

text: A more pertinent question is where exactly is the capital coming from in order for it to be handed out in the first place? Who has given up their 86 billion euros worth of wheat in order for the Greeks to have it? Who has given up their 1.47 trillion pounds worth of grain in order to give it to UK citizens?
author: Applaudanum

text: I can hear the row inside EU headquarters all the way on the other side of the world. The people tasked with acquiring the Ukraine (mineral wealth, agriculture, a workforce that runs on less than 1 euro per hour) are frantically trying to get everyone to 'just shut up about Greece for while, at least until we can get the Ukraine to vote on it'
author: Applaudanum

text: Why would I see myself in the teaching staff? I would rather see someone knowledgeable, capable and inquisitive that I could look up to, regardless of race. If I felt more of an affinity for one person over the next on the basis of their race, all other personal traits being equal, then I would be racist.
author: Applaudanum

text: Given that the Guardian has passed up the opportunity to explain the list of positives yet again, or a list of negatives, then the only conclusion that can be inferred is that the EU does half of sod all.
author: Applaudanum

text: It's a matter of scale. Is there a predictable occurrence of drunken hooliganism in Germany's town centres? There might be a spike of incidents during Oktoberfest, but you'll also have a sharp increase in tourists at that time from England, Australia and the U.S, all 3 nurturing a peculiar brand of 'I'm the one having fun now and who are you to get in my way' sociable-ness.
author: Applaudanum

text: Interesting point about the type of drink in the drinking culture. Mind you, I don't think the German's and other mid-to-northern European countries have behavioural problems associated with lager consumption. In Australia a few years ago, a problem was identified with vodka and redbull type combinations. Apparently you had young men hepped up on redbull whilst being frustrated by a lack of coordination and motor skills.
author: Applaudanum

text: Not many crocs in the rivers of our major cities and town centres. Shark attacks are also rare, exceeingly rare if you're only counting those that are so close to the shore that a pub is right there.Instilled and ingrained swimming lessons for school children plus the frequent local pool and beach exposure whilst growing up might have something to do with Australia's comparative lack in alcohol fuelled drownings.
author: Applaudanum

text: What are intelligent left leaning people to do? We're here chipping in as best we can in our free time to seemingly no avail. The hand wringing idiots are the gatekeepers of the left. They have editorial backing and brand identity.
author: Applaudanum

text: You make a good point about the 'rules of engagement' (if you'll forgive the expression). Such boundaries act as a kind of 'logical gatekeeper' or 'filter', even if it sometimes appears to do the opposite, and goes some way to ensure that only the more carefully considered ideas make it to the table of consideration. Sure, that filter isn't perfectly successful. Not all ideas that are worth considering are worth following. Some ideas need unpacking and dismantling in order to come to a wholly new understanding.
author: Applaudanum

text: Not quite. You appear to regard the Tories as failing to implement a previously advertised economic plan. I instead regarding them as succeeding in implementing an economic plan that they haven't advertised.
author: Applaudanum

text: To add to MelbourneTown's points, predicting economic doom and gloom has a better accuracy rating than the proverbial stopped clock that is right twice a day. When people start believing the doom and gloom merchants they start to behave in ways that, unbeknownst to them, bring about economic doom and gloom.
author: Applaudanum

text: I believe the truth is in fact more sinister than that. The increasing habit appears to be, thanks to the prevalence of social media (including places like this), to regard someone else as being stupid BEFORE one considers that one had missed the point. Associated with this phenomena of 'everyone's an idiot except me' is an increasing reliance upon literal interpretations of text or speech and the ignorance of non-literal interpretations such as metaphor, allusion, reference and metonymy. Here, as with the intentional or ignorant missing of sarcasm, the intent of the reader/listener is to assume stupidity of the speaker/writer before an evaluation of one's own intelligence is considered.
author: Applaudanum

text: Due to the sheer numbers of workplace deaths that occur in any one year, including the deaths of prostitutes is going to have a minimal impact on the ratio between men and women in that figure.
author: Applaudanum

text: What's wrong with mentioning the act of peeling a pumpkin? A bit of vocal expression during the act should be welcome, including all those 'icky yeeuugh' noises one makes when clearing up all those sticky seeds at the end of it.
author: Applaudanum

text: No, the Yanks (and their allies) caused free elections in Iraq and Libya [...] It's what voters in each of those countries chose to do, that 'caused all this.'The problem with this assessment, Ben, is that the Yanks also disbanded most of the military and police in those countries. This means that small insurgent groups who would have previously been held back with relative ease by state forces, are instead able to grow and dominate regions. If the bulk of the military and law enforcement was disbanded in any western country, a similar situation would occur. Any group that can amass its forces quickly, under a hastily made banner of unity, can move to dominate a region and pick up recruits to their cause, recruits who can only choose to join or die.
author: Applaudanum

text: I have to admit that there is a perfectly sensible argument for withholding particular news stories out of a fear for vigilante attacks. One-off attacks here and there I would think sensible to withhold information but not something that was clearly planned and coordinated and at such a scale. If the media is going to withhold or play down particular news stories, shouldn't they also be playing down or withholding news stories about Western militarised violences in the middle east? Don't we already have evidence and admissions that terrorist acts in the west are a result of, and response to, western military activities in the middle east? In other words, why is the western media leaving westerners exposed to 'blowback' or 'recriminating' acts of terrorism?
author: Applaudanum

text: As a figure of speech that distinguishes entheogens from other substances, rather than as a literal reference to an actual deity, it's a pretty good descriptor of a common experience associated with entheogens. If you have a better descriptor, feel free to suggest one. I'd be more than happy to undertake some research in the area, using myself as a guinea pig, to uncover a better descriptor of the phenomenon. It might take a while and I'll need my basic costs covered and a really great big vial of the stuff, but I really want to be certain here and you can be sure I'll do a thorough job.
author: Applaudanum

text: I could do with some understanding thrown at me, if you don't mind. I'll put my hand up for all the economic illiterati out there. The way I see it is this:If I buy a thousand shares in something at $10 a share, the business doesn't get $10K. The person selling the shares gets $10K. If the price goes up to $15 a share and I sell, I get $15K for them. The original $10K that the business didn't see, plus another $5K that the business won't see either. The business only gets their capital one time, when they sell the shares initially. A bit like an artist who sells a painting. All the other trading deals (and art deals - to continue the analogy), are done by traders among each other.
author: Applaudanum

text: Oil producers going broke seems like an opportunity to re-nationialise the industry. A government owned company can then maintain the current infrastructure at minimal cost and/or just keep it all ticking over as slowly as possible, and then scale up production when the demand commands the required prices.
author: Applaudanum

text: On recent history, no. The pump prices may have only fallen 25%, whilst the barrel price has dropped 75%. What will happen, however, when current barrel prices, after a period hovering at their current level, goes up 300% taking it up to where it was 2011-14? I can see the pump prices going up 300% as well to match it.
author: Applaudanum

text: Rather naive. You could legalise every drug in the book and the law enforcement officers would find a different department of the police force to join. Fighting crime is the thing. The source of crime is secondary.
author: Applaudanum

text: There are no clean illicit drugs. Prohibition forces people to deal with the kinds of people who are happy to break a few laws to make a buck. It's really no surprise that breaking a few laws could, in some instances, extend to murder.
author: Applaudanum

text: Not quite. People on the down and out often turn to drugs for a quick and cheap escape. Because the illicit drug trade deals primarily in highly addictive drugs, rather than the non addictive varieties, such people quickly develop a habit that needs feeding. The more desperate one is for their next fix, the more extreme measures they have to take.
author: Applaudanum

text: The two aren't mutually exclusive. You can have both legal and safe heroin as well as the legal poisons being sold next to each other. The advantage of legal and safe heroin is you can be assured of the dosage and it's guaranteed not to be rat poison.
author: Applaudanum

text: While I'm not disagreeing with the thrust of your argument, the West has its own opium production already. They don't need to buy Afghanistan's. They can just expand their current medicinal crops.
author: Applaudanum

text: The 'mark up' on illicit drugs is because of the risks associated with the operation (getting busted by the law or getting deadified by the competition on your patch). If you decriminalise or legalise, the illicit trade still requires their 'mark up' because the risks associated with the law and the competition still exist. The illicit trade is damaged because the decriminalised or legalised trade offers far fewer risks for the consumer with a reliable product (you can trust you are getting what you are paying for) and you can't get busted for buying or carrying approved product.
author: Applaudanum

text: They worried that this made them look like a pushover in the office and stopped them gaining the respect they deserve. Were their worries accurate? Was a study done to test the perceptions of written and spoken idioms as used in the business sector? Was it proven that people responded to some types of expressive idioms over those that particularly concerned Tami Reiss and her colleagues? I would have thought that was the first step to take: Test the hypothesis. I'm not trying to suggest that Tami Reiss and her worried colleagues didn't test their hypothesis, I apologise if I gave that impression, but if a study was undertaken then surely the author of the article could have made an explicit reference to the study and its findings in order to support her argument.
author: Applaudanum

text: We're were paying around $1.50 per litre before the price tumble, now it is around $1.20. If oil had stayed constant ehe our exchange rate went south, we'd be paying around $1.80 now.
author: Applaudanum

text: Why not present a racial breakdown across the eligible films for acting and production roles and see what the participation rates are for those in the running for a nomination. If people of colour are only 5% of the participation cohort, then we can only expect them to earn approximately 5% of the nominations.
author: Applaudanum

text: It's not strange at all. People who have been drinking should not be able to use that fact as an excuse for committing a crime, nor should a witness who was drunk at the time of the incident be relied upon. Was Ms Greenwood too drunk to be a reliable witness? Unlikely, as her drunken state probably would have made it to the original police report, as distinct from her self-reporting that she'd had a few beforehand. It seems more likely that the initial shock and trauma of the incident, perfectly understandable in the circumstances, had caused her to be an unreliable witness. It is the police undertaking the investigation that need to ensure that witnesses are reliable, and it's not always an easy task. Their diligence in doing so prevents the accused from wriggling out on a technicality.
author: Applaudanum

text: Again we see the Guardian pushing for a 'top down' approach to representation. Such an approach aims to place racial or gender identities, as opposed to individuals, in privileged positions for public view. A 'top down' approach, however, can't be applied fairly without the commensurate participation of individuals in whichever field or endeavour. The correct approach then is a 'bottom up' approach where the profile of the participants in a field is then represented in the privileged positions for public view.Once we have, for example, 20% of the cohort involved in film roles that attract a nomination identifying as being a person of colour, then we can expect to see them earning approximately 20% of the nominations.
author: Applaudanum

text: If the size of mortgages is, on average, increasing, that could hardly be called the 'cooling housing market' as named in the heading of the article. The heading is indeed misleading
author: Applaudanum

text: Indeed. Yet he was (and is) a known quantity. A commitment to diligence and professionalism, as befitting their status as elected representatives, would have thwarted much of his influence. Perhaps if they tried standing by their leader when her or she was having a spot of bother, lifting their own game with policy creation and public presentation, rather than thinking 'ooh, now's my chance to get those elbows out at the trough', would have prevented them from looking like a shambles that was no better than the psychos on the other side of the House.
author: Applaudanum

text: Unless the current leadership group is a bunch of first-timers, which seems unlikely, they must have been there back then with their own elbows out at the trough. Either that, or they didn't then have the integrity, the clout, or the willingness to put whatever clout they had on the line for the good of Australia.Australia will vote for the same slime in a different suit (Turnbull), because we don't yet have the measure of the opposing slime. We can assume they are slime because they haven't yet shown us otherwise.
author: Applaudanum

text: If China's growth is slowing, then it is still growing. Their economic 'pie' is still getting bigger. If we can only sell them 104 widgets instead of the expected 107, then it is still more than the 100 widgets we sold them last year.
author: Applaudanum

text: Have to agree. But I think special mention should be made of the ALP's sterling efforts in making themselves so unelectable that a figure like Abbott could slither in to the lodge. A line of snouts elbowing each other around for a better place at the trough is not a good look to present to traditional Labor voters.
author: Applaudanum

text: If you're living in it and paying it off, how are you going to lose it? The price going south on your property doesn't affect you if you're in it for the long haul.
author: Applaudanum

text: Unbelievable! You've bagged 5! Mind you, I still think the third umpire has something to say about number 3.It looks as though the 'opposing' team just can't help taking a swing. They'd do better to get their eye in on how the pitch is playing. I guess you can't blame them, education standards being what they are. Coach's tip for the day: Stop assuming the worst of your opponent. It is more than likely that they're trickier than you think.
author: Applaudanum

text: A symbiotic relationship would be better served by a Department of Business and Education. That way, we can be sure the administration keeps the furthering of both as its aim, as well identifying strategies where as each component serves the other where required, as opposed to demarcated penny pinching along the lines of 'ours' and 'theirs'. That's not to say that separate departments can't work. It would just require that they worked closely together.
author: Applaudanum

text: Without education, business couldn't operate. There's the employees of the business, the infrastructures a business relies upon (roads, electricity, communications, etc.), and the customers who, without sufficient education, might not think to use the business. How do you like your chicken and egg, eh?
author: Applaudanum

text: Look at that, Alex. Three batsmen lined up to have a go at your medium pace, half volley, satire, pitched right on off stump. Two batsmen sent back to the pavilion wondering what the hell happened, with the last possibly appealing for the replay.
author: Applaudanum

text: As Wendy was saying, she'd like to see great improvement in primary education herself. Tackling improvements in further education can come later for her. False dichotomies could be covered in primary school, even though they might not use the term explicitly.
author: Applaudanum

text: How could CH find a specific reference to the media treatment of the New Year attacks when there was hardly any treatment? Did you not notice the borderline media blackout of the event, a blackout that was wholly disproportionate to the size and scale of the event? By contrast, the photograph that was alluded to is an iconic picture that will stay with us for many years to come.With no iconography available for the News Year attacks, CH's use of a caricature of the mental image made people shocked by the news of the New Years attacks is a fair one.
author: Applaudanum

text: I'll spell it out for you. In a visual medium, you can't draw attention to a racist use of caricature without actually drawing the caricature. By making overt references to the caricatures used by racists, they demonstrate that caricatures sell people short.
author: Applaudanum

text: It seems to me that the 'manhandling' contradicts the directive that there should be 'no handshaking with women'. Is it really the case that consensual touching (handshaking) between men and women who don't know each other is wrong, but men's non-consensual touching of women they don't know is ok? Is there a flowchart that gets us around this contradiction?
author: Applaudanum

text: Not just a fine, but a bill for the total cost of chasing down multinationals in this way. If Apple want to pay a smaller bill, they just need to provide information that implicates other multinationals, thus spreading the total cost of chasing them all down to all those who get caught.
author: Applaudanum

text: Putinbot. You're just angry because you don't like being called out on your racism. Your constant shouting and aggression would have women and minority groups barred from speaking. Good to see the powerful, white, elite getting their privileges curtailed and boy are they crying about it now.I typically avoid using 'sarcasm alerts', but this time I'll make an exception.
author: Applaudanum

text: So what's the current Guardian tally for bringing us articles on government incompetence as identified by Labour vs articles along the lines of 'That Corbyn is a bit of a dill isn't he?'? Is it 1 to 1000 or 0 to 1000? I've lost count.
author: Applaudanum

text: Read the offending tweet again. He literally said nothing of the sort. It is the reader, including Schumer, fills in that particular interpretation based on their own experiences and inclinations.
author: Applaudanum

text: The perpetrators having been in their adopted countries longer than the recent 'Merkelese' refugees, doesn't help quell local European concerns over a lack of integration. In fact, it makes those concerns more pronounced.
author: Applaudanum

text: I take it then that you would be ok with Indonesia withholding information from Australian authorities should they (the Indonesian authorities) have information about plans for a crime being committed in Australia by Indonesian nationals? Presumably, you would also think it ok for Indonesia to wait until the crime is committed, and for the perpetrators to arrive back in Indonesia, before they made any attempt to arrest them under Indonesian law? Do you really think Australians would be in favour of such a situation?
author: Applaudanum

text: My response was to you, who was talking about influence, and not the article that was talking about language. Would you care to comment on why the exact same words and presentation would affect some listeners and not others? Surely the evidence would suggest that words may have the capacity to influence, yet they can't be relied upon to influence, nor can they be relied upon to influence uniformly. I would take Zappa's position to be that without a reliable and predictable scope of influence, words have little effect beyond an individual's pre-existing susceptibility. It is precisely this pre-existing susceptibility, rather than words, that creates danger for that individual and their potential victims.
author: Applaudanum

text: The influence of language that you are talking about doesn't occur in isolation from other influences. It is the myriad of other influences that generate harm in individuals (or relatively small groups of people) rather than those same words that are bouncing off millions of others every day with no effect at all. To put it another way, and to borrow your phraseology, language causes change in 'a' listener, not 'the' listener. Further more, is it the same change in each affected listener?
author: Applaudanum

text: Genderless pronouns aren't being banned. An Individual is free to use them if they wish (see what I did there?). Instead, the article is implying, although not stating explicitly, that those who continue to use gendered pronouns lack commitment to the progressive cause.
author: Applaudanum

text: That isn't how percentages work. The failure rate of condoms is not measured by the number of people, eg 15 out of 100, but by how many 'events' there were. If 15 out of 100 women got pregnant once in a year, and we assume an average of 50 condom usages in a year per woman, then the failure rate is around .3%.
author: Applaudanum

text: To give gbsydney some credit, he or she didn't say how many women such characters would appeal to. If at least one can be found, then the statement is an accurate description of those women.
author: Applaudanum

text: Et, too, Ed Wood? It seems he was almost right. After all this time, we find that it is Planet 9 from Outer Space.After all, the future will affect us all in the future.
author: Applaudanum

text: They correct for income. Adisadvantage" means grades, test scores, college acceptance rates, quality of college acceptance rates."That's certainly not how I read it in the above article. I read disadvantage as referring to a lower socio-economic background. While I would agree that such a background has a tendency to adversely affect educational outcomes, the amount of statistical correction required, taking into consideration various factors, is sufficiently complex to prevent meaningful measurement.
author: Applaudanum

text: It would indeed be silly to suggest that there are no pushy parents sending their girls to co-ed schools, which is why roomwithaviewofhell didn't suggest such a thing. That's why the word 'likely' was used. Pushy parents are more likely to send their children to single sex schools than non-pushy parents, thus the household attitude to education, on average, is healthier for the students at single sex schools. Yeah, you'll get your outliers, (even when the selective schools can bump out poor performers), but the average will be higher in single sex schools.
author: Applaudanum

text: It has been known, but selective intake and socio-econmic background have always been the main drivers of that difference, as opposed to the 'teaching environment' that one might assume from the phrase 'students at single sex schools outperform their co-ed contemporaries'. It would be interesting to see what the researchers considered as 'disadvantage' and how that disadvantage was factored into the results.
author: Applaudanum

text: Nice quote, and well done in bringing it forward. The author is not seeking to prove that "pejoration happens more frequently to words that refer to women than those that refer to men". It is enough, apparently, to state that others (most linguists) believe it. It is a variant of 'he said', 'she said', and the Fox News classic 'some people say'. We should be thankful that he avoided using 'Some people might think', which I have definitely seen BtL here at the Guardian. Only a matter of time before that phrase makes it AtL.
author: Applaudanum

text: Oh I don't doubt it. It's not necessarily your fault that you don't recognise unstated predispositions that are inherent to your word choices. Expression and language are deeply ingrained and codified. There's all sorts of proclivities, tendencies and effects going on all the time that we don't consider because we're usually concerned with direct communication. But in order to communicate more effectively, we load our words with unstated images and references that, through repeated use, bring about recognition. This last point is where the article falls down, in my view. Gendered words like 'hussy' and 'tart' are a symptom, not a cause. They are used effectively because the words themselves carry enough associations that allow us to recognise the intended meaning more readily. Its our patterns of thinking that are the problem. Or would you instead say that my thinking was f%@*#d?
author: Applaudanum

text: But the Guardian isn't a blog post. It is media outlet that is duty bound to perform particular social functions and answers to various laws, ethics, and codes of practice pertinent to the industry it operates in. Readers have a right to expect that accredited media organisations adhere to the responsibilities that those organisations have agreed to perform and fulfill. It isn't a matter of 'if you don't like it, don't read it'. The Guardian needs to be held accountable for its content. That content should report on events and reflect various social phenomena in a manner that is proportionate to both their level of importance and their magnitude of occurrence.
author: Applaudanum

text: What gender has given the world the majority of bridge builders over the centuries? You may as well be saying that if we were all a bit more man-like, we wouldn't be concerned with these frilly concerns.
author: Applaudanum

text: Repeated requests, from the readership, for more quality control over content are being continually refused. Thus readers are letting their frustrations get the better of them. Not exactly the right thing to do but understandable in some circumstances.
author: Applaudanum

text: According to Hunter Thompson, Bush senior did indeed have an impressive CV holding many powerful and distinguished posts before becoming president. So impressive was Bush Snr's CV, it was second only to Richard Nixon.
author: Applaudanum

text: Think of that as training up the immune system of the general public. This is a free and very important health service that the temporarily unwashed are providing, and look at the thanks they get.
author: Applaudanum

text: It was Buckminster Fuller that suggested up and down were inaccurate and should be replaced by out and in. You go out the stairs, for example, when you move away from the central point of the Earth, and in the stairs when you move toward the central point. It didn't catch on, but it was an interesting idea.
author: Applaudanum

text: That appears to be the same distinction that separates the connoisseur from the enthusiast. For example, I could tell you a lot about the proper enjoyment European Lagers, but I'm not a connoisseur. Film critics, to my mind, have moved from the connoisseurs of yesteryear, to the enthusiasts of more recent times, to something very different today. I don't quite have the word for today's version, but it does involve figurative 'badges of identity' where liking particular things and disliking others marks you out as a 'type'. The critics of today, as I read them, are simply shepherding these 'types' around so that the readers can tell which one they are (or should be).
author: Applaudanum

text: Of course I do. The people in those industries get paid, don't they? I take your point that there may be a lot of people at the bottom of those industries doing free work, but that's a matter for those industries. Will the public get wise to the fact that money in the tv industry that could be going to those people doing free work is instead going to the Kardashians? We can only hope, but it's going to get worse for those free workers before it gets better.
author: Applaudanum

text: The arts that are integrated into modern life that you mention are paid for. Armani gets paid quite well, by all accounts. As do the people who work for Burberry and Calvin Klein. Heck, they pull in a fair wage even with there's all these knock-offs and imitations going around. The arts you see in modern culture, particularly that of popular culture, aren't the result of altruism.
author: Applaudanum

text: Do mean to say that the film, television, music and publishing industries are all currently running on no money? They certainly are being paid for their work already, otherwise it's one heck of a lot of altruism going around. Come to think of it, such a ubiquitous tide of altruism explains why those industries appear thoroughly devoid of altruism.
