It's not our fault if those industries have come to a paying arrangement that rewards the few and the many in such a disproportionate manner.
author: Applaudanum

text: 'All or nothing' might appeal to romantic ideals of artistic penury, but it's a misrepresentation of how artists survived throughout history. They all had to take time out for some kind of life-maintenance or survival. This history books don't mention their day-to-day drudgery that occurred inside or outside the studio. How do you know you aren't measuring your whole life, work and all, against the 'highlights reel' that is the history of art and artists.
author: Applaudanum

text: Why do two thirds of the people who comment on CiF now do it to sneer and insult?Because assuming other people are bad makes one feel better about themselves, and helps them not have to spend too much time thinking about something. They can just shoot from the hip. It's kind of like mental support, but as art. What forms do I need to sign for funding for my meta-sneer comment art?
author: Applaudanum

text: Fine, don't call making art a hobby, call it a lifestyle choice. I can agree to that. If people make choices that, at the end of the day, don't pay very well, then that's their lookout and explains the emptiness of their pockets. Those whose choices lead them to pay their way as far as they can, shouldn't be stung further.
author: Applaudanum

text: We all make choices in life. It doesn't mean we should be paid out for each and every one of them. But rather that our choices should be geared to those that enable us to support ourselves in the community as far as possible.
author: Applaudanum

text: Bloody typical. Those computer and software companies go and make their product easier to use, and now the message boards and forums have become the playgrounds of the daft. Present company excepted, of course.
author: Applaudanum

text: You appear to have a very 'monolithic' view of how what men think about their own relationships. There are no doubt those that like to be boasted about on their supposed prowess, whilst there are no doubt others that believe in a shared intimacy that is of interest only to the parties involved.The phrase "telling [others] about our private life, including details of our sex life" covers a whole range of possible content from 'I'm very happy, thank you' to a 'blow by blow' account. Whilst the article isn't specific on which end of the spectrum the problematic messages leaned towards, my experience (and the assessed consensus BtL) is that on average, a woman discussing her private life will fall closer to the blow by blow account than men do, on average, about their WAGs.
author: Applaudanum

text: Us 'insecure' men aren't telling. That is the one of the points going around.Unless you'd like groups of men to start (yes, 'start'!) getting into blow-by-blow descriptions of their sex lives with their WAGs?
author: Applaudanum

text: Discredited? I just jump straight to BtL and fire away. Works a treat. Mind you, I don't know if someone else made this point earlier. I 'sped-read' the BtL content as well.
author: Applaudanum

text: 'Option Paralysis', fantastic choice of words. Well done. (I had to fight off the temptation to find a better superlative, lest I be caught in a moment of option paralysis).
author: Applaudanum

text: I'm glad to see this admitted at last. It confirms all those less than charitable thoughts I had had for years about all those people wearing skinny black jeans, a non-descript t-shirt, and a thoroughly worn-in flannel shirt.
author: Applaudanum

text: Surely you mean Arabic women? If so, I quite agree. But that's not to discount out the matchless beauty of the women from the subcontinent (those eyes!); the beautiful women of africa (that skin, that physique!); the sumptuous scandinavian seductresses (that complexion, those cheekbones!); the shapely women of latin america (look out, my heart's started to race); the powerful, almost as if carved in stone yet still soft and squidgy, women of northern and eastern Europe; the elusive mysteriousness of women from the far east; and as for Mediterranean women, where do I start? As long as it's right away, I don't mind where. Heck, even chin-deficient british ladies make it possible for me to spill my pint (no, that isn't a euphemism).
author: Applaudanum

text: You should see some of the trends in the teenage demographic, particularly the headscarf, makeup, tight jeans and a figure hugging top. You can almost hear them say 'Yes, Dad, I've got my headscarf!' as they leave the house.
author: Applaudanum

text: If only there was someplace that you could tell people that you've never met that you've never had a twitter, Facebook or Instagram account. I wonder where such a place might be.
author: Applaudanum

text: But someone at the magazine can crop the image, change some of the colours and the definition or focus (if already in focus) of the background, re-jig the lighting a little, gloss over any blemishes and bingo!
author: Applaudanum

text: There's more to being a metal meathead than unsporting thuggish-ness in the mosh. It pervades the whole of the individual and informs their everyday behaviour and interactions with people. Such people are going to be like that anyway, so I'm not suggesting Anselmo is a cause as such. Of course the committed-to-meathead types won't change. Rather, Anselmo validates and promotes such behaviours and attitudes. The people who might have been dissuaded away from such behaviours through lack of reinforcement instead have those behaviours reinforced and others are persuaded to take up such behaviours by further reinforcement.
author: Applaudanum

text: This is my precise recollection of Pantera's rise in popularity. They brought in the 'meathead' to the metal scene. Sure, there were meathead types amongst the throngs listening to Metallica, Megadeth and the like, but they didn't have that aggressive streak to them. They were goof-ball meatheads, if anything. Along comes Anselmo with his shouts, the screwed up face, the muscles-and-tatts, and the borrowed from rap poses and 'fling-the-wrist' gestures, and metal became a thing that 'tough guys (rawr!)' started to identify with.
author: Applaudanum

text: That, at least, is a reason that can be discussed. I personally don't know if it's true whether americans will vote for someone like that, or if Sanders is indeed that far to the left. Would he be more to the left than than Bill Clinton and Obama?
author: Applaudanum

text: Nice pickup.The word 'unelectable' is such a bulls**t word in political debate. I can't believe how much traction and supposed 'authority' that such a word has gained. Anybody who uses that word, without reference to what it is that makes someone unelectable, is trying to pull the wool over your eyes.
author: Applaudanum

text: They are agreeing that the establishment has screwed them and they are willing to go all the way to the edge of the box in a desperate attempt to be heard.The major parties, and those that how to lead them, are simply doing what it takes to get into office. 'Vote for us, we're on your side', is what it all means when you boil it down. Once the party gets in, then it turns into 'Payrises for politicians', 'Ease up on restrictions to the banks and finance sector', and 'Tax breaks for big business', because 'We're on your side, folks'.
author: Applaudanum

text: No, I can assure you, I didn't. For the cheap seats: Once she writes a song, she can sell the rights. Martis1 was correct, she rights (as in sells the rights) to vapid pop songs.
author: Applaudanum

text: We have been tap-dancing our entire lives for your approvalNot likely. If you could have gotten the money with just a lack of approval, as distinct from disapproval, you would have kept at it.
author: Applaudanum

text: Just who is buying this magazine, Stuart? Is the readership predominantly men, or predominantly women? I'd be surprised if more than 10% of buyers were men.In my view, such magazines and their seeming popularity among women confirm the observation made some 40 years ago that 'Men look at women. Women look at women being looked at by men'. The difference here is that men aren't actually looking at those women in that particular format. Rather, it is assumed that men would be looking at these women if they just happened to be around. As it happens, that's a pretty good assumption, yet that doesn't change the fact that all this is happening (the encouragements that 'you could do it too' and the 'what else is worth doing?') without the direct participation of men.
author: Applaudanum

text: Warner is vice captain of the Australian cricket team, not some junior nobody. Where is his assertiveness? His volition? He had a leadership decision to make for two players. One of those players was neither involved nor affected, so he effectively had a leadership decision to make over what he alone would do. What the hell. Give him a ribbon for participating, tell him he's a good boy and that it wasn't his fault he went out.
author: Applaudanum

text: What you describe happens here as well. Heck, I've had it happen to me in 'meatspace'. People are becoming accustomed to taking offence as their first available response. Screen life is affecting the real.What is worth remembering, either online or in real life, is that those who take an unpleasant interpretation of your words as their first option are doing so with the express intention of thinking the worst of you. The thought that you can be (or are) better than their unpleasant interpretation doesn't cross their mind. Life's too short for that kind of negativity.
author: Applaudanum

text: Rubbish. The horse is clearly the subject of the photo. Rub out the horse, the photo is achingly dull. Rub out the people, it's a great photo of a horse.
author: Applaudanum

text: You make a very good point, BA. Tv is a dead medium for advertising. When was the last time someone asked you 'Have you seen that great ad on tv?'. You are now more likely to hear 'Have you seen that great clip on Facebook (or YouTube)?' or have someone send you the link diectly.
author: Applaudanum

text: It was the reference to Aryans in the specific context of being 'approved' whilst non Aryans would be 'non-approved'. It's borderline, sure, but close enough to trigger a moment of mirth amongst the dedicate readership. I can see you are about to ask a question at this exact point along the lines of 'Does this mean that any literal reference to Aryans invokes Godwin's law?' (How did I know you were going to ask that?) Of course it doesn't. That would indeed be silly and worthy of invoking another law, one that unfortunately remains yet to be coined, pertaining to the appeal to excessive literalism for the purposes of scoring a cheap argumentative point.
author: Applaudanum

text: Yanis is talking about how infrastructure and employment is distributed in the region. To use an example he uses himself: If the yanks need something built and the location isn't that important, areas within the U.S that are economically poorer are put forward because the resultant employment opportunities stimulate growth in that region, thus helping the local economy. You can't do that in the EU because of each country is putting their own interests first.
author: Applaudanum

text: I call those small pesky flies 'square flyers'. They are quite entertaining to watch. They'll do their square circuit a few times, than a sudden crazy deviation for about a second, then back to the square circuit. You can watch it for hours. Beats what's on telly.
author: Applaudanum

text: Their usual point of entry, particularly on older cars, is to crawl between the gap between the door and the car body. You can find them just sitting there in the door frame trying their best to be inconspicuous.
author: Applaudanum

text: This article contains a heck of a lot of facts surrounding what 'He said'. I can't deny that such facts are of particular interest to the media, who can use such facts to contrast whatever 'He said' or 'She said' facts take place in the future. Yet for us readers who might not have the facts pertaining to the cost of health spending and where that funding comes from over the last 15 years, such 'He said' style reporting is of remarkably little benefit. What, Guardian, do you suppose we do with the information you have presented us?
author: Applaudanum

text: The facts are even more slippery than that. You can get anybody to state an opinion. Put a 'he said', 'she said' etc, in front if that opinion and you've got a whole new fact. That fact being that a particular individual did say what was said. Whoever claims that news outlets (including the Guardian) aren't full of facts is wrong. It's just that the facts aren't always what you think they are.
author: Applaudanum

text: Also, when they say 'crumble' they really mean drop $60K on current prices. They'll pick up they house they were eyeing off, and then pick up an Audi with the savings made.
author: Applaudanum

text: One's of them is bound to be right sooner or later. Could be this one, could be the next one. Could be the 64th one down the line. But hey, don't blame the bearer of bad news.
author: Applaudanum

text: I respectfully disagree. The situation, as implied by the author, was that the particular someone really believed that the was real aggressiveness. By contrast, I'm suggesting that people say there is aggression where there is none, and where they don't believe there is any, purely because they don't have a proper argument to fall back on.
author: Applaudanum

text: Oh I dunno. 'That young woman is walking on the same side of the road as me. She's obviously flirting with me'. Or, 'That young woman stood in the elevator with me, over in the opposite corner and took special care not to look in my direction or acknowledge my presence. I'm picking up the signals. I've still got it'.
author: Applaudanum

text: The box office only measures how many people paid for a ticket. It doesn't measure whether viewers liked the film or not.People are often lured into (or away) from a film based on testimony from their peers. Yet people also wander in in the basis of the actors, the director or the subject matter. Furthermore, no one adheres to just one of those two attendance styles for the rest of their lives. They switch between the two on a case by case basis.
author: Applaudanum

text: It's more the moronic munching that boils my proverbials. It's not just the invasive sound but also what it signifies. You go to 'gold class' a couple of times and going back to cattle class is a real ire opener.
author: Applaudanum

text: Their employers will have a slightly wider profit margin, assuming their customers aren't affected by the penalty rate cuts. But the business landlord who leases the property to the business owner will get wise to this wider profit margin and jack up the rent before you can say 'transfer of wealth upwards'.It will be those business property landowners who will have extra money to spend in the economy. Pushing it off to the Caymans is a popular economic stimuli.
author: Applaudanum

text: But you could have done it, just like he did. You just needed to do what he did. I'm not saying he wasn't lucky, or that the system doesn't need looking at. Rather, he participated in the system according to the rules. If the other Senate candidates independently chose to distribute their preferences his way, by putting him ahead of their more established opposition, that was their lookout.
author: Applaudanum

text: I'm quite supportive of the changes, depending on the particular implementation. The '1 or the 100' way was far too much of a contrast. Being able to put 6 or 12 is a good middle way. Mind you, what's Muir done that was so bad? Last I heard, he was a model representative. Far better than a major party lackey who does what the party wants and to hell with local or state sentiment.
author: Applaudanum

text: Aren't you supposed to number all the boxes on the House of Reps ballot paper? There's only ever 7 or 8 candidates. If you follow a party's 'how-to-vote' pamphlet, you are giving in to their choice of preferences. Lucky, following a 'how-to-vote' pamphlet is not compulsory.
author: Applaudanum

text: Indeed. People of a leftist persuasion are much poorer for the Guardian's lack of backbone and editorial fortitude. *Note to the Guardian: Better arguments and explanations of complex events are obtained by confronting the difficult realities when they occur, not by avoiding them and hoping they will go away. It's kind of like how young readers get better by reading books that are above their skill level. They don't get better by reading only at their skill level.
author: Applaudanum

text: I'm not sure how the commerical media where in on that though, everyone knows after the fact he lied, but how can someone know before the fact?The commercial media get in on it by filtering out the stories. They highlight the ones that show one party in a good light and the other party in a bad light, whilst limiting or burying stories where the good and bad lights are swapped around.Then you add in the various 'he said' and 'she said' stories where what was said (eg, 'Party in disarray') becomes a big headline, or not, depending on who is looking good according to what was said.
author: Applaudanum

text: If you've numbered your preference below the line, how did Labor get their mitts on them? If you've numbered above the line, you've put your faith in people who have repeatedly let you down.
author: Applaudanum

text: I've been in a very similar situation. While I didn't exactly say 'Talk, you bastards!', the response I got was along the lines of 'I'm following what's go on around the table. If something grabs me, I'll participate'. Seemed to me like a variation on 'When you get interesting, I'll start talking'. So I decided to continue being my 'un-interesting self'.
author: Applaudanum

text: Now that the information is in the grasp of many people, the difference to human existence, if we assume here us such a thing as a 'path' without that information, is certain.
author: Applaudanum

text: So which brands are now being affected? The article says that all Italian brands will be tarriffed up, but it also said that there was a 2014 ruling already affecting other Italian exporters.
author: Applaudanum

text: They should also foot the bill for the total cost of policing those particular laws, along with the costs associated with administering justice (for those laws) for one financial year. After all, if there was no corruption, we wouldn't need to incur the costs to police it. It's kind of like user pays, where the perpetrator has an expectation that they will require justice rather than evade it.Pinning the total cost of policing and administering justice for those laws may sound over-the-top, but I'm not entirely heartless. They would only be up for the total cost if they were the only one caught in that financial year; If two people were caught, that would be half the cost each; If four people were caught, that would be a quarter of the cost each, and so on. How's that for an incentive to see that justice gets done, eh?
author: Applaudanum

text: Sorry, I meant 'older' as in women that are older than other women, as distinct from women that are older than myself. Seeing as a quibble over a minor expressive slip-up forms the bulk of your recent post, are we to assume that you agree with the general thrust of the argument? Seems odd that you wouldn't mention a disagreement if that were not the case.
author: Applaudanum

text: Precisely. All sorts sags are well underway by then, as they should be. It's what happens to real, everyday, people. But these perfectly normal signs of aging, the little sags, the pockets of fat collecting here and there, the weird creases, are too much imperfection for Lena 'I don't care about billboard perfection' Dunham to flaunt. Ironically enough, it is her newly found refusal to flaunt her imperfections that now confirms her commitment to the Hollywood status-quo of billboard perfection and renders her previous claims, claims that she was doing it for a more realistic representation of women's bodies, as dubious.
author: Applaudanum

text: Seems a striking coincidence that this new found appreciation of modesty should occur precisely at time when we could reasonable expect the aging process to push the body ever so slightly beyond the 'imperfectly normal' into the 'icky normal'. Is Dunham's 'new' normal too 'icky' for show?
author: Applaudanum

text: The left appear to be having a type of 'we are the world' moment. Sure, we could look after "our" lowest paid workers, their services and their housing, but what about the "world's" lowest paid workers, their services, their housing?
author: Applaudanum

text: Take a beautiful and majestic plant from the rainforest and put it in the desert. Does it stay beautiful and majestic? Take a hardy cactus from the desert and put it in the rainforest. Does it stay hardy?Genius may be born. But it has to be looked after in the right conditions or it dies.
author: Applaudanum

text: It takes real effort, I can't disagree with you there. But the work is geared toward maximising 'exchange value' rather than 'use value'. Its aim is to shift money from one pocket to another, or to get people to 'play' at things whilst not really doing anything (Hi BtL. Fun, isn't it?) whilst being encouraged now and then to shift their own money from their pocket to that of another.
author: Applaudanum

text: At the level of knowledge required to really excel at the sharp end of those activities, one isn't dealing with concepts or phenomena that can be widely understood or verified by the general public. In other words, the badge of 'genius' in these fields can't be verified independently. The people working in printing journals or getting orchestral music performed aren't really experts in the fields they work in, not at the sharp end. Rather, such folks are experts at the blunt end. They have to be. Thus the need for independent bodies (ha!) like universities (double ha!) to do the accreditation leg work so that we know we are getting the real genius from the sharp end.
author: Applaudanum

text: Such a charity would have to be a large organisation. Large organisations typically have a few people at the top calling the shots to the people actually doing the work. Those people at the top, yes even at charitable organisations, get paid a very very good salary. Thus the people at the top are the sort of people who are attracted to money and are readily 'bought'.
author: Applaudanum

text: So, according to your plan, if I invest in property and run it at a loss (because the real money comes in when I sell it), can I use that to bring my earnings down to below 50k?
author: Applaudanum

text: 'US says'. Both articles. On the basis of those articles, I have no reason to doubt that what was reported as being said was actually said. Mind you, some people can say anything.
author: Applaudanum

text: If interest rates go up house prices will fall. Some might take that fall in prices to mean that those houses would then be more affordable. They'd be wrong. Those houses would be exactly as unaffordable as before. The only difference is that those currently with a mortgage will find that their repayments have now become less affordable.
author: Applaudanum

text: Do I have the right to use my money to provide for my family instead of having to pay for your arrest because you chose to engage in acts that could be reliably predicted to require police action? Does the government have the right to steal my money to pay for your use of the police service and the legal system? That is the current system. I must choose to pay for you to get shot. Can you loan me a 20? C'mon. It's not like you're going to need it.
author: Applaudanum

text: We'll be waiting a while to find that out. We still haven't seen if he gave up his British Citizenship, which he was supposed to do when he first became an MP over 20 years ago.Having to return 20 years of Ministerial, Cabinet, and Prime Minister pay plus allowances (need to get NASA to do the calculations for all that) because they were gotten by fraud is going to a bit of a budget windfall.
author: Applaudanum

text: (heck, even the first one) would make a good example of where Hollywood is going wrong in this regard. You've got 4 women in the 4 leads where the vast majority of the audience would have been women. Was it not an empowering film? How does it compare to the  which had 4 men in 4 lead roles?
author: Applaudanum

text: Then what are you complaining about Hollywood for if you don't watch their movies anyway?On a related note, purely hypothetical, if you don't watch Hollywood movies how do you know they don't contain realistic depictions of the lives of ordinary women?
author: Applaudanum

text: The two aren't exactly mutually exclusive. How can you tell what's down to the script, what's down to the actor's interpretation, or what's down to the direction?From the perspective of the viewer, the one actually receiving a potentially positive representation of women that will go on to inform their day-to-day life, you can't separate the contributing factors.
author: Applaudanum

text: Right, and Inzaghi's point was that such and age difference reflects what happens in real life. Does a 'Toy Boy' style arrangement happen more often than 'Sugar Daddy' arrangement in real life? No, of course not, and there's very valid sociological and biological reasons as to why the Toy Boy arrangement happens less often.
author: Applaudanum

text: Streep was, quite literally, factually correct. Yet her factually correct point was utterly irrelevant and embarrassingly misplaced. A person indulging in racism directs it towards those whose more recent ancestors are from somewhere different than themselves.
author: Applaudanum

text: Depends on what sort of films you see and what you're looking for. Whenever I see Melissa George in something, for example Triangle, she generates interest beyond her looks whereas Scarlett Johanssen, in my view, can only create character depth to the thickness of cardboard - and pretty flimsy cardboard at that.
author: Applaudanum

text: There's attractive women all over the various age brackets. But it's what goes on in their heads that influences their public persona and personal bearing that makes them attractive. Those that have to rely on superficial appearances (note the words 'rely on'), typically don't have what it takes to make them attractive going on inside their heads. If you'll forgive the generalisation, they are ugly people inside their heads if they have to  their looks generate attractiveness.
author: Applaudanum

text: Indeed. Take a look at the titles of these works by him published in his lifetime: Arithmetica Universalis, Opticks, Philosophi? Naturalis Principia Mathematica, and De motu corporum in gyrum. It's like they're in a foreign language or something.
author: Applaudanum

text: Those majority of Syrians who voted for Assad? Those Syrians who, before the current conflict, enjoyed a culture where people of different religions and sects got on with their lives without much conflict?
author: Applaudanum

text: No, they'd just need to manage a few more clicks on their computers. An elaborate set of bookmarks in their internet browser should be able to manage it. There's plenty more outrage in the web.
author: Applaudanum

text: A smaller, more focused operation that did a few things superbly well, you say?What's the point of twitter, then? Is it to encourage communication between people or is it to make money for a vastly smaller group of people? That's where your focus is going to be pointed towards.
author: Applaudanum

text: Thanks for that, Steve. Yet how do we know which measure (median or mean) journalists are using when they say things like 'The average wage is x' or 'the average wage has risen by x'?In Australia, for example, the reported average in the media and by the statistical bodies is around $20k higher than the median. No one talks about the median, let alone the growing gap between the median and the mean. The average, at least in wage discussions in Australia, is taken to be the mean, and the raise in the average is used as a justification for raising the costs of services.
author: Applaudanum

text: Sorry Steve, I'm going to need a bit more explanation for that one. It sounds as though you are saying that it is the median, rather than the mean, that is being reported in articles when they mention that 'average wages have risen x%'. That can't be right, surely?
author: Applaudanum

text: Is the average person doing better? An rise in the average could be down to extraordinary increases at the upper end of the spectrum whist everyone else has flatlined. Wouldn't the median give a better picture?
author: Applaudanum

text: Good to hear it, fluffybunny. To take articles in the Guardian as a rough approximation for overall feminist commitment to particular causes, how's the article count for paternity leave measuring up against articles about female quotas in positions of power?
author: Applaudanum

text: Your point, supposedly, was that you believe in equality. Yet you appear to favour preferential treatment for some. Missing out on promotions because you've taken 18 months out of the workforce, and for the next 5 years are only doing 3 days a week at 10am-4pm (on the dot - no exception), happens to men as well, you know. So when it does happen, either to a man or a woman, it is always a direct result of their choices.
author: Applaudanum

text: If an employer holds a position for a female worker for 2 years so that she can pick up where she left of when she returns, but doesn't do the same thing for men in the office, are they being treated the same?
author: Applaudanum

text: I love doctored cards, they're hilarious! Well, maybe not the example in this article, but the child's birthday card with a big number on it and an out-of-place digit added to it is always a winner. Great for teenagers who try to be serious and moody: you can give them a card with teddy bears or rainbows on it and your crudely drawn '1' is guaranteed to slot in.You have to be careful though, the age is often included in the message inside the card, so you have to check if you can doctor the number there as well.
author: Applaudanum

text: Because the adult parents of teenagers can then converse with their children about popular culture in a manner akin to peers rather than as parents. That's what you want as a teenager isn't it, for your parents to 'rap with you and your homes while you're just chillin in the crib, bro'?As they say in the classics, 'Crib bro quo'.
author: Applaudanum

text: The big problem is that no one is going to take on the planning and building of infrastructure. To take Melbourne as an example, our public transport system was built decades ago. Many of the pieces, (most of the train and tram networks) decades and decades ago. Yes despite there being many more users of public transport than decades and decades ago, and despite there only being routine maintenance and some tinkering around the edges (not counting the proposed extra city -airport line), the system is still too expensive and the governments are flat broke. What are governments doing differently so that such projects aren't able to be built, yet were possible decades and decades ago?
author: Applaudanum

text: So when shares go down, it's turmoil. When they go up, it's turmoil. Good to know what the benchmarks are for turmoil for future reference.Speaking of future reference, did you know that on every single trading day no one knows for sure which shares, currencies or commodities are going to be up or down the very next day? Talk about turmoil. I don't know how they cope with that sort of turmoil laden uncertainty.
author: Applaudanum

text: My beef is with the phrase specifically, not the cause, and the rallying behind the phrase rather than looking to deeper explanations for complex problems. The phrase, either by design or accident, is used to suggest that any opposition, including opposition over 'what do we now do about it?', is down to an argument over whether black lives matter or not. The fact is, you'll find very few people (as a percentage of the whole) who would openly claim that black lives don't matter, or that black people shouldn't be treated with respect by the state and the criminal justice system. A similar ruse is used by anti-abortionists who claim to be 'pro-life'. The implication here is one who disagrees must be 'anti-life'.
author: Applaudanum

text: I would have liked to have read more about how the phrase 'black lives matter' is an argumentatively irrefutable phrase. I believe it's a more advanced version of the ruse 'Have you stopped beating your wife?'. There are very few, if any, answers that wouldn't directly challenge the unstated intent or illocutionary force, without 'incriminating' the respondent. The meaning of the phrase 'black lives matter', in it's most literal sense, is so obviously truthful that it's mundane. Thus to try and counter it, in any shape of form, is to put yourself on the chopping block for failing to accept such an obviously mundane truth. If one tries to counter it one thus becomes tarred with the tag 'racist', a tarring that Burkeman surprisingly endorses, as only a racist would suggest that black lives didn't matter.
author: Applaudanum

text: I remember when live-music gigs at pub-type venues here in Melbourne finished at 12 or 12-30am. Larger venues like the HiFi would go to about 1am. I don't know how we survived. We weren't even permanently connected to the great electronic 'book-of-knowledge' that would have assisted us in being punctual.Even just a a few years ago, I caught an international band at the HiFi on a Friday night, and I was still able to catch the tram home (pre 1 am).
author: Applaudanum

text: Perfectly clear and sensible. But the wronged individual still has to get on with their life after being a victim. I find that a lot of what is called 'victim blaming' on this types of issues is instead a recommendation to limit the opportunities in which other people can do wrong to you.
author: Applaudanum

text: I have this vision where everybody stops watching commercial tv, and the studios keep making it and putting it out there, louder and louder, more vile and more dumbed-down. The whole thing just gets worse and worse while we all try to look away and pretend not to notice, as though it were some ranting and raving relative that we try not to see anymore.
author: Applaudanum

text: I know Palin isn't running. That's why it's a hypothetical. But hey, if you don't want to answer a straight question that tests your stated commitment to "not voting for bernard sanders because he is not a woman", then that's ok.
author: Applaudanum

text: Sorry, I come form a country where we have to vote, so that influences my way of thinking about it. To rephrase my question for the U.S: So you wouldn't vote for Sanders then? You would have voters contributing to Palin's vote tally, but you wouldn't contribute a vote for Sanders, risking a Palin victory, in order to uphold your stated principle of "not not voting for bernard sanders because he is not a woman".
author: Applaudanum

text: Approximately 150 million women who wont be president this year. Is it their Uterus that is excluding them? Or could it be that voting for President should be based on things other than markers of gender? If you believe it's the latter, you might want to look over Sanders' policies. It appears his view on this matter is more aligned to your beliefs than Clinton's would be.
author: Applaudanum

text: The same thing has happened to me with soft drink. I replaced soft drink with water, or the diet/no sugar soft drinks, and now I can't hack the 'fully leaded' stuff.
author: Applaudanum

text: But how do you know the answers? I'll lay odds that you didn't take both measurements yourself, so you would have had to have been informed at some point. Your reliance on this information for 'knowing' requires a very small leap of faith or, in other words, a belief and confidence in both 1) your sources of information, and 2) your ability to resolve the contradictions that arise from having different sources. Thus it could be accurately said that you are "more confident in [your] own beliefs and less susceptible to outside influences".
author: Applaudanum

text: The linking of 'fact recall' with extremism seems a curious line for a supposed news outlet to take.I take it we wont be having more articles that include a short quiz on current events. The sort of quiz that might determine that x% of surveyed Guardian readers believe such and such a falsehood to be true. Does the Guardian expect that the routine measuring of 'fact recall' in the readership on stories and issues reported by the Guardian might put some shortcomings on open display?
author: Applaudanum

text: It is now apparent that whenever David was invited to play twister, it was either through design, circumstance or protest (his or theirs), that his role in the game should be to hold that big card with pictures of hands, feet, colours, and that thoroughly unconvincing spin-able arrow. So much has this experience shaped his view, he's even blocked out the whole sorry mass of intertwined and slowly writhing bodies laughing and giggling in front of him.
author: Applaudanum

text: Back in the day, some claimed that banana-skins were scientifically proven not to work as we'd intended. But then, science also claimed (back then, don't know if they've revised it) that bumblebees shouldn't be able to fly.
author: Applaudanum

text: I simply answer the door with a rakishly tilted party hat, with a few spots of confetti and a streamer or two about my person, alcoholic beverage in hand, weird glint in the eye, and one of those party whistles. Sometimes though, in a rush to get all those accoutrements together, I forget to turn on my well worn 'party chatter and music' tape.
author: Applaudanum

text: Interestingly, the thing 'nothing' is precisely the thing we can't be. The 'nothing' stands as a kind of impenetrable barrier because once a 'non-nothing' is in there with the 'nothing', and not merely cosy-ing up alongside it, the 'nothing' stops being a 'nothing' and becomes a different thing altogether (i.e. not a 'nothing' anymore).If you can get your head around that, I don't think it difficult but my expressive capacities aren't what they could be, what about the people who think that the impenetrable 'nothing' is God? Are they Atheists?
author: Applaudanum

text: Median average? Surely you have a median (the 'middle' number in a list of values 3, 4, 5, 8, 9) and you have the average (the total, 29, divided by how many are in the list, 5, = 5.8). What the flip is a median average?
author: Applaudanum

text: When the landlords who lease the premises to the business realise that their business tenant suddenly has a wider profit margin, they put the rent up faster than you can say 'trickle up economics'.
author: Applaudanum

text: The Earth's diameter is less than 13,000 km. Use any edge to measure its distance from the sun and it wont have much of an effect on that difference of 5 million. Put it down to the effects of 'rounding'.
author: Applaudanum

text: Excellent point.I was once called to do jury duty for a Supreme Court trial. I went in as a total legal skeptic. Before going in, I was convinced the legal system was an elaborate con designed for dodgy dealing between establishment figures and more sinister types, that it was all arcane jargon, obscure interpretations and outdated customs, procedures and paraphernalia. I was blown away by the meticulous detail and the sheer weight of information that was put forward for consideration. I came away thinking that the procedure served a very real and valid purpose.
author: Applaudanum

text: If all the convictions under Joint Enterprise are put under review, purely because they are of the category 'Joint Enterprise', is that not placing a type of Joint Enterprise upon all the convictions? Are they not all being tarnished regardless of the individual merits of each conviction? It seems that the opponents of Joint Enterprise think that Joint Enterprise is perfect fit for getting rid of Joint Enterprise.
author: Applaudanum

text: Not only that but he was the CEO of an interplanetary organisation. He must have spent loads of money, or gone into debt, to hire all those contractors needed to build the Death Star only to have it (and all those contractors - Thanks ) blown up by terrorists who had recruited his own son. It's Patty Hearst all over again.
author: Applaudanum

text: If they've recently bought, why are they suddenly selling up? How often do people sell up within 5 years of taking out a mortgage or having only paid off less than 15% of their principal?Stamp duty alone is enough to make you sit tight for a little while longer.
author: Applaudanum

text: Thanks Brendon...err, I think.I do agree that the ad challenges gender stereotypes as you say. I'm also suggesting that the ad, by choosing an image of female behaviour that we associate with the more recent promotions of contemporary popular culture, highlights how our own behaviours are susceptible to media influence.
author: Applaudanum

text: Wot?To appear to be involved, I think it better to ask direct questions in such a way that encourages people reading a comment to fill in any blanks one might have.Just saying.
author: Applaudanum

text: Trivialises issues of gender identity? I would suggest that the assumption that his 'strut' conforms (or subverts) gender identity instead trivialises the gender identity of the billions of people who don't perform that type of dancing/strut.My first thought was that it was an absurdist, yet evocative, demonstration of the dehumanising aspects of both 1) group-behaviour and by implication 2), the western individual's susceptibility to various forms of propaganda and group think. I thought it remarkable that such a potent criticism of what the Frankfurt School theorists called 'the Culture Industry', on the very medium which propagates that industry, could be still be possible in this day and age. There's still hope for us all.
author: Applaudanum

text: Not exactly profit though is it? The house that starter purchaser will by in 5 years time, to replace the one they've just sold, will be going up 5% a year as well from now until he or she buys it.
author: Applaudanum

text: Those armchair MRA lawyers would be turning into the amalgam of Sir Galahad and Germaine Greer on the basis of eyewitness testimony from dozens (if not hundreds) of people. I would have thought such people should be encouraged, don't you?
author: Applaudanum

text: Is he a music producer or is he a 'talent/artist' producer? He might be in control of (or oversee) the whole package including music, videos, image, publicity, sponsor/promotions, scandals etc (i,e. the total package). Either way, it seems odd that Sony would deliberately harm sales buy putting in a junior nobody.
author: Applaudanum

text: SenseCir did say ''. The implication is that theatre isn't so boring when it doesn't try to be film and it's a correct implication. The problem has more to do with the need to 'belt it to the back rows', which cinema doesn't require.
author: Applaudanum

text: I recall seeing something that was touted far and wide, by reviewers and not just the company) as being a top shelf, biting, satire. The suggestion was that it would re-invigorate satire for the 21st century (or words to that effect). Woe and behold, it was more of the same targeting of upper middle class consumer habits. OOoooooooo, edgey.
author: Applaudanum

text: We've just had a note from the studio script advisors: the 'f' word is ok, just not too many and not when there is heightened anger involved. Put in a 'c' word every now and then, once every couple of seasons in order to create a bit of a talking point and some online outrage would be good promotion. But we're going to have to remove all references to 'risk-free corporate'. The board feels that this isn't the sort of image that they'd like to have promoted.
author: Applaudanum

text: Indeed, Seinfeld did deconstruct. That youtube video merely described. Thanks for the link... even though I now have to ... pause every few words... in...order ...to lend a bit of ...emphasis...and...  out ... meaning... as though I was really ...... putting in maximum effort to wring out ... (more pausing)... (and again) ... a very wet towel.
author: Applaudanum

text: Shows that are recorded in front of a live audience are edited. The laughter captured off the audience can also be edited. Bit of a boost here, hold off for the right moment there, a single brief cackle in the middle of nowhere for a bit of spontaneity, put in that that real enthusiastic roar of laughter from 6 weeks ago, no one will notice.
author: Applaudanum

text: There was a great moment in The Simpsons from that era where Bart sees Dinosaurs on their tv. He seems excited and a little shocked and exclaims 'It's like they took our lives and put it on tv!'.
author: Applaudanum

text: How we (and others) talk about things in public (including online) affects how we think about things in private. It sets an example about what is appropriate. Speaking for myself, I don't walk around trying to think about inappropriate things just for the heck of it. If an inappropriate thought jumps in, it gets booted pretty quickly. This might sound like harsh self-policing but, in my view, if I can't share a thought later with somebody then that thought isn't adding anything positive to my life.
author: Applaudanum

text: To say one is 'taking a photograph' covers a range of behaviours. You could take a photograph from 30 feet away and not even have the subject of the photo know. If you had a series of photos of the same person at different locations using a zoom lens from 30 feet away, and the subject didn't know, then it starts to be a bit creepy. Not exactly harassment but not exactly legit either.At the other end of the 'taking a photograph' spectrum, you've got barging in front of someone, and 'iphoning' their cleavage. Are all such behaviours just 'taking a photograph'.
author: Applaudanum

text: Men that know each other, you mean? Or men that don't know each other but are standing near each other at the football wearing the same team colours? Wholly different situation.
author: Applaudanum

text: That's a pretty good definer right there. I would also add that if the 'commenter' would have felt a little 'antsy' if a man said that exact same comment to them in the same situation, then they know their comment has a sexual connotation.I'm reminded of that scene in Pulp Fiction where John Travolta and Samuel L Jackson are arguing about whether foot massages (it is understood they are talking about a non professional context) have a sexual connotation. Jackson wins the argument, arguing that they do, when he asks Travolta 'Have you ever had a foot massage from a man?'.
author: Applaudanum

text: Indeed. It is despicable, wholly unjustified and uncalled for. It is bullying, but it is more than that. There's a 'strategic edge', almost like game theory, to some of the more 'level-upped' examples. Try this example:First comment, in my opinion, not harassment. Not polite, rarely pleasant, but occasionally the surrounding context can affect the scenario.Second comment, harassment. No ifs, no buts, no 'but she disrespected me'. Every single time. Harassment.
author: Applaudanum

text: Sorry, I meant 'trying it on' in terms of their justifications, not the initial harassment that is often called 'trying it on' as you say. They are, if you'll excuse the expression 'trying it on about their trying it on'.
author: Applaudanum

text: That's because they're 'trying it on'. They don't really believe their lines about their harassment being 'complimentary', 'harmless fun', 'normal' and so forth. They are simply trying to excuse their behaviour by appealing to the higher authority of normalised behaviour. Because normalised behaviour is agreed upon, they are trying assert a new 'normal' by suggesting that 'Hey, we all agree on this. What's wrong with you?'
author: Applaudanum

text: I think you mean 'there's always two'. My partner's iPhone 4 (bought at the same time) is still going strong. So that's 2 in the same household defying the laws of physics. Even bumblebees defy the laws of physics.
author: Applaudanum

text: Last I heard, the batteries are replaceable. Mind you, I could be out of date. I haven't needed to replace my iPhone battery in the 4 years I've had my iPhone 4 (which I bought after the 5 was released). It's more likely a software update will kill my phone than a physical failure, there really should be a law against that.
author: Applaudanum

text: But books present examples of empowerment and disempowerment. It's not always clear cut, however. A common device is to present disempowerment that the reader can sympathise with whilst casting the 'powers' in a negative light. Unfortunately, media outlets like the Guardian are regularly bamboozled by such devices because they don't have the intellectual capacity to see the negative light being cast upon powerful forces. See the article on opera from last week as a classic example.
author: Applaudanum

text: That's more of a validation kind of thing. The people on tv are important and worthy of attention, otherwise they wouldn't be on tv. I wouldn't, so the argument goes, want to be one of 'losers of no importance' so I better bling up.
author: Applaudanum

text: I recall the scene in the first film where she has to be rescued by Harry and Ginger after she has a little girlie cry in the toilet block. I couldn't believe how brazenly disempowering that scene was.
author: Applaudanum

text: Your lack of elaboration suggests a more passive attitude to debate. Are us non-passive types going to have to imagine what your response entails, like imagining characters in a book?
author: Applaudanum

text: Loading up with hops allows you to hide faults in other areas. The fact that most of these craft beer breweries have an IPA as their flagship beer is purely a coincidence.
author: Applaudanum

text: If something passes in front of my field of vision, that's merely a happenstance (G.Costanza). The guardian could have put up pictures of people covered neck to toe, instead of the ones they chose for this article, in order to prevent any opportunistic happenstances like the one you mention.
author: Applaudanum

text: So which year was it they all wore tuxedos? Mind you, keep publishing the pictures of pretty ladies wearing revealing clothes of varying degree. My Victoria's Secret catalogue has been delivered yet and I wanted to do my bit ... for... errrrr... feminism.
author: Applaudanum

text: Exactly. The correct data off how the charity spends its money (how much goes to needy people vs how much goes to admin) should be published on all of their advertising materials and information leaflets.
author: Applaudanum

text: That's exactly how I read it too. If he didn't mention the 'not so attractives' he would have gotten grief below the line for trying to enforce unrealistic appearence standards. So he does mention it and gets grief for a patroning attitude.
author: Applaudanum

text: But not having the drinks before the dinner out, before the drinks, before the movie, before the after film drinks, before the cab ride, before the late-morning brunch impinges on my freedom.
author: Applaudanum

text: Furthermore, dealing a highly addictive substance requires only a small client base of regular users who keep the turnover coming. Less addictive or 'party' substances require the dealer to deal with a higher number of non-regular users who might drift in and out of the scene, thus increasing the risk of detection.It's a bit like 'survival of the best fit'. Meth is that best fit in the current policing environment.
author: Applaudanum

text: Make other less-addictive drugs more available with safe doses and content, all without the need to deal with the organised crime sector, and meth starts to look a lot less inviting.
author: Applaudanum

text: You're probably right. The price of efficiency I s'pose. Mind you, best keep quiet on the ol' barrel-of-a-gun motivational method. I can really see Private enterprise adding it to the armoury.
author: Applaudanum

text: We could listen to the analysts at NATO, or we could go back and read Guardian articles that predate the Russian involvement in Syria. How often, Ukraine aside, did Russia get name checked as a participant in articles on European affairs in the first 9 months of last year? If Russia wasn't being mentioned regularly 4-14 months ago concerning European affairs, then either they weren't involved or we were poorly being served by this particular media outlet during that period.
author: Applaudanum

text: I tend to see comments from people who are angry at the double standards where support for the destabilisation of Syria, for example, is barely commented upon and supported above the line. By taking a 'flowchart' approach to cause and effect, one could readily observe that without the aforementioned support for destabilisation we wouldn't have had cause to worry Putin because he wouldn't have gotten involved.
author: Applaudanum

text: I used to have a pair of army surplus trousers from the early 1960s. Rugged, great cut, and so very comfortable. They had this odd 'wrap around' strap system that went around the waist that included a little buckle on each side. Do you think I could find another pair anywhere? No. So I had to wear that pair one all the time until they eventually disintegrated. Took 'em a while.
author: Applaudanum

text: It seemed to me that Rongan was suggesting that poverty is a serious problem that the issue of 'gender' isn't addressing, as distinct from not being bothered about 'gender'.Are the few women in either party making a stand and actually 'crossing the floor' (going against their party) on policies that would, if implemented, adversely affect women?Politics, as odd as it may sound, isn't a lifelong vocation or dedication. In fact, the rise of the 'careerist' politician has brought further disdain and mistrust upon our supposed leaders. A childish veneration of identity type over person-hood (in other words, a lack of empathy for those who are different from you) would have hopefully grown out with the baby teeth by the time an individual thinks that they have the intellectual fortitude and necessary experience to make a difference to society.
author: Applaudanum

text: We could always follow the lead from capitalism and outsource our baby production and child-raising to countries that do it cheaper. Ship them in when they are at school age, pay a premium for those countries that are supplying product with English language installed, and then aspiring parents can compete with child-free people in the workplace on more of an equal platform. That does raise the tricky (for some) issue of genetics where the argument is that parents don't feel the same about non-genetic propagation. But I'm of the view that those who would treat an innocent child differently on the basis of genetics probably aren't the sort of people we should be relying upon to raise successive generations.
author: Applaudanum

text: What your 'memorial/statue' distinction misses is the 'process' of history. How ideas change and mutate over time is an important part of how our history operates. A statue is the ideal form in which to represent both the transient nature of the individual (the ideas and life within which are subject to change) whilst also retaining permanent form (relative permanence in the case of humankind). Statues (the revered kind) and memorials both aim to impart an unchanging lesson for all time. But this unchanging lesson doesn't exist.
author: Applaudanum

text: Those people at the D-Notice office must be busy. All those millions and millions of twitter and facebook posts to sift through every day in order to shunt the media away from them.
author: Applaudanum

text: Keeping the statue whilst encouraging a general awareness of history in the surrounding culture allows people to discover and access these ideas on their own terms, in their own time, as part of their lives. In short, they learn it and retain it because they discover it when they need it. Lectures and films, by contrast, happen in a space outside the everyday interaction of life where the message risks 'bouncing off' the listener, achieving nothing. People switch off and think 'yeah, yeah, yeah, whatever' when the information isn't of use to them in their life at that time.
author: Applaudanum

text: Wrecking ball, bulldozers, explosives. Many ways to choose from. Flatten the area and build giant tower blocks to house refugees and migrants. Just think how many thousands we could put in there. Isn't that more important?
author: Applaudanum

text: I would have thought it better to hold meetings and talks concerning social issues right under the nose of the statue. That would show history who's boss.Then toddle down to help out at the foodbanks and the soup kitchens. Oh, that's right. You can't take selfies while you're peeling potatoes.
author: Applaudanum

text: Hows the 10-15 year trend on rent? Still less? You are correct about mortgage payments including a component of 'dead money'. Interest is 'dead money' just like rent. The difference is you can do something about the amount of interest you pay'. Did you know that you can save 66% off your dead money by just doubling up on your payments?
author: Applaudanum

text: No at all hypocritical. It is not an interviewer job to give opinions, and less to insult people.If that interviewer is employed by a state broadcaster, then his opinion should be permissible if that opinion is defending the rights, in agreement with the state, of people not to be unfairly discriminated against.
author: Applaudanum

text: Interesting how you give the interviewee a 'Get out of Opinion Free' card by citing the words "I believe", yet you don't give one to the interviewer for "I find". I believe I find that a tad hypocritical.
author: Applaudanum

text: Not that I understand AI at all, but I've found this whole Go caper very interesting in the last couple of months. The two human champions so far have been quite respectful of the computer opponent and appear to have relished the opportunity to be really tested. I've found that to be quite inspirational.
author: Applaudanum

text: Interesting that your example is of the human changing the rules and adapting faster. What if the computer changed the rules and didn't tell the human (in your example, you make no mention of informing the computer of the rule change)? Who is going to adapt fast then?
author: Applaudanum

text: It might just be a male reaction to the sight of an attractive woman in pyjamas or lingerie-looking dayware, but I must confess both types of attire project an unspoken message of 'I'm not that far from the boudoir'.
author: Applaudanum

text: That's the thing about art, the whole thing isn't necessary if only the point mattered. How would an art gallery be if little cards with a short line or paragraph outlining the point were to replace all of the artworks? Replacing Guernica with a small card saying 'Picasso didn't think war was a good idea' would have the same effect on the viewer? Of course not. The same goes for Easton Ellis. Like it or not, the depravity is part of the experience of reading the book and 'colours' the way the point is being expressed.
author: Applaudanum

text: I thought the Bateman was supposed to be an allegorical symbol for the wider society. Mind you, he still could be. It's just that he wouldn't be trolling social media but rather, symbolising social media.
author: Applaudanum

text: You'd be right to be skeptical Stuart, if it weren't for the consistent observation that feminists are soft on sexism in minority cultures. To criticise minority cultures on the grounds of not conforming to Western ideals is, apparently, to articulate the superior attitude of the coloniser.
author: Applaudanum

text: It strikes me that there's an 'upgrade' mentality to health that is aimed at young people. Having a kale smoothie would be like keeping your OS running at full pace in top condition. It's just that with so much information on many different healthy options, much of it conflicting, people can't work out if getting a CPU upgrade, a RAM upgrade, or an OS upgrade is going to benefit them the most. Hence the anxiety.
author: Applaudanum

text: Indeed. The 640 Billion dollar question. Exactly which pile of funds, whose big mega stash, will be depleted and replaced with a note saying 'The Government promises to put back'?
author: Applaudanum

text: I was responding mainly to the 'doing without it' part of your comment. It may well be bunk, but it's there. How's that for the church's new slogan for the 21st Century.
author: Applaudanum

text: Interesting rationale that highlights that the literal is not the be all and end all of communication. Post-death benefits go to other people, not you. You've forgotten about them already and you're not even dead yet. Presumably you would want good things to continue to happen to people after you've gone, even if you can't come back to witness it or share them yourself. The good works you've done in your life, or just the good example that you've made of your life, will continue. Sure there's no benefit to you but it's not all about you, is it?
author: Applaudanum

text: People are being upset and inflamed because they are either 1) Ignoring the possibility of a statue representing a warning from a more sinister past, or 2) Assuming that that statue is currently being venerated by everybody else.
author: Applaudanum

text: I can sympathise with the point, but if you remove the statue you remove the possibility of having that particular lesson taught to future generations. You would have to find other means to have that lesson taught. Will these other means sink in?
author: Applaudanum

text: It's not the current certainty of what Rhodes stood for that might one day be challenged, but rather their certainty that the act of removing the statue is the right thing to do. Well, that's certainly how I read it.
author: Applaudanum

text: Relevant to the protesters but not relevant to the article. The article wasn't about the statue, nor was it about Rhodes. It was about the current furore and our present relationship with history, any history.
author: Applaudanum

text: Eject them and have them reimburse the cost of the ticket for anyone who claims to have missed an important part of the performance due to the disruption of the heckler and the heckler's ejection. It's user pays: no heckling means no need for the ejection if you don't want to pay for it.It's rubbish behaviour and needs to be called out, with emphasis on the 'out'.
author: Applaudanum

text: ... Rita Hayworth walks in with a giant martini... care for a sip?... she asks with one raised eyebrow...she turns to Marilyn and says...I just saw Sophia Loren drive up in that Alfa of hers...she's going to be so rapt to see him here...and right then, Sophia busts into the room and she looks right at me... Oh my god!... she says and continues... get Claudia Cardinale on the phone right now and get her over here...he he...this is going to be brilliant...then I could hear a motorbike out in the street...it sounded exactly like Anita Ekberg's BSA Gold Star...
author: Applaudanum

text: The 'all sorts of stuff' response also protects the respondent from having to go into an in-depth discussion including various names and terms that he or she assumes you aren't familiar with.
author: Applaudanum

text: Indeed, beckow. You are backing up Greg's argument against the Guardian's position quite well.Remember also, around the time the Russians began their campaign, they were accused, by Turkey, US and Uk, of hitting a hospital before the Russians revealed that they hadn't even got off the ground yet. Then a week in, Turkey, US and UK all claimed the Russian strikes were 'excessive' (and words to that effect). I thought they were odd responses to someone coming in and doing the job that one was claiming to be doing already.
author: Applaudanum

text: Have to agree with Bluestone. Second half of season 4 is the pivot point. It's as though the creators take the time between seasons to review what works and what doesn't.
author: Applaudanum

text: Generally speaking, eve. The narrative in the US has an undercurrent of 'socialism is going to take away my business, my house, my consumer choices' ready to deploy at the mere whiff of the dreaded 's' word.
author: Applaudanum

text: Such protests (skirmishes) rarely, if ever, show the protestors in a good light and the news media frequently takes advantage and has done for decades. You can't say they weren't warned.Protesting at someone else's speech, particularly if violence is involved, makes you look like an authoritarian who could turn their ire upon anybody in an instant, even honest Joe and Josephine who were just minding their own business. The 'vocal left', sometimes called the 'regressive left', is handing power to the right. Well frikkin' done.
author: Applaudanum

text: Except that Barbara Ellen suggested that she agreed with him, yet he was wrong to say so. We live in a world where you can say the right thing but, depending on who you are or what your identity class is, you can be pilloried for it.Shouldn't we be encouraging the statements and discussion of things that are right, true and correct regardless of the owner of the voice making the statement?
author: Applaudanum

text: I would have thought that restricting a person's attempt to restrict another person's freedom of speech serves to promote freedom of speech. It's similar to not tolerating intolerance serves to promote tolerance.
author: Applaudanum

text: Have to agree with ausgirl. Compulsory voting means that political discussion in the media is less refined and complex than places without compulsory voting (yes, even compared to the U.S!).But it's not all bad. First of all, no one can catch you intentionally casting a 'donkey vote' (I hear that putting smiley faces in all the boxes is one example of the style). Secondly, because voting takes place at school hall and civic halls, some communities hold nearby events because they can guarantee solid foot traffic passing through. It can be quite the community occasion.
author: Applaudanum

text: I agree with the sentiment, yet TV cooking programs often function as 'food porn*' for the viewer. The viewer gets the sensation of preparing a meal without actually doing it.*The term 'food porn' refers to viewing habits rather than the sexualisation of food. For example, if you're watching Nigella produce a fantastic looking meal while you're on the couch picking chip crumbs off your shirt, that's 'food porn'.
author: Applaudanum

text: So basically you're ignoring the observational part of Nick's comment, which suggests that such taxes will always hit the poor the most, & instead prefer to imply that he/she is nasty? Nice move.
author: Applaudanum

text: I think there is a world market for maybe five computers. Thomas Watson, president of IBM, 1943."There is no reason anyone would want a computer in their home." Ken Olsen, founder of Digital Equipment Corporation, 1977.Weve learned and struggled for a few years here figuring out how to make a decent phone. PC guys are not going to just figure this out. Theyre not going to just walk in. Palm CEO Ed Colligan, December 2006 (Apple released the iPhone in 2007).
author: Applaudanum

text: Regarding your last reply to Jason, other countries are feeling the effects of their own booms in the 'qualification industry'. Sure, you could do those sorts of subjects and, presumably, many more. But what were the percentages of the student cohort taking them? Were they each a small component of a more generalist 'arts' degree, as distinct from outright degrees themselves? Naturally, I don't expect you to have such information to hand, but the question is important nonetheless, and there must be such information somewhere. Our higher education institutions are 'administered' to within an inch of their prospectuses. We see a lot of their promotional material for prospective students. We see very little in the discussion of trends relating to what happens to graduates.
author: Applaudanum

text: Because there is only ever a finite amount flowing through the system at any one time. At the next point in time, there may well be more money flowing through the system, but that amount is finite as well. Even with an increase in the money supply, comparing one moment in time to another, the concentration of wealth into fewer hands is still occurring.
author: Applaudanum

text: Would be a bit silly to rely on taking money from people who happen to be wealthier. I mean, look at the collection of wealth as a percentage across society. How's the spread these days compared to 60 years ago?
author: Applaudanum

text: The White House can't sign an agreement either because a building can't hold a pen. Not every sentence that has meaning is literal.What TruthnotPR means is that you can stop classifying other people according to socioeconomic status. But how will you stop other people classifying you according to your socioeconomic status?
author: Applaudanum

text: How wide was the range of courses at the local poly 40 years ago? Was that range targeted towards the local industry? Now ask the same questions of today's versions.
author: Applaudanum

text: Amazing, isn't it? On the one hand we have the most tech and media savvy generation in existence, yet they are all seemingly bamboozled into a catatonic state of despair because the media-farmed dreams didn't come to pass.
author: Applaudanum

text: I quite agree. But surely taxation should be at a level consistent with recent periods of cultural and social expansion. How the heck did brain surgeons, cardiologists, even business leaders, get the motivation to get up and do their jobs a few decades ago when they were paying much more in tax as a percentage, as well as earning much less as a comparison with the median? Did they want to just chuck it all in as 'not being worth the bother'? What make current specialists so, ahem, special, that they need the pay increase, as a multiple of the median, in comparison with the people doing those same jobs before?
author: Applaudanum

text: Lots of scary numbers about what "could" happen, yet there appears to be very little analysis presented that suggests 'why' such things will happen. It's obvious to the point of meaningless-ness that trade will be affected in some degree. Anybody could tell you that, just as easy as a localised market downturn anywhere in the world "could" adversely affect trade. Would an investigation, outline, or projection as to which particular industries are going to have to find new markets to sell to because Europe will suddenly find another supplier too much to ask from our 'newspapers' when discussing this topic?
author: Applaudanum

text: We once had a jar of dried chiilies that was contaminated with tiny bugs. The little buggers were hard to spot as they were red as well. I always wondered what psychotic dreams and visions the poor buggers had.
author: Applaudanum

text: I find it amazing all people dont have a plan for the apocalypse.It's not that amazing. Imagining ourselves as being the full stop of humanity is to grossly inflate our own sense of importance.
author: Applaudanum

text: Bailing out the banks to prevent further damage down the track is a wise thing to do, as you suggest. Yet why wasn't a partial ownership (to the value of the bailout in the form of shares, or a decent cut of future profits, for example) considered?
author: Applaudanum

text: Excellent point. I thought the Guardian was particularly conflicted on this issue. We get lots of articles week in week out about how women aren't taken seriously in high profile industries, yet it seemed that all the Guardian was focused upon was what she was wearing and the responses to what she was wearing. No discussion or lauding of her actual work which won her the award, Guardian?
author: Applaudanum

text: Are you suggesting that the Yanks don't have an interest in Syria? They'd been bombing ISIS from strength to strength for 4 years out of a duty to do the right thing in world affairs?
author: Applaudanum

text: Are you referring to the Syrian subjects that have joined ISIS and other groups resistant to the Syrian Givernment? That's the thing about terrorist groups, their participants are counted as 'citizens'.
author: Applaudanum

text: Thanks for that, Marc, but the specific context here is the availability of a future workforce to run society. It appears you agree that it doesn't matter where the people come from, provided of course there is the right amount and they are sufficiently skilled. If that is the case, then 'locally growing' the individuals of the future workforce is indeed a lifestyle choice because there are no requirements or advantages for them to be locally grown at all.
author: Applaudanum

text: It's one thing to note the origin of a observation as though it doesn't matter. Yet if it doesn't matter, then why mention the origin at all? It's quite another to note that the observation is 'influenced' in some way due to the specific origin of the observation. Redgum, as I read it, has so far refrained from explaining why the specific origin of the Ray's observation matters.
author: Applaudanum

text: What does that matter if the opinion is based in observation and logic? Or aren't white, make, boomers, allowed to have an opinion.Perhaps it's like the Barbara Ellen article on Jamie Oliver the other day where it was admitted AtL that a man shouldn't express an opinion based on fact and reasoning even if the commentator agrees with it?
author: Applaudanum

text: We could always ship people in as early adults to do the work and pay the taxes. You don't have anything against them, do you? Or would you rather that only particular sets of genetic markers were 'allowed'.
author: Applaudanum

text: Let's not mention that whole 'Pen is mightier than the sword' business, or the bit about the 'White House signing an agreement'. Metonyms aren't really happening. It's enough to make one drink a bottle.
author: Applaudanum

text: But discussions about generations are, generally speaking, generalisations. I thought that was generally understood. We know that a selection of particular cultural and behavioural traits are going to belong to millennials more than they are to Xers and boomers, even though some Xers and boomers will share those traits.
author: Applaudanum

text: Collective an incremental damage? I thought western societies were safer, more productive, and more culturally and technologically advanced than ever? Best bin all the stuff created by grown ups then.
author: Applaudanum

text: Not so. MooAndTwo clearly tried to compare women being attacked while travelling alone to people coming home with ski injuries in an attempt to find the 'most dangerous' form of travel.
author: Applaudanum

text: But do those safety precautions extend to 'further precautions' on the basis of the traveler, through no fault of their own, being at a greater than average risk, or being exposed to an additional risk than other categories of travelers?It would appear that Bates thinks not. This, in my opinion, is bad and dangerous advice.
author: Applaudanum

text: Best to compare like with like, Moo. Are women travelling alone (sorted by destinations, duration and activity type) more likely to be attacked than a woman in the company of women, women in the company of men, men alone or men in the company of men?
author: Applaudanum

text: But we can't stamp out the people who perpetrate violence, those in other countries are even harder for us to stamp out. So, in the spirit of doing what we can, we advise people to be particularly wary.
author: Applaudanum

text: You can when a car driver leaves you no option but to T-bone their front side panel, forcing you to slide across their bonnet.The advice to motorcyclists, surprisingly, is not to expect car drivers to notice you. Rather, the advice is to ride with significantly more caution than the average car driver in order to avoid being left with the option of falling off or under cars.
author: Applaudanum
